I figured with all the good reviews on it why not try it. As a kid I grew up on Nintendo and loved their systems back then. My daughter was so happy. It was so much fun making our own Mii characters. The game selection in a lot of stores is great! Plus the price on this system was a score. We played wii sports for hours trying to beat each other. It was really fun. I can't wait to buy some of the family friendly games.

author: Kindle Customer
title: Five Stars
content: Excellent quality

author: Laurel L. Paras
title: The New Age Gaming Console
content: It's the new revolution. It's interactivity and creativity is unmatched. Great for party games and casual gamers. Not that hardcore as the Playstation 3 or XBOX 360 Elite but still... This console will sell more and more. And will bring alot of fun for gamers of all ages. Every family homes must have one. It's a must. For Hardcore gamers you know what you want. You must either have a PlayStation 3 or an XBOX 360 Elite with a Nintendo Wii! OR IF YOU'RE REALLY HARDCORE GET THEM ALL! And of course a Gaming desktop or notebook. Alienware and Dell XPS! YEAH!

author: Ronald Reagan
title: Console Quandry
content:
I admit that when it comes to writing about the Wii I am not entire unbiased.  I camped outside the local Target on release night to purchase my Wii and would have done so even if Nintendo's revolutionary next-generation console were made of granite and had no moving parts.  Since I bought the Wii to exclusively play one game, namely Super Smash Brothers Brawl, I also make poor financial decisions.  This being said, however, (and ignoring whatever bias I might have against Microsoft and Sony) I highly recommend the Wii simply because it is the least of three evils.

Evil, The First:
I would really like to buy an X-Box 360.  It has by far the best game lineup (being out for nearly a year longer than its competitors), it has a very good online service, which can be used to download additional content for existing games and even new games, released only through "Live". The hardware (especially for the Elite version) is very impressive, on par with the PS3 and definitely better than whatever the Wii has to offer.  All of this being said, an X-Box 360 is very expensive.  The Elite version costs close to $500 dollars and, of course, most of the newly released games are $60 instead of $50.  Even this would not be a problem if it were not for the conspicuous hardware failures that numerous (I have actually seen the legendary RRoD with my own eyes!) 360s continue to suffer.  Paying $500 for a great gaming system is reasonable, but paying $500 for a pleasantly-shaped paperweight is a little pricey.  So the slightly less entertaining Wii costs half as much as a 360 (assuming you can actually find one being sold at retail price, like I had) and doesn't have any hardware trouble infamous enough to be widely documented.  Wii for the win!

Evil, The Second:
For many years (nearly six, to be exact) I owned a PS2.  With its unimpressive technical specs this console still managed to dominate in last generation's (that makes me seem so old) console war, simply because it had more exclusive good games than the Game Cube and the X-Box put together.  Sony seems to have learned the wrong lesson from the success of its previous console since it made the PS3 a technological powerhouse, complete with a Blu-Ray DVD player and backwards compatibility issues.  The latter wouldn't be a problem except that the PS3 has no good exclusives on it.  Yes, that's right.  Not a single game exclusively out for the PS3 is amazing enough to warrant the system's $400-$500 price tag.  If you don't believe me, go read some reviews.  The best of the best on the PS3 are all multi-platform releases, available also on the 360 (and sometimes on the PC).  Sure, there are promises of Final Fantasies and Metal Gear Solids, to be available sometime in the future, but, right now, the PS3 is just a DVD player.  By comparison, the Wii already enjoys a variety of exclusive first-party releases.  In fact, after being out for a little over a year, the Wii already has the standard Nintendo lineup: a Zelda game, a Metroid game and a Mario game (I'm steadfastly ignoring the Paper Mario game, Monkey Ball game as well as several others).  In about three weeks, the new Super Smash Brothers will come out, providing yet another reason to buy a Wii.  In addition to all of the new games, it is backwards compatible, so it can be used to play old GC games, as well as numerous ancient games, purchased through the Virtual Console.  If the PS3 ever gets Home working and if it ever gets its promised exclusives, then we can talk about technological superiority or HD resolution.

Evil, The Third:
I might have already mentioned the advantages the Nintendo Wii has over its competition.  The price, the games (though it does have a lot of shovelware, which I assume smart people won't buy), the backwards compatibility.  Add to this the nicely implemented motion sensor controller, the build-in Wi-Fi support and the vaguely Mac-like aesthetic appeal...and I suppose you get that the Wii is the top-selling console pretty much everywhere.

Recently, I have considered purchasing an additional gaming system (360 or PS3), but the aforementioned problems lead me to believe that a new computer would be a more sound investment.

So, in conclusion, buy a Wii or build a PC that can play Crysis.

author: Lee Ann Jaeger
title: Great Fun!
content:
We have had the most fun with our Wii.  It's a great way to exercise when it's snowy or rainy and you just can't bring yourself to go to the gym.  My 76-year-old mom started with bowling (with included sports package) since she is a lifelong bowler.  Then she took up baseball and she's been hitting more home runs than 47-year-old me!  The fitness test is fun to see where you rate in fitness every day.  I've found that I am not a bad golfer, although I think folks would cringe if I was actually out on the green.

Wii has also been great fun for my Big Brothers Big Sister "Little" and I to play together.  She is an awesome bowler for being only 10.

I just bought Boom Blox and I've been learning how to play it.  It's only throwing, so if you want an all-around aerobic fitness routine, definitely try the sports package (golf, baseball, tennis, boxing, bowling).

P.S. Making your avatar (Mii) character is also some of the silliest fun you'll ever have.

author: Timothy A. Coonfield
title: Innovation and gaming at its finest!
content:
The Wii has been released and it has represented to me the biggest revelation in gaming since I got my Nintendo Entertainment System back in 1986.  I've been an avid fan of the PS2, but with the new generation, Sony and Microsoft seemed to focus simply on making their consoles more powerful.  Better graphics, etc...

But with the Wii, Nintendo did something different.  They innovated and created a new way of gaming.  Something that differentiates from the previous generation in ways other than pixel counts and load times.

By now, everyone and their grandmother knows about the new motion sensitive controller.  As you wave your controller through 3d space, you guide your on screen self to swing a sword, roll a bowling ball, or suture a wound in surgery.  You quickly find yourself immersed in a new experience like no other.

The Wii package includes Wii Sports, a package of 5 small sports games built to show off the Wii capabilities.  Tennis, bowling, golf, boxing, and baseball are included, and while simple, these games will keep you and friends entertained for hours as you whale away with your new toy.

A great set of launch games quickly make use of the new controller style.  I personally recommend Zelda:Twilight Princess, Trauma Center, and Elebits.

If you are lucky enough to be able to find this system on the shelves, I highly recommend it.  As a video game player for the last 20 years, i can safely say that this is one of the shining examples for me.

author: Rosemary Simons
title: Five Stars
content: It works fine. We are having a lot of fun with it. Plus getting exercise too.

author: mayte i figueroa
title: May need to return if can’t get a second controller.
content: My daughter is having an awesome time. Easy to put together. Seller sent Sports Wii very quickly after not getting in original shipment. Equipment in good shape however did not include a second controller. I believe that should have been included so that she could play with a friend.

author: Kaila and Erica
title: Five Stars
content: Works great and is so much fun

author: Cozygopher
title: wii console
content: my family and i have had more fun with this than i thought we would. can't wait to purchase more games for it.

author: Crazy Logic Error
title: Very good system, needs more games
content:
We have had a Wii since they came out.  At first we played Wii sports a lot.  But that quickly died down.  Then we had Mario Galaxy, Zelda TP, Mario Kart, Mario Party, SSBB, and Super Paper Mario.  We have since bought more games.  But the kids just seem to play a little and then go back to the 360 and PS3.  Banjo Kazooie, Rachet and Clank, and others.  They get bored so quickly with the Wii and i feel that is because the games, other than the select few that held their attention for a little while, are not that great.  That being said, the system does have a few must play titles and with New Super Mario Brothers Wii coming out it should get played a lot for a while.

The systems controls are great when implemented right.  I bought the Conduit and although the game was a little weak the controls were fantastic.

The graphics can be decent if a company chooses to do so.  Maybe not on par with other consoles but still really nice.

There are some games on WiiWare and of course they have plenty of classics you can download.

Although not included, if you buy or have a Wii i would recommend WiiMotion Plus as it makes for a more responsive motion control in games that utilize it.

This is a great system that would have been a 5-star for me if the games had been there.  Just needs more quality games.

author: Steven M.
title: Fun, innovative, but dated
content:
The Wii, when it first debuted, was an innovative way to game - by making the gamer interact with the game vs simply manipulating a remote, it brought a whole new aspect to the gaming world - and attracted a whole new generation of gamers to the industry.  Old and young alike were willing to game.  No longer were games designed that took immense skill or countless hours to play - now there were games that could be played in a matter of minutes and took very little skill besides following the motions suggested on the screen.

Now, however, the Wii is beginning to show its age.  It still only connects via 480i (or 480p if you buy the special cable), while the competion connects at 1080p (HD).  It has built in wifi, but only 802.11b/g - whereas newer standards exist (a/b/g/n), which allows better streaming, faster downloads, etc.  And finally, with the release of XBOX's and PS3's motion systems, the Wii has lost one of its major initial advantages.  Yes, it still has countless games that require very little skill or time to play - but XBOX and PS3 quickly ate away at that market as well.

What Wii still has that no other system can claim are the franchise games.  Mario being the most prominent that comes to mind.  Many gaming companies have tried to capture the appeal of the Mario franchise, but have found it a hard nut to crack.  Too many gamers grew up on the original Nintendo and Mario to care much about any newcomers to the jump, run, repeat genre.  With the addition of the Wii online store, users can buy old, classic games for very little cost, reliving some of their glory days of gaming.  Add the fact that the Wii now has YouTube, Netflix, Hulu, etc (albiet in 480i/p) and you have a nice combination for that TV in the gaming room that isn't connected to the PS3, Roku box or other network capable device.

Yes, the Wii has likely seen its heyday and isn't long for this world, but it will be fondly remembered as the gaming system that got people to standup and play!  That's something that will never be contested.  The Wii has attempted to rebrand itself (new colors, slightly new design and minor updates), but nothing will put it in the same league with the PS3/4 or XBOX / One.  Perhaps Wii is content with its lot in life.  Who needs to be number one when you can sit quietly, attract the casual gamer and reap rewards off game sales and other little transactions.

Overall, this is a fun gaming system, which I still own and will keep until it dies.  It doesn't get much use these days and isn't the most advanced piece of hardware in my home - but it still gets turned on from time to time, even if only to watch a quick Netflix film in the quiet part of the house.

author: John
title: Came exactly as specified!
content: Great product with almost no signs of use. GameCube controller port cover was missing (however, this was specified in description of product). Save data was still on machine so I did have to clear memory. Aside from that, the console worked 100% perfectly and came exactly as expected. This seller has very few reviews, but in my experience, is very reliable!

author: Nelson
title: Great Fun, Great Price
content: I'm not much for computer action games, or arcade games, but after playing bowling and golf on my son-in-law's Wii I was hooked.  This is great fun and the price is right.  I bought it and play more often than I thought I would.  One thing that this has over other game machines is that your whole body gets involved, not just your fingers.  The graphics may not be HD, but thay are very good and very clear with no noticable motion problems.

author: Anthony
title: my little cousin had one forever ago and I enjoyed it then
content: I have never owned a Wii before, my little cousin had one forever ago and I enjoyed it then, but my only reason for buying one was to play a couple Gamecube games I haven't had in forever and had to re-buy. (Super Smash Bros. Melee, Jedi Knight :Jedi Outcast 2, Star Wars: Rouge Squadron, etc) and also for Super Smash Bros Brawl) it does what I want, and I'm pretty pleased. I only wish the support for this system wasn't abandoned by Nintendo because of the Wii U. All of the neat little channels are done and over with, and kind of lose a little allure.

author: Jonny mendez
title: Five Stars
content: Nice arrived pretty quickly

author: S. Klund
title: Great game, great service
content:
Purchased the WII Fit for our son from Amazon.com... Product was in great condition (New Wrapped), Shipped in time expected, no damage when received.
This is the first time ordering from Amazon.  I plan to order more now that I know I can trust the transaction!

author: Angela Moore-guerra
title: Best Use of Reward Points Ever
content: I had been wanting to purchase a Wii since the launch of the system, but the money tree wasn't producing.  My husband and I decided that instead of trying to come up with the extra money for the system, we would rack up the reward points on our bank card by using it for all of our bill payments and everyday purchases.  It took us a year and a half, but we finally got it!!!  We are enjoying each and every moment that we spend playing with it, and our oldest daughter loves the Wii Sports games (especially baseball.)  It really is a nice system to own that the whole family can get something out of.

author: SCHAUN BISHOP
title: great game console!!
content: was a great game back in the day. especially smash bros brawl.

author: Ricky Hamilton
title: Fun for everyone, not just you.
content:
I haven't really been following game systems for quite some time since the nes, snes, and playstation 1. But after seeing the Wii, my wife and I decided to try it out.  It's absolutly great.  Coming with a game and ready to get online right out of the box.  The Wii remote is great and is spot on.

If you want a system where you, and your friends and family can all play this is definitly the system to get.

author: C. Bayne
title: The best video game system
content:
We have owned an Xbox, PS2, PS3, Dreamcast, various other Sega incarnations, and various Atari systems.  This is the most fun of all of them.  The visuals aren't as good as the PS3, but you get to stand up and move around.  The controls on all of the games I've played on the Wii are very intuitive.

We were lucky enough to get a Wii at Best Buy the day we decided to look for one.  There were none available online (at a reasonable price), otherwise we probably would have bought one from Amazon.

I think my favorite "game" is the Wii Fit.  We did have to wait for that, but it's worth it.  The Wii Play, which came with the unit, is still one of my favorites.  And I like House of the Dead.  Sometimes you just have to go out and kill zombies. :)  Oh, and Mario Kart is also a lot of fun.

What other game can people of all skill levels and ages play together and all have fun?  What other games don't leave you with sore thumbs?  OK, there might be some out there, but this is the best system.  You get your whole body involved and you feel like you've done something.

Now, if Nintendo would just get around to making them a little more available, that would be great.

author: bob schwartz
title: still a lot of fun
content: even though it does not have the games that the xbox and playstation have it still has a lot of games that are really fun to play, it is fun for the whole family

author: AC's Mom
title: WII
content: This is everything I thought it would be and more.  Fun for the entire family!

author: bandy
title: Five Stars
content: Hours of entertainment.  We still use this wii.

author: Joshua Glowzinski
title: a Wii for me is all that need be
content: When I first saw information on the new systems I wanted a ps3.  I had played my ps2 more than my xbox or my gamecube.  But I changed my mind and went for a wii.  I saw someone one amazon saying you could pre order it from f.y.e.  So I did and they called me to come get it a week before Christmas.  I had also pre ordered zelda.  When I first started playing zelda I didn't really get into it.  But now I'm stuck.  The way you have to play games on the wii is great.  It takes something old (video games) and adds something totally new in it's controls.  Also the online aspect is very easy to use and set up.  I think it took me all of 10 minutes to get online with it.  The store is set up very well.  Even if you normally have a hard time figuring things like it out, you will have no trouble here.  The colors of the menus are very nice.  Everything has a relaxed feeling.  You get to set up your own mii.  A mii is a little person you can create on the wii.  You can create as many as you'd like.  This may seem stupid but I assure you that is is not.  The size and weight of the system are all great.  When your moving it around you can do it with ease.  It has a very easy to open door on top that allows you to connect your gamecube controllers as well as your game cube memory cards.  It is so easy to get everything up and ready to play that you just feel perky when your through.  The only thing I would say annoys me is the wired controler bar.  Go on amazon or to ebgames and get the wireless sensor bar.  It is only 19.99 and it works great.  So in closing the wii may not have the highest graphics, HD support or online games but if you get one and play once you will find yourself saying. "who cares?"

author: Roland Martinez
title: Liquid Buys Wii
content: Bought from liquid buys.....before i say anything it came in the original packaging and it came with wii play and wii sports.....this wii is in perfect working order just a bit loud at times and maybe. A few times where it should load faster

author: Goldilocks
title: A fun family friendly consul for years of fun
content:
The Wii is a fantastic gaming system fit for all family members and it has loads of fun family friendly games and has a few nifty tricks up its sleeve. To show you what to expect with the Wii I will talk about some of the main amazing features of the Wii

1. Fun family friendly games
The Wii is a great consul full of many fun games that are family friendly. One thing to expect with the Wii games is that none of them (that I have found) are rated above T (which stands for teens) and a majority of the games are rated E (which stands for everyone) so you can expect your child to have fun beating their games without having to worry about anything questionable occurring in them. The games are also great because a majority of them are multi-player which means you don’t have to worry about kids wanting a turn because they all play together. It’s also great when you have friends over because you can compete with them on the Wii.

2. Easy to use and it has a couple nifty tricks
The Wii is a really easy consul to use. To start off they tell you how it works. In addition, the main page of the Wii is made really simple which makes it easy to figure out what to click on. This is nice because on other consuls like the x-box I found it really confusing to figure out how to work things and find the right button to click. The Wii remotes are also really nice because they have a sensor system within the remote and all you have to do is point at the sensor. After hovering over the correct icon with your cursor you click on the picture that correlates with your desired designation. In my opinion I like being able to use a control stick to go to where I want to go, but the sensor is still easy to use, plus it enables you to play interactive movement games like, Just Dance. Now a couple little nifty features about the Wii include the fact that you can play your old game cube games on the Wii, (you still need a memory card) which is really nice because our game cube broke a few years ago but since we had the Wii we were still able to play good old game cube games. Also you can download really old games on the Wii by going to the Wii shop which is really cool, because it gives you the ability to try out some awesome classic games you probably can’t get these days,(you do need a game cube controller for those games however) so it gives you more game options if you’d like.

3. Transportation
As far as transportation is concerned, the Wii is fair, but it’s not the best. You have to unplug everything and wrap up all the wires and stick them in something, which is not hard, but can be a bit of a pain after a while. I’ve taken my Wii all over the place and have just accepted the routine, so it’s not bad at all.

4. Durability
Durability wise I think this consul does quite well, but I do not suggest dropping it or not handling it gently, because it can still break or be damaged. It also needs to be dusted frequently otherwise dust can get into the system and prevent you from playing some games (I have only had trouble with super smash brawl, because its disk is twice as thick as others). As for how long it lasts, I don’t really know. Mine has lasted for 10 years so far and is still running fine, so it can last for a long time if you treat it well, but I have had friends who have only had their Wii’s last for 2-4 years so I think it really comes down to how well you treat it.

5. What it comes with.
The Wii comes with a stand, a controller, a power cord that gives power to the Wii and another cord that makes it so sound and picture pop up, a sensor, a Wii remote, and a game called Wii sports. If you want to play with multiple people then you need to buy more controllers, because the consul only comes with one. (You only need four controllers total because that is the max amount of people).

6. It’s a bit dated now
Keep in mind that the Wii is an older consul and there are a lot of newer consuls that replace the Wii like the Wii U and the new Nintendo Switch. If you want something new then this is not your choice, but if you want years of fun for your child then this is a great consul that is fun and family friendly.

author: A. Elliott
title: wii console
content: Great interactive games for the entire family.  Bowling is the greatest!!!!  Well worth the price.  Has given this family of 5 hours of enjoyment TOGETHER!!!!

author: Concerned One
title: Inexpensive, wireless, great graphics, fun for whole family.
content: As always, nintendo may not be doing the whole package such as HD dvd or Blue ray, or monster HD graphics, but The 480P, wireless network, unique controlers, and low price tag make this unit a very formitable competition for the X box 360 and PS3.  One thing nintendo has never left out is the whole family.  This unit may not have all of the violent and top selling games at the other two units, but it has plenty of games that are fun, and allowable for 5-8 year olds to play with.  This is worth checking out.  I'm sure you will not be dissappointed.

author: VA
title: From a Xbox 360 owner..!!
content:
I am 30 now and have loved video games since childhood. I have owned Atari 2600, NES, PSP, PS2 & now the Xbox 360. I have also played several others in Gameboy, Gameboy Advance and the DS. I always had a soft corner for Nintendo but since I already own the 360 (which I love) I didnt really feel the need to go for the WII.
But the ever increasing sales and people from all ages raving about the WII made me go for it. Being so fond of video games I didnt want to miss the flavour of motion sensing. So got it last weekend. Here's my take on it.

1) Controls & Gameplay:
To start with its wrong to compare any other high def console (like the 360 or the PS3) with the Wii cos these are totally different products. The former ones are meant for hard core gamers who want nothing but spectacular graphics and detail. The WII is meant for people who either have not experienced video games and the ones who want good entertainment with simple interface and easy controls. (in 360 & ps3 some of the control combinations which are possible with so many buttons on the controller make it difficult to remember). And this is where Nintendo does a great job. It has the most easiest of controls in the games and chosing options on the interface and in between channels couldnt have been easier. It does not give you a cramped up feeling on the screen. Gameplay is very responsive and accurate mostly in all the games. Some people have experienced issues in bowling etc. where the ball turns towards the left. To counter all such issues, just make sure the Sensor is kept in the center of the TV and your controller is at the same level of the sensor while playing. This will give you best results. Also with the Wii Motion Plus getting launched the controls will become much better than they are now.

2)Graphics:
I own a samsung 40" lcd and the 360 looks great on it. Since I knew the WII does not have High Def graphics I wasnt expecting much from it. But after I plugged it on, I was pleasantly surprised with the rich colours and the clarity of the games on WII sports. The distance between my TV and the couch is not more than 10 feet but the Wii graphics still look nicer and much more than acceptable. I was thinking of going for the WII component cable which I wont now. Dont think I require it.
So for folks who have a 29" or a 32" graphics would look neat with an AV cable.

3)Build:
Another thing which impressed me was the build quality of the controllers and the nunchuk. Its very intelligently done with smooth finish on top and slight grainy and frosted finish at the bottom. This gives a real good feel when you hold them for the first time. The console is pretty compact and can be carried anywhere.

4)Wi-fi:
This is a big plus as you dont need to hook up another lan cable or buy a wifi adaptor. It detected my connection in no time and I was online. Havent tried the online features but I downloaded one channel which was free and that seems pretty decent.

The only thing which I hope Nintendo changes is the supply of the worldwide adaptor. This comes with a 120v adaptor only for the US and cant be used anywhere in the world. Today all the gadgets come with a 100-240v power adaptor and can be used in any part of the world. This was the only problem which I have with this bundle.

Lastly 2 points:

1) Its a great extension for all the gamers on 360 & PS3. You should go for it and you wont regret it. It will be a good change from the hard core and online gaming which we are used to now days.

2) My wife who is not a gamer has also got hooked on to this and we have had great time playing tennis & bowling. We are going to carry it to our parents place when we go there next.

Overall, Nintendo has done a great job in getting people together with this product and anyone who is even slightly open to trying it should go for it. You wont regret it.

author: Cindy Lou
title: Wii
content: The Wii console is small and fits out of the way. It was easy to hook up. The only problem I had with this purchase is the remote does not work. I tried configuring it to the console and also tried new batteries, and still no luck. Had to purchase a new one from the store. I have not had time to get with the purchasee to let  them know of the problem and to get a replacement. Schedule has been hectic. So, I can not say they have not corrected this problem because I have not contacted them yet.

author: Rachel
title: Five Stars
content: Pleased with purchase

author: Matthew Williams
title: Great Idea Kids Love It!!!
content: We were originally worried that this may be a little much for our children. We are tired of buying toys only to see them play with them for a week and then in the toy box they go to rarely be seen again. We have a 4 and 6 year old and decided to pull the trigger. And boy are we glad we did. THEY LOVE THIS GAME. They literally played it all day and didnt want to stop at bedtime. I love the fact that it makes them active while playing the games instead of just sitting there. The whole family will enjoy this for a long time. I highly recommend this over the PS3 and XBOX 360 for the kids. And there are a lot more kid oriented games for the Wii also.

author: Andrew C. Yao
title: So far, it's largely living up to it's hype
content:
I've played the Wii at a friend's house.  Did some Wii Sports and
some Monkey Ball games

**SETUP**
watched a friend setup the Wii.  The process wasn't immediate, but seemed straightforward.  The included RF cable was used.  Strange Nintendo did not have the Wii S video cable available at all let alone include it in the box.  The sensor bar was rested horizontally onto the TV more or less center.  There was some physical setup with the wiimotes (attaching wrist straps, installing included 2 AA batteries, etc.).  There was some initial setup recognizing the console and 4 wiimotes (aka Wii remotes) that I wasn't around for, but it was done within minutes by the time I ducked back.  The wiimote is used as a pointing device similar to a mouse and the buttons like a keyboard for menu selection.  Popped in games and launched them from the menu.

**GAMES**
*Wii Sports....
A collection of 5 sports games to showcase the wiimotes' capabilities

Boxing -
It was hilarious to watch some Marine actually furiously punch the air as if he were punching a real person in front of him even though only moderately light movements were required.  Almost took out some furniture and the TV since he got sooo into it.  With the Nunchuck attachment also sensing movement in conjunction with the wiimote, you've literally got 2 fists.  Just before fighting, there's a warm up session/tutorial on how to punch high/low, block high/low, and dodge.

Tennis -
You don't have to worry about positioning and movement.  The AI will automatically do that for by running for it if it's close enough.  You just worry about swinging and hitting the ball with the correct strokes.  Actually, the game can be more forgiving than that.  I used a forehand stroke instead of a backhand stroke and the game swapped it for a forehand instead.  Sometimes the AI doesn't get to the ball on time for those slams or hard drives into the corners, but it would appear that happens mostly to you swinging the racket too soon and causing the player to not be able to dive for it.  There are some funny, comical movements as those Wii Tennis doll players try to "fly" towards the ball.  The moving around done by the AI makes this the least realistic towards the real deal, but I'm sure as a startup game, this was intentional.  I'm sure they'll be other Tennis games to address that.

Bowling -
Similar to real bowling, if not exactly like it.  Before you throw, you line up left/right position and angle of throw.  Whether or not it actually follows that imaginary line you drew in your mind depends on how you throw the ball.  Pressing and holding the underside button picks up the ball and releasing it while making the motion throws it onto the lane.  I'm barely a decent bowler, but it appears attributes like wrist movements and force of throw were accounted for

All the Wii Sports I've played were not quite the exact thing in real life, but then again, the Wii was never meant to be a substitute for the real deal.  Just a closer simulation of it.
The group of people who did play it were able to get into the game fairly easily after viewing the brief instructions whenever a new game is started

*Monkey Ball
A collection of 50 or so mini-games that use the wiimote extensively as well.  The mini-games can span minutes long to even 8+ minutes.

a game where u tilt the platform... (forgot what it's called)
An up-to-down scroller to guide the falling Monkey Ball character onto a target platform while collecting bananas for points.  Kinda like that Plinko game from Price Is Right.  You roll (like when an airplane barrel rolls, NOT to be confused with turns along it's long axis) the wiimote which also tilts horizontal platforms which was a neat way to control things.  It wasn't as enjoyable playing 4 player simultaneous since quarter screen display made it harder to anticipate and see what was below.

Monkey Darts...
Having played alot of real darts, this was quite realistic.  For example, just like in real darts some people who start off don't hit the board they don't throw with enough force so it goes down or they twist their wrist so left-right accuracy goes far left or right.  Using the A button (topside of wiimote) to grab a dart and releasing it to let go, u can get get more solid throws by throwing it with higher force (quicker arm movement).  The one game where higher speeds/force does make a difference.

All in all, the Wii may not be THAT, Revolutionary, but it sure as hell fun and different from the other 2 next gen consoles.  While I can't just strike off games like Gears of War or Geometry Wars as being inferior (despite being terrible at them), I will say only so many people could get into those types of games.  While Nintendo also has games that will appeal to a certain interest group/fanbase, truly any person regardless of video gaming skills and experience could get into these Wii party games.  No opportunity to review Wii's other features like the Virtual Console or multimedia capabilities of the Wii, but so far so good.  It's gaming with the wiimote are impressive and deliver.

author: CM Joker
title: Fun, but not for hardcore gamers
content:
Believe the hype!!! The Wii is a very fun, highly entertaining console that will keep you, your kids, you parents, your grandparents, the neighbors, and maybe your pets (just kissing) laughing and playing for hours.  Even with just Wii Sports, I have personally had tons of fun playing with friend seriously, and watching people make fools of themselves for fun.  Overall, its really never a dull moment with the Wii around.

However, this is not a console you want to buy if you are a hardcore gamer expecting to play hardcore games.  Honestly, I have a Wii to play with friends that aren't really into other games.  For instance, my girlfriend only played PS2 games with me about once a month, just because she was okay with them.  However, she is very into the Wii and will play for hours because she feels its simple and fun.  Me on the other hand, I play Wii, but I have another console for the "real" games...the Metal Gears, Final Fantasys, GTAs, etc.  So, if you or the recipient is into certain types of games, you may not want to get a Wii and look to PS3 or 360 as your primary console.  But, I will say the Wii makes a solid back-up console strictly for simple and fun gaming.

Overall, Wii offers a great experience for the casual gamer and their friends, but offers little to the true hardcore gamer.

author: Trader John
title: Way too much fun
content: Waited in line to get this for my kids when it came out. We have just brought the Wii FIT as well.  This is just adding to the Choir. WII is fun. I am 47 years old and playing WII Sports, WII Fit, WII SuperBrawls with my 10 ten years old. I never thought this would happen. Nuff said. Now my problem would be keeping my kids from spending too much on WII.

author: Amazon Customer
title: great for kids when stuck inside!
content: I'm a stay at home mom with a 4, 2 and 9 month old and my oldest loves the Wii...it's still a little too difficult for my 2 year old but she tries.  I need to find some games that she may like and can play.  I use it for exercise and entertainment....love it!

author: Lori L.
title: the most awesomist game system made period end of sentence
content:
bought this for my 3 kids for their graduation, b-day gifts, my youngest katie has wanted this forever, the title is her words she asked me to write down. I bought it for $249.99 when Amazon had it at that price, was unable to find it anywhere for that low of a price & if I did it was already sold out. And I refused to pay more for it, I hate being retail hijacked, the important thing is they love it & it gets them up off the couch a bit I hope it was good incentive for this last year of hard work for them all.

tootles Lori

author: Aaron Merkel
title: Wii - Why?
content:
In my OPINION, this system was not needed, and was only produced because of the XBOX360 AND PS3 emerging.  The GameCube never got on its feet and then the Wii comes out.  It feels like a gimmick that falls flat with the Wii-motes and many peripherals.

However, I admit that some games are fun and done well and it does continue the Nintendo tradition.

Not long from now, another version of the Wii will be released that is backwards compatible, so don't bother buying this one at all anymore.

author: Holly
title: Will change how people think about video games
content:
I've had my Wii for 24 hours now, and my first impressions are that this system is going to revolutionize video gaming.  There are a few things that make the Wii worth buying more so than the XBox 360 or Playstation 3:

-Better value - $[...], comes with a game and a built-in "memory card"
-Better controllers - The Wii remote and nunchuck are a bit pricey, but they are by far the most comfortable, accurate, and intuitive controllers I've ever used.
-Potential for on-line services - The virtual console games are a bit pricey right now, but the potential for Wii channels to grow into something awesome is definitely there.  The Wii is the first console I know of that shipped with a built-in set of on-line services, several of which were active the day of release

Now, for the review:
The Wii hardware is small, sleek, stylish, and attractive.  It doesn't feel cheap or flimsy, but compact and durable.

The operating system of the Wii is intuitive, clean, and moves pretty quickly.  The wireless configuration is easy for anyone familiar with wireless networking.  I had it connected to my secured wireless router in just a few minutes.

I can't say enough about how cool the Wii remote is as a controller.  Not only is it innovative, and provides whole new ways to think about controlling video games like Wii Sports, it's also a much more comfortable controller to use for traditional games like Zelda.  Being able to sit with your shoulders spread and your arms at your sides is a new freedom of movement that I never knew I needed while playing a video game.

Wii sports is also more fun than I expected.  Although the interface and games are simple, they are also entertaining.  The tennis and golf games borrow a bit of their look and feel from Mario Tennis and Mario Golf, both pretty solid "fun-sports" titles.  The bowling game is also particularly fun, especially when played with a friend.

Overall, I don't miss having the enhanced graphics of the PS3 or XBox 360 even a little bit.  The games I've played are fun and engaging, the new controller is going to change the world, and the on-line "Wii Channels" show a lot of promise.

I'm really happy I bought this system, and if Nintendo keeps delivering at this level of quality, I don't think I'm going to need any other game systems any time soon.

~Chris

author: LLL Team
title: Got me off my [...]
content: I really enjoy it and I have been getting more coordinated as well.  A video game that does something other than eat my waking hours!  AWESOME.

author: MariaSmiles
title: w/Netflix, wii LOOOVE our Wii even more!!
content:
Wanna have even more FUN with loved ones? Wanna spend more time with someone, but can't get past awkward conversations? Wanna stream movies and TV shows to your TV, as you like? Turn on the wii, baby (& get Netflix)! From canoeing with family members, to swordfighting with friends, to cow-racing with acquaintances, to watching old episodes of Fraggle Rock, wii will have you laughing, rowing, slashing, lassoing (a la Indy!), and yes, now watching for as long as you can stand it! We've had our wii about six months, and it just got better! We just started our Netflix subscription a few weeks ago, and we love that too! With a Netflix subscription that includes the ability to stream, if you've got an internet connection to your house, you can watch any one of TONS of movies and TV shows (stuff you can't get on OnDemand!) My beau was especially excited about the 21 Jump Street Episodes :) Be prepared to spend more than just the purchase price for the wii - there are lots of fun extras that you kinda need, extra wii-motes and nun-chucks, in addition to the games (tip: always read the reviews on the games, I've bought a doozey or two, & if i had read the reviews here on amazon, I would have saved my $$ for a better game). But, if you have kids or you are even just a couple who goes out a lot, the wii (& now, netflix) may save you some money in the end, and you'll spend more time together, doing fun stuff. And after all, isn't that what life's all about?

Thanks to wii and netflix, we eat at home more (saves money, gas, & calories); watch fewer commercials (they're bad for the psyche AND the wallet!); are more active with our entertainment; spend more time with family & friends; spend less time aimlessly channel-surfing; enjoy more varieties of entertainment, like documentaries, old TV shows, and musician stuff; are more conservative with spending $7-15 per person to see a movie in the theatres (that we hopefully will enjoy!); and actually look forward to spending time at home (after all, we ARE paying for it, whether we're here or not!)

Gotta go, we've got a few movies in our queue, just waiting for our undivided attention!

PS - I rely on reviews here at Amazon to help me make informed buying choices. I hope this review has helped you in the same manner. If you voted this as helpful, I Thank You!

author: Florentina

content:

See you!!

title: Check the cord.
content: Beware buying used. I was gifted a used one from amazon by my brother. Within 6 months it stopped working. It's suspected to be the actual cord that has the issue. Great system , bad cords.

author: Praise

content: The wii broke down after one use.

author: K.K.

content: I had read a review when purchasing about what was included with the wii. They said that the nunchuck was not included just a controller. I just recieved the console today from Amazon and there is a nunchuck included.

author: K. A. Baird
title: Lots of fun, but be careful
content: The Wii is as much fun as everyone says it is.  Middle-agers need to be cautious: Batting imaginary balls, or swinging virtual clubs still taxes your body.  If you havn't been physically active lately, go slowly.

author: TonyL
title: good value/service
content: my wii's cd drive failed...this replacement works perfectly and was very well packaged when it arrived

author: J. Howard
title: Note from a Parent
content: If you have a kid who sits in front of the computer or with videogames all the time, and you wish he/she would get some exercise, the Wii is an easy answer.  To play the sports games that come with the Wii, my child has been performing all the physical moves required for batting, serving, putting, bowling, etc., until he was too tired to move.  I *like* the Wii!

author: Nils Valentin
title: Best family focused game console. Period !
content:
Below I describe what lead me to the decision to decide for the Wii.
Living in Tokyo, you should now that space is very precious. So is your freetime after work (in general after 8-10 PM  or on the weekends). I live with my wive, a 3 year old daughter the 70+ year old mother in law, etc... So that already gives you a good background on what facts I had to make a decision on. 3 generations in one household, so how did the Wii hold up against it ? You are about to find out...

During this summer I was slowly collecting ideas for the next generation game console.

The choice to make was basically either

- an Xbox 360
- the Wii or
- the PSP 3

I wanted something that doesnt cost an arm and a leg and doesnt get so warm that I can heat the room with it. I wanted something that the whole family can enjoy together and if possible with some sort of "activity".

So I went to Akihabara (Electric Town) in central Tokyo  where all the good customer and game maniacs go queueing from the last night in front of the shop for the newest game ;-)

The Xbox was supposed to have the widest choice of games (at least outside of Japan), is not s expensive as the PSP3 but I remember from some time back that there was a heating issue with the first version, which didnt make me feel so comfortable.

The PSP3 has a superb graphic and is probably state of the art but somehow gave me the impression that mostly hardcore game-maniacs would use it on their 50 inch flat screen monitor or with a projector. Playing it on such a big screen is great but can make you real exhausted if you look at it for 2+ hours. Eventually virtual world and real world change their meaning. Playing it on a small screen wouldnt really justify the extra cost.

The Wii seemed to be the kind of console which doesnt take up half the room and heating it all up and spend a fortune on power consumption, so that was nice to see.
Wii also comes with games and accessorie which my 3 year old daughter can enjoy at least watching, while PSP3 and Xbox 360 have a strong focus towards violence intensive action games which I wouldnt want her to enjoy at least for now.

I also wanted to spend some quality time with my family again doing some fun games.
A friend of mine already had a Wii and was very enthusiastic about the way the "Wiimote" (The remote of Wii) is working. He enjoyed the simple fact that for many games you actually have to move your body.

So for me it became very quickly clear that the Wii is the best choice for us.
Game maniacs or hardcore action game lovers will want to choose the PSP3, or (if you dont have so much money) the Xbox360.

As I found it hard at the beginning to quickly find sometimes which kind of category / age / target users a game is focused towards I have created my own game lists here on Amazon on which I will also list up games that are not yet available outside of Japan.

Hopefully some readers will find it useful.

author: Living Life Now
title: Fun for the whole family!
content: Can't say enough about Wii!  Lots of fun for the whole family.  Has worked exactly as marketed - would definately recommend this for endless entertainment!

author: L. Sims
title: Five Stars
content: Great price

author: Julian Pope
title: A Revolution in Motion Gaming
content:
When the Nintendo Wii first came out, it was so popular that for the first few months you would be hard pressed to find a single one on any store shelf anywhere. As of January 2014 over 100 million units have been sold worldwide. That's almost 1 Wii per every 3 people in the US. Why was the Wii so popular? The answer is simple. The Wii appeals to everyone. Most of all, the Wii appeals to families. Their entire marketing scheme was based around the fact that the Wii is fun for the whole family and easy to use by all. Some of the ads even had grandma's playing the game console!

The biggest negative point, and my only con, of this console was that it was being released in the HD era but not in HD, right before the PlayStation 3 and Xbox 360, both of which ran games in HD while the PS3 even had a Blu-ray drive. Therefore, the consoles resolution and frame rate would not be able to exceed 480p and 60 fps and it plays neither Blu-Rays nor DVDs but does offer video streaming services such as Netflix. Perhaps the Wii's best and most appealing feature is it's motion sensing technology. Being able to use the Wii remote as a baseball bat or tennis racket gives you a feeling that you are actually IN the game, no other console offered anything like this at the time. Nintendo's evolution from the standard candy bar style controller from the NES and SNES days to the Nintendo 64 and Gamecube controllers took a step back to the simpler build and it worked perfectly. This design allows games to be played on the Wii remote by pointing the remote at the screen, or simply turning it sideways. There is also several accessories that can be used in conjunction with the Wii remote such as the nunchuck, which has a separate analog stick and can be held in one hand while the remote is held in the other, and even a Classic Controller, which much resembles that of the Super Nintendo.

The console is quite easy to set up, the sound the Wii produces is decent but it is certainly feels like it is held back by it's lack of High-definition support. The user interface is incredibly easy to use, all you do is point and click, similar to using a computer and mouse.

The Wii offered lots of Nintendo's great, classic gaming characters in fun games but it felt like something was missing. It wasn't until the Wii U was released that it became apparent that what was missing was the upgrade in resolution. The best thing about the original Wii by far was that it opened the door for family gaming, easily allowing anyone to pick up a remote and join in on a game.

author: Shannon OHare
title: Not game-cube compatible...
content: We had to replace our wii because it crashed during an electrical storm. The only downside was I thought this was going to be game-cube compatible, it's not....even though the serial numbers I found online said it should be. It's okay, we only had one game-cube game we liked to play and can live with out it.

author: J. mendoza
title: definetly great
content:
this is the best gaming system out there game play wise, the graphics may not be all "hyped" up as the 360 or the PS3 but at least I don't have to play a huge amount of money for a glitchy system I would suggest this system for anyone and everyone out there I enjoy mine throughly and I have played the PS3 and the 360 I didn't like the PS3 at all, and the 360 was ok but this Wii is the cheapest, most fun and coolest of the three, sleek design, fun games, great for all ages

I love my Wii so I say get one when you can but make sure you get one online or in a store for 249.99 not some suped up price plus if you buy it from another comsumer you don't get all the benefits of replacement so pay attention and get a wii when you can so you can all have fun during the holidays, like me

author: Debi
title: Simply The Best
content: This game is just as advertised.  Fun for all ages.  It is a keeper.  Easy to hook up, easy to understand how everything works, and easy to play.  Although is a little painful the day AFTER you play if you are a bit out of shape!

author: S. K. RICHARDS
title: It's a Wii
content: It's just OK for me, but the wife and kids love it.  Lots of fun, exercise and entertainment.  It's hooked up to the big screen and WiFi so they also watch movies and shows with NetFlix on it.

author: Amazon Jeff
title: Wii sells millions ... millions BORED!
content:
Ahhh, the Wii.

When it was before it's time I drooled like a fanboy at the notion, watching the previews and imagining the possibilities.

When it came out I loved me some WiiSports, and fell in love with the Mii channel. I even made a web site about the Wii...

Now here I am a year later and I've barely touched it. Sure, Mario Galaxy is fun, and to some degree WiiSports hasn't lost it's charm... and Metroid, oh, wonderful and beautiful Metroid... but alas, this system is collecting dust. It simply doesn't have any of the games the Xbox 360 has been graced with, and it doesn't quite handle Blu Ray movies as well as my PS3.

Smash Bros. may get some juice into it's circuit boards for a few weeks, and Mario Kart is coming in "Early 08 - I mean April - I mean Early 09 - I mean..." and that will surely rock.

But is it enough?

The Wii seems to present a limitless landscape of possibilities for games, but unfortunately, Nintendo doesn't know what the internet is and third-parties don't want to waste time with motion controls or big budget games.

The result? It's like handicap children in a playground. It's not fair. It's not fun. It almost makes you feel kind of sad.

Verdict? The Wii has nothing going for it. Let the next snaggle-toothed, hype-train-riding, Coca-Cola drinking sell-out buy it instead. It's a better fashion accessory than it is a gaming console.

author: Kristy Sherrod
title: Awesome!!!!
content:
I waited in line at Wal-Mart for 8 hours Saturday to get a Wii & Twilight Princess and it was well worth it!  I was very impressed with the realistic play of the WiiSports games.  The tennis is great!  So much fun!  I didn't even get to Zelda until the next day after buying it b/c I was enjoying the sports games so much.  It was a lot of fun to play and great exercise too.

Twilight Princess is great too.  I'm just waiting on my player's guide to come in!  Let you know more later on that one!

author: Mark Sturman
title: Wii
content: The Wii is great! It's about time family was put into all this video gameing. It gets people up off their butts to physically play games. It's wonderful. Love it!

author: Emmor E. Boslet

the exercise that he gets with the tennis, bowling, & the other games.
He plans to add Wii Fit as well as hunting games as he is an advid hunter.
I was glad to get him something he enjoys & keeps him healthy.
Amazon was great to work with & the sender had the game to my door in record time without me paying extra.
I will continue to shop with Amazon.

author: Bugg

author: Samuel A. Shinn

author: Scott Richbourg

author: Patricia

content: My son and I love the Wii. Really love that its game cube compatible and that we can watch netflix on it. It was kind of tricky to get hooked up to the internet, but we figured it out.

author: Quickpix
title: Addictive
content: I was at first hesitant in purchasing the WII since I had recently purchased a PS3, but my wife wanted to get one.  I really enjoy my PS3, but the WII is on a different level.  The interaction portion makes it addictive.  Now it's not so hard to convince my wife to play video games, where with the PS3 it's out of the question.  I also like the design of the unit being extremely small and portable with wireless connection features.

author: K Brooks
title: Five Stars
content: Totally satisfied!

author: A. LeBrun
title: Love it
content: I love this.  It brings my family together.  My 3 year old enjoys it as much as anybody else does and she is pretty good at it. It will make you realize just how out of shape you are though.  All in all, best investment I have ever made.  TWO THUMBS UP!!!!!!!

author: Sports Nut
title: Wii Fun
content: Wii is an awesome gaming system.  What is in the box is enough to get started.  The sports games are very entertaining.  Anyone can play.  No gaming skills required.  My mother has been playing non-stop every day since Christmas.  Gets you up out of your chair and moving.  I hadn't played video games consistently since the Atari 2600.  This is a great system for adults and children.  The more people, the more fun.

author: Kindle Customer
title: Five Stars
content: This was a gift and it was a big hit!

author: Chris
title: Don't waste your money, battery life on the remotes is HORRIBLE!!!
content: Battery life is GARBAGE on the remotes!!!!! The hand is hard to find on the screen a lot of times. I hate playing the Wii because every 2 minutes it says "connection interrupted." Love the games when it works, but it was a waste of money.

author: Sarah Gray
title: bought used, great
content: So nice to buy this used, my kids broke our first wii. Didn't want to buy another new one and was very happy with this one. It came with games already on it which my kids loved. So overall, we are very happy with our purchase.

author: S0DA POPINSKI
title: The Wii is not for hardcore gamers at all.
content:
Games:

I would only recommend the Wii to people with young children (13 and under) or people that want a game system just for fun when they have company. The Wii lacks games for hardcore gamers. It doesn't get the majority of multiplatform games that the 360 and PS3 do because of its weak hardware. Most 3rd party titles are a joke. The 1st party games are fun, but the same that we've seen for years. Aside from Super Mario Galaxy, its the same old Mario Party, Zelda, Metroid Prime, Mario Kart, etc that have been around for years. It's like a Gamecube with motion controlls. I did love Mario Galaxy, one of the best games so far this gen. Other then that though, pickins are slim. With games like Assassin's Creed, Bioshock, Oblvion, Fallout, Soul Calilber, Street Fighter, Burnout Paradise, Modern Warfare, and so many more that are on PS3 or 360, the choice is clear. Also keep in mind 360 and PS3 both have awesome exclusives of their own. The one saving grace for the Wii is it does have access to download (for way too much money) old school games.

Hardware:

The hardware is very weak, almost last gen. It does have full backwards compatiblity for the gamecube which is nice. The console itself seems well built. No red rings of death here. Lack a lot of memory, but does have SD expandable memory. Motion Control.

Online:

Online play is a joke. Friend codes, no voice, etc.

author: Renoptimus
title: Fun for everybody
content: I've had my wii for about 3 weeks, and so far it has exceeded my expectations. Don't hesitate to get one since they are hard to find. I have Animal crossing City Folk and Resident Evil 4 wii edition, both of which are great games. Wiiconnect 24 is a good feature, wii sports is actually fun, and there's just so much to do. I've downloaded punch-out from the virtual console and it only took seconds. My only issue is the lack of HD graphics, but trust me you will have a lot of fun.

author: Jimmy Gutierrez
title: Five Stars
content: the wii worked just like it should.

author: Jarucia Jaycox
title: Who Can't Love IT?
content:
I'm sure some of you out there are Wii haters, and that's cool.  But for the rest of us average-joe mostly non-gamers this is a totally fun system.

It's easy to enjoy all the standard games with only a small level of gaming ability.  Just be ready with Tiger Balm when you're done to address the strain in your shoulder joints.  I seriously thought about icing mine after a strenuous game of tennis.

Also, this system travels beautifully.  Pack it up and take it to the next party you go too.

I know some folks may think lowly of the Wii as it isn't as hardcore of a system (owing to its games) as the other seriously hardcore gaming systems out there, but who died and decided that a video game systems couldn't simply be mindless and fun?  Geeze, isn't that how video games started out anyways?

Highly recommend this for couples, families, older folk, tennis players, those who dream of touring withe PBA or PGA and anyone else in between.

author: Amazon Customer
title: Doesnt work
content: The one I bought didnt even power on.

author: James Owens
title: Four Stars
content: Works fine

author: K. Loh
title: Simply awesome
content: Whether it's yourself or between a group of friends, Wii brings you tons of fun.  With the wireless control in hand and having to go through all the motions, not only is it fun but it's a great workout.  You'll have to pick the right game for you, but once you narrowed down your choice, you'll no doubt have a good time with a Wii.  Not to mention, if you're having a big bbq party or a drinking party (especially), you'll find the Wii capable of providing you with endless options to party!  I couldn't wait and bought it was soon as it came out.

author: Twana N. Johnson
title: Five Stars
content: Fun

author: Adam
