content: Worked for about 3 months

author: Liza Bochene
title: love it!
content:
love it!!!

 I am 34 years old , I just wanted to play  Mario Brothers, (old school) , but  I  found  out  I can  do sports, dance,  fish..... it is very nice!!!! I love it, even my  husband  who doesn't like to play  any video games, is playing it!!!

author: Robert Cross
title: Wii
content: The Wii is so much fun.  The adults in the family love it as much as the kids.  The sport pack is great.  It has all of the sports you would want to play.  Baseball, tennis, golf, bowling, boxing.  They are all so much fun to play.  You can even make a mini Wii that looks like you.  I would recommend the Wii to everyone.

author: GarionOrb
title: Nice little anemic console.
content:
The Wii is undoubtedly a great little console, however, it may not be for everyone.  The controls are top-notch, however.  The games are generally fun, simple and family-friendly.  True to Nintendo's vision of the system, anyone is able to just pick it up and play.  The Virtual Console has a plethora of great classic games from almost every past console (NES, SNES, Genesis, Master System, NEO-GEO, Turbografx-16, MSX), plus it's fully backwards compatible with GameCube discs and also includes its own WiiWare service for original downloadable games.  This makes its game library enormous.

The cons:  It's small, humble appearance is due to the lack of horsepower under that hood.  Nintendo has stripped the console of almost every aspect that defines the current generation of gaming.  There is no HD output, which is curious since more and more people are purchasing HDTV's.  The display looks awful on an LCD screen.  The graphics are great for cartoony games, but it cannot compete with current hardcore games as it's about on-par with the prior GameCube and PlayStation 2.  Most disturbing is the severe lack of storage memory.  At 256 MB, it's simply NOT enough if you download several games or channels and also have lots of game save data.  Wii has an optional SD memory card slot, but while you can store games and files there, the Wii cannot play directly off of it, which means you have to manually move files back and forth to be able to use them.  Game-wise, all your favorite Nintendo franchises make their Wii appearance (Mario, Zelda, Metroid), but there's a horrible lack of good 3rd party games.  In fact, the Wii game library is overrun with 3rd party shovelware that's barely worth $10.  This will be a serious issue if Nintendo wants to maintain their position in the #1 spot.

Wii is a good system, but if you're looking for true next-gen gaming, better go with a PlayStation 3 or Xbox 360.

author: AnotherHiggins
title: Console Excels In Social Settings
content:
There's a reason this is such a hot item.

When you feel the need to "blow stuff up", a console from Xbox or Playstation might be a good fit. But there are a couple of things that those consoles don't do well. And Wii picks up that slack very nicely indeed.

1)
Getting your parents and grandparents involved. The first time I had my parents over after I got the Wii, I put in the sports disc (that comes in this package) and started up tennis. My mom asked, "How do I serve". I asked how she would serve if she were really playing tennis (something which she hasn't done in many years due to heart problems). She made the motion and, VOILA!, her avatar served the ball.

My dad, who I don't think has played a video game with me since we got Pong when I was a kid, kicked my butt in Bowling the first time he played.

What I'm saying is the controllers really are very intuitive even for "non-gamers" and the games are fun for all ages.

2)
Party settings. I love Halo and other games like that, but it isn't much fun to watch other people play, especially for non-gamers.

On the other hand, with great party games like Rayman Raving Rabbids 2, the Wii becomes almost as much fun to watch others play as it is to play yourself. That's because, when done right, people stand up and make fools of themselves while competing against other guests.

---
One word of caution, though: Really do strap on those wiimotes. Sweaty palms could really ruin your day if you throw a wiimote through your TV. (This has never happened to me, but we always strap up.)

author: Kenneth Brosky
title: Missing just one thing ...
content:
After having played games like Warioware and Sonic and just about everything else already on the Wii, I went ahead and purchased one and haven't been disappointed thus far. The first game I bought was Legend of Zelda, and I'm still playing it after 20+ hours of gameplay. In addition, I've made a point of taking advantage of all the games that Nintendo sells through its online service for download. Yes, you heard it right: Nintendo, Genesis, SNES, N64 and now even Neo-Geo ... all of these games can be downloaded to the Wii and played (price varies, of course). For those of us who grew up with video games, it's an amazing chance to replay old favorites and pick up ones we never had a chance to play.

As for the Wii games, the style and content vary wildly. Just about anyone can find something they like, and the innovative motion controls can be put to great use (and sometimes not-so-great use, so it's a good idea to check the reviews before buying a game). More new games are coming out now, and some of the ports from previous systems--especially PS2--are still fun to play if you haven't had a chance to pick them up previously. The graphics will never be as good as those on the Xbox360 or PS3, but that's not a huge hang-up for most.

The only thing this system is missing now is a hardcore game. Xbox 260 has Halo 3 and Bioshock, and PS3 has Resistance. Wii came close with Metroid, but it's just not enough. I see a lot of opportunity with Wii for gritty first-person shooters, strategy games like Rome: Total War or even Command and Conquer, and other games like Star Wars Battlefront. Once Wii begins to take advantage of these areas, then it will have everything.

author: C. Martin
title: Great for the whole family
content:
What can I say, it is everything I expected. There are plenty of things to do without even owning a game(if you have WiFi).  And the games are a blast.  With Wii sports, my mother, father, and girlfriend(three people who haven't touched a game console since the original Nintendo) all get together to play bowling.

The only problem I can see is that after a couple hours of playing games like Monkeyball and Elibits, my right wrist that holds the Wiimote really starts to hurt.  I wouldn't be surprised to see Wii carpal tunnel for alot of heavy gamers in a couple of years.  You must take a break or you will be hurting the next day.

Other than that it is a great price, great system and amazing innovation.

author: whatever
title: Two Stars
content: Worked for one day. Now disc is stuck and won't eject.

author: KristenTag
title: Great for kids
content: This is great for younger kids.  My kids put in many hours on this system; however, as they got older, they wanted to switch to more advanced games on the xbox.  I'd say this is great for kids 10 and under.

author: don adkins
title: Good system
content:
System arrive without any problems, good working condition.

As far as the console performance and quality, i'd say its not worth buying now that the Wii U is out. Just get that, you wont regret that.

If you cant spare the money for the Wii U, then its a great buy. Theres not awhole lot of games for the system however, most are kid friendly.  The only reason I got the Wii was for Mario and Zelda.

author: JJs2cents
title: So good, we have two - one for each!
content: We bought a Wii for one of the kids last year. When the other one went off to college and took the Wii for a semester, the kids decided to trade systems at break. The older one liked it so well, he kept it at college for the year. So, this year we bought another system for the younger one. The Wii gets you up off the couch and moving! No more couch potatoes video-gamers...but, if you have someone with limited mobility who wants to play, they can have just as much fun. And theres something for everyone with varying ability levels. You dont have to be good to have fun :)

author: Brian J. Turner
title: Wii to xbox360 is apples to oranges
content:
if you are looking for a system to replace your first person shooting, marrowind playing xbox 360, the Wii is not for you. the Wii is not a traditional gaming system (as i am sure u already knew). if you are a hardcore gamer, and want to continue to do so, nintendo still hasnt made a system for you. nintendo usually gears their system to the younger gen of gamers. but with the wii, now any first time gamer can pick it up and play, so the older gen also.

how can i explain this better. the Wii is mario party to the extreme. every game on the wii, because of the controller, feels like a fun goofy game. the more i play it the more i feel it was built for mario tennis. this is the ultimate get your friends togther. girls and guys. and goof off over a few drinks.

this system succeeded in every way possible at accomplishing what it was meant to do. which is be a fun, easy to use, addictive system. but it is not trying to, nor can it ever, replace an xbox 360 for a hard core gamer. once again.. they are apples and oranges.

... but to be honest... at risk of negating everything i just said... if i had to pick.. i would go with the Wii

author: Shaun E. Flynn
title: Great product wish the wii u was this good
content: Still playing this thing. Great product wish the wii u was this good.

author: My2centsworth
title: THIS SYSTEM IS CRAZILY INSANELY FUN!!!
content: I don't own one yet, but I played one at a GameStop [playing ExciteTruck] and I was so bad because it is a completely new deal, but it is one of the best [if not the best] video game[s] [systems] I have ever played!

author: Romina
title: Exactly what I needed
content: Exactly as I expected. No wires, low price and works well!!

author: Sanjeev K. Mallick
title: the wii rules!
content: When I got the Wii for our family, we absolutly loved it.  This is one of the most fun family gaming system that I've played.  Every Friday we all get together and play with each other.  It is very fun and can get your heart pumping.  I recommend this for any family.  Wii Sports is very fun, happy it comes for free with the wii.  The other games are fun also.

author: Li
title: Wiiiiiiii, i love it
content: best console i have ever had, enough said! if anything, the wii really do takes gaming to another level, no more sitting on my butt for n (unknown number of) hours. nintendo does the thing right once again. you cant get anymore real if slaying of a monster involves real movement such as a swing, stab, and hack (instead of pushing buttons). i hope in the future i can expect more realistic gaming from them.

author: Moni
title: Poor Condition
content: I returned due to poor condition upon arrival.

author: Amazon Customer
title: Very disappointed
content: I’m very disappointed my wii “sports” didn't come in the original packaging there weren’t any instructions and It didn’t come with the wii sports game as it states in the description. I bought this for my sons 4th birthday because he would have loved all the sports games. My son was disappointed in his gift because I didn’t purchase any games to go with it because it was supposed to be included. I attached a picture the packaging that it came 😥

author: C. Ayala
title: If you have kids you better buy this product.
content: This console it's great for kids and for the old. It promotes active playing not just sitting and present buttons. I have nephews who play the wii sports game and they actually sweat playing it, specially the boxing games.  It's also fun to  play against older people. I say buy it.

author: Jolene L. Strauss
title: absolutely love it
content: We love our new wii. Set it up in less then 10 minutes and we were bowling. Any age group would love the wii. We have friends that are in there 50's and they had a blast playing the wii sports that came with it.

author: Carlos
title: Five Stars
content: Arrived in awesome condition. Could hardly tell it was pre owned!

author: Gerardo. Hernandez
title: Five Stars
content: works great, was easy to mod

author: alejandro
title: Five Stars
content: Extremely satisfied got it just how it was described

author: Jake
title: all worked great and have had no issues
content: CONSOLE ONLY, NO CABLES. Make sure to read the description, I ordered cables separately and ordered 3 of these to soft mod, all worked great and have had no issues. Look and work like new.

author: Tracy Webb
title: Mom's Wii
content: I cannot say enough about this product. I ordered it for my Mom for Christmas (yes, my Mom), and even though I payed double the price I would have in the store, I'd pay quadruple to see the look on her face again when she saw it on Christmas. I'd given up hope of finding her one. Thank you so much! The product arrived quickly and in excellent condition. I'll certainly do business with you again.

author: manuel
title: Still Kicking
content: I bought this console on,  December 23, 2008, believe it or not. The Wii is still working and doing its job. Ive had so much fun playing it for the past 11 year, with, friends and family. I'm so glad I bought this back when I did its been fun owning it for this long.

author: Eric Heath
title: Good for the whole family
content: I have a PS2 that I love to play, but have very little time to since it takes away from my being able to spend time with my wife and 3 yr old son.  With the wii, they enjoy playing the games as well and it allows our whole family to have fun together.  I recomend this to anyone who wants a gaming system that the whole family can enjoy.

author: Richard Montes
title: BEST INVERSION
content: I feel i spent my money properly. This is an amazing product

author: eternalcube
title: Wii is the new-generation console
content:
As expected from Nintendo, the Wii offers fun for everyone and more!
If you are a casual or hardcore gamer, the Wii is for you. The wiimote enhanced the gaming experience and games like first-person shooters became more easier to play. If you want awesome games, buy Super Mario Galaxy, Metroid Prime Corruption, Paper Mario, Wario Ware, Zack & Wiki, Fire Emblem and the upcoming Smash Bros. Brawl.

author: Jeff Patton
title: Product came as ordered the second time around, the ...
content: Product came as ordered the second time around, the first one had an issue and was quickly resolved. My kids have been playing with it regularly since and no issues whatsoever.

author: Amazon Customer
title: One Star
content: This didn't work well for us for more than one player.

author: K. Schmidt
title: New, Different, and Entertaining
content:
If you haven't had a chance to try the new Nintendo Wii, find a friend that has one or check it out at Walmart or something, because even though it might seem silly to wave around the remote and make a fool of yourself, I would guess you would be surprised how original and fun the Wii is to use.

The problem with this console right now is that it is very hard to get your hands on unless you pay a fair amount more money and buy it from a private seller, and there aren't many games out for the system yet. Unless your really excited about a new game that HAS been released (like I was), I might suggest waiting for the hype to die down a bit and some new games to come out, and then you may be able to get one for a better price. It's definately worth checking out, though.

author: CBlair
title: fun and games
content: we bought a wii for my 12 year old granddaughter and we set it up in our game room and we all liked it so much that we decided to keep it at our house and when someone finds another one we will let her set it up at her house. all of this was with her permission.

author: Amazon Customer
title: Excellent experience
content: Got here safe and sound, works great. My family loves it.

author: Mike S.
title: family oriented, for the casual gamer
content: A family gaming system that is O.K. With all the hype I was expecting more. Most games are geared towards little kids, which was to be expected. Why no HD? Many people that rate it 5 stars say "It's the game play not graphics" I agree to a point, but in this day and age there is no excuse not to have HD and to me it only enhances the game play experience. And if it's game play the're worried about then I'm sorry to say that I have found few games I consider fun.  The sports games are fun but the redundent motion gets old quick. The bowling is fun when having a party! For ages 4-9 and 50+. My wife likes it but I will stick with my 360.

author: M. Fitzsimmons
title: Grandparents stay connected
content: Hey, my kids and grandchildren are the most important people in my life.  The Wii is a great way to connect with them and have fun doing it.  When do you last remember actively playing with your Son or Daughter or Grandchild?  This great game helps break down the barriers of age...it's something you can all share, laugh and enjoy doing.  It becomes clear on the first try that this is not your standard Video Game but a way to stay active just like outdoors activities of Tennis, Golf and Baseball or indoor sports like Bowling or Boxing.  Be careful, you will work up a sweat but better still, you'll create memories your Children and Grandchildren will remember and cherish.  It's a great product!

author: Charles Harris
title: wii
content: Ordered this product and received it very quickly, was pleased, the only thing wrong was the coord which the seller offered to replace, got the new cord and its working perfectly!

author: k9doc1
title: WII enhances your family activity levels
content: I was initially reluctant in getting another game system for our children...but I was proven wrong.  Now, I end up playing more than our kids...of course my family and I also spend quality time competing with eachother.  Because the games are so interactive and physical, I feel like as if I actually worked out...  Great game system for everyone in the family...I guess may be not for a person with heart condition...

author: The Stinker
title: Couldn't wait
content: With all the family coming  we decided to go ahead and open the new Wii before Christmas. This thing is an instant hit. Great source of entertainment from young to er...old (Im 58) If you have an ounce of competitive blood in you, you will get into tennis, duck hunting, bowling, basketball, pool and other endless varieties of games.

author: DSteal
title: Works great!
content: Everything works and it was packaged very well!  It comes with all the cords you need too!  My kids are so happy to be able to play their Wii games again.

author: Jane Robichaud
title: great fun!!
content:
we have the best time playing with our Wii game , we can spend hours playing different games at such an affordable price !! it's great spending quality time with family members ,we look forward to purchasing more family games throughout the comming year ,,

sincerly Jane

author: Lee
title: GREAT PRODUCT AND PRICE
content: I could not pass up this GREAT deal just $140 or so after i purchased my original Wii for $350+

author: Noraima
title: Purchase as a gift
content: I bought this for someone as a gift and they enjoyed it, don't know know if they use everyday. It was a good buy !

author: Not My Name
title: Like Everything, Give it Time
content:
I had to wait a very long time for my Wii and when i finally did it, i had been waiting outside Target for 6 hours. Thats only after waiting outside other various stores for weeks on end. Those of you who have rated the Wii poorly (collecting dust) and what have you...why aren't there more for sale in used then?
With that said...some of it's true. Games: blah. When it first came out i couldn't find anything i really really enjoyed. Excite Truck, Need for Speed and of course Zelda.
NOW though...upcoming releases like resident evil chronicals where you play like you're in an arcade, only to be followed up by the release or the wii zapper. Guitar Hero III comming out for the Wii, tomb raider, mario galaxy, boxing...there are just so many being released in the next few months.
I think the wii is very versitle and while at first the wii wasn't really for heavy gamers because the graphics aren't PS3 style (but compare them to the atari and what do you have? great graphics) but now they have made up for the graphics (which i think are perfectly acceptable, if i wanted perfect graphics i'd just watch a movie in high-def) by producing games for the avid gamer and games for the family (mario kart is comming out soon).
All in all it's been a long while coming where the wii could please a family of 7, while also pleasing the lonely heart who sits infront of his/her computer with a mt. dew and snacks thanking the lord for halo 3.

author: Timothy J. Heckman
title: Wii = Friends & Family = A Blast
content:
First things first.  I am a gamer.  My fiancé is not.  Getting her to play video games is darn near impossible.  Then we got the Wii.  For the first three weeks we played it every night.
Playing the Wii isn't just sitting there playing a video game.  It's interaction, both with the game and the people you're playing with.
If you haven't tried it, find a friend that has one and try it.  You'll be wanting one soon enough. This system will change the way games are played.

author: Denise Macaulay
title: Fun for the Rest of Us
content:
I am not a hardcore gamer. Although I have been playing video games since Pong, the Wii is the first game console I have owned. I love video games, but being a mom with three boys I don't have much time to play and when I do I like to do something that involves my family. But I was an arcade junkie in high school and college and I still enjoy blasting aliens and beating up bad guys.

However, the reason I never bought a console before because I didn't really see an advantage over PC gaming. Now, I love detailed graphics (which is why I preferred computer games for so many years) but to me that is not all that gaming is about. The PS3 and Xbox360 games look awesome, but when you get down to it, you are still just pressing buttons. And you can punch buttons on a PC just like the consoles. So for me there weren't enough differences between the PC and a game console to justify the extra cost of a dedicated game machine and the more expensive games. Then came the Wii.

Now for all of you that have been gaming for years--every day of your life, for several hours a day--I can see why you wouldn't like the Wii. All those years of training your thumbs to move little joysticks and perfecting rapid button pushing skills are mostly useless when you pick up a Wii remote. This is not the console for the hardcore gamer.

But for the rest of us, the Wii is the great equalizer.

I have tried to play video games with my boys in the past but it would take me most of the time I had to play, just to figure out how to get started. My boys were always very patient and helpful, but I'm sure that the only reason they weren't bored out of their minds was just because I was spending time with them. I doubt they got much fun from playing with me. (Well, other than the entertainment of watching mom's characters kill themselves 30 times in a row because I kept pushing the wrong buttons.) Now, we can actually have fun playing together. My boys have put in lots more gaming hours than I have, and the first couple of weeks we had the Wii they could beat me at just about everything. Now not only can I play, but I can sometimes obliterate them. Hee-hee.

I love the motion controls. It is not just a gimmick to me. It is much more natural and fun. Yes, playing Lego Star Wars on the PC is fun, but for a lifelong Star Wars fan like myself, getting to swing the Wii-mote around like a light saber in Lego Star Wars: The Complete Saga is just about worth the price of the system alone.

I am also very happy with Nintendo itself. After months of heavy use, our Wii developed a disc drive problem one week before Christmas. Now, you could say that this means it is a defective product. But I have had tons of computers and sometimes you just get a bad drive. This is why you have a warranty. Anyway, we had bought games and more Wii-motes and Nunchuks for the kids and it would really wreak our presents if the Wii wasn't there for Christmas. They explained they would do their best but there were no guarantees. To make a long story short, at absolutely no cost to me they shipped it back the repair shop, fixed it, and shipped it overnight so that it arrived on the morning of the 24th. Stuff like that makes me a lifelong fan.

The Wii is really great for wet, cold winter days when it is too miserable to go out and play. When people are sick and we can't go anywhere, we can still go bowling. (Unfortunately, the Wii controls are very realistic and I am just as bad bowling at the virtual bowling alley as I am at the real one.)  My whole family is having a ton of fun with this. We used to spend evenings sitting watching DVD together--now we play games together. Now, I've actually seen people complain about the fact that you can't just sit and play, but that's what I like about it the most.

We have a Tigger in our family who can't stay still for more than a few seconds at a time. Getting him to sit down and play a board game is next to impossible. We would have to call him back from across the house every time it was his turn, so having a family game night was pretty much out--until now. Now we can play Mario Party 8,Godzilla Unleashed, or whatever and he can have fun and bounce around all he wants. Fun without the stress.

I highly recommend the Wii. You get a whole lot of bang for your buck. For the less than the price of a PS3, I have bought the console plus 3 Wii Remote Controllers, 3 Wii Nunchuk Controllers, and had enough left over to buy several games. But more importantly, it has been a fun addition, beneficial addition to our family. The Wii definitely makes my lifetime list of Best Purchases I Have Ever Made.

author: Joni
title: Great but a little Pricey.
content:
The wii is great and it has a lot of good features but the games that you buy in stores can be a little pricey. I have had my wii for a little less than 6 months and I'm already bored with my games. But I have found some fun in the Wii Shopping Channel. You can buy old games and new games from $5-$15 which is great compared to the $30-$50 games in stores. Other than that the Wii itself is great with some interesting channels.

I hope this helps.
-The Daughter of.

author: Mike K.
title: Console Breakdown for the Casual Gamer
content:
***The ratings contained in this review are not my own personal ratings but are intended to best aid a beginner or novice in the gaming world***

I am what you may call a gamer aficionado. I have been around since the NES release and have played them all including back dating myself to the Atari 2600. This review is intended to clarify some points for the more casual gamer, and will cover this and last generation of consoles by maker.

Nintendo - The first in my list because this is the first you will recognize.

And we will start off with last generation, the Gamecube. Gamecube was intended for children. And let it be known that it didn't disappoint. Gamecube has released some very solid titles, including Metroid, Mario, Zelda, and Smash Brothers. I know there are going to be comments made about this, but remember, this is for the casual gamer and the casual gamer will enjoy and appreciate the quirkiness of Smash Bros. without noticing the minor flaws. So back to the review. The Gamecube has maintained solid four-player gaming and has re-released a few titles (Zelda: Ocarina of Time) that will make it well worth the purchase. Not to mention the Gameboy Advance interface (Especially for you Pokemon fans) and the price. The Gamecube is by far the cheapest "new" console on market.

But the Wii, in addition to being the cheapest new generation (I refuse to call them next-gen anymore) will also play all the old Gamecube games (A feat X-Box missed the mark on). And for those of you who knew that your parents grew up on NES or just really want to know what 16-bit gaming was all about, the Wii includes an internet feature which will allow you to download all the classics you missed out on (read as They will charge you to play classic Nintendo games). There is a one time fee involved, so don't fret too much (although it's a little high for someone also shelling out around $50 a game for other consoles as well). The Wii is fun and innovative, and if you want to feel more involved in the game, Nintendo nailed it. The new controllers are completely motion sensitive without losing the function of an analog stick. The button systems are intuitive although a little frustrating (i.e. you point the controller just off the screen when trying to aim). Nintendo did a great job growing up.

The Bad - Although the cheapest in the bunch it is also the most difficult to find. I got lucky and bought mine just when it was added online. You'll probably have to ask when a store gets shipments in and trail the truck in from the freeway. Also, although the Wii plays all old titles, you'll still have to purchase "old" controllers to play them. The online is fun as well. Mii's alone are worth it. BUT, the store will frequently freeze unless your wireless internet is set up just right. (There is a connection for wired internet, but what do you need that for if the Wii has a wireless modem built in?)

The verdict - All in all, you'll be incredibly happy with a Wii and for a Casual Gamer you may not need anything else. All things considered: 5 out of 5 for the casual gamer. The joy of playing this fun console, the price and Wii Sports which comes included with the console far out-weigh the inaccuracies and glitches held within the controller and the fact that this little thing only produces picture in regular definition, not High-Definition..

X-Box - Microsoft threw it down when they teamed up with Sega to create what they hoped would be (and may still become) the ultimate gaming console.

The original X-Box was created to be very much a devoted computer: devoted to gaming. There were even computer mod chips readily available to enhance your playing experience and the hard drive was upgradeable. Granted the casual gamer would need a friend to do the changes and probably wouldn't even know the difference (except for the interface) unless that same friend pointed it out. Now this is a new system put out by a "new" company, so there is no backwards compatibility (you can't play any old games). The controller is probably the most comfortable (in my opinion) and the games are mostly nice to look at. There are some moments (Halo) when you'll even find yourself standing still in the game to stare at the scenery. Being a new system make sure you at least get Version 2 (I had a V 1 that heated up very quickly, but I kept the V 1 controller for my own comfort... it's bigger, my hands are big... enough said). But when it came down to it, Microsoft's online play was probably the biggest achievement. For the first time, there was an online community that eased the ability of online console multiplayer. Of course I'm referring to X-Box Live. Which lives and strives in it's updated version.

X-Box Live is a must if you want the X-Box 360. How else can you boast about your achievements? Which brings me to "Gamerscore". On the X-Box 360, Microsoft introduced Gamerscore as a method of getting gamers addicted to playing. And it worked. I can't tell you how many times PacMan ate three of the powerpellets and died making it to the fourth. But about the 360. The console sends picture in High-Definition. That's 720p HD by the way, not the 1080p Sony and Blueray are pushing. What does that mean? That means better, more realistic picture. But not perfect or "super-real" which is a term that has been used to describe Gran-Tourismo HD for the PS3. It means seeing your car splash through puddles, seeing skin stretch with joints bending and muscles flexing. And speaking of HDTV, The 360 will play HDDVD's, but only with a $150 driver. Otherwise, you'll be limited to the same old 480p. The 360 has focused primarily on the First-Person-Shooters, it seems, gaining some ground in Role-Playing-Games. Which leads me to say, for the casual gamer, This console could become a little expensive. X-Box Live has built an arcade in which (once again) you pay a one-time fee to play old games (as well as some new ones) off your console. Also, unless you're going to spend $35 every three to five games for memory cards, you'll have to pay at least $100 for a hardrive. The 360 plays "most" of the old X-Box games, and they are working on updating their software continually to try to add more. Another annoyance is that every game you play will download an update for it's online play, achievements and sometimes even patch an in-game glitch. This I am classifying as an annoyance because it 1) takes up memory and 2) isn't a one-time deal. Some games will have three or four updates the first time you play. But I have nothing to complain about as far as the interface, playability, and mid- to high- level games for casual and hardcore gamers. Did I mention the computer sync which will allow you to operate your computer from your X-Box?

The Bad - Although X-Box 360 is nothing to scoff at (unless you are a die-hard PS fan that refusing to acknowledge the PS3 is/will be a failure) it may be a little daunting for the casual gamer who wants a quiet, quirky, fun platformer. There are a few out there, and they do seem to be increasing in number (what with now trying to compete with the Wii) but the 360 doesn't seem to have anything mainstream that isn't full of glitches. Thank you Sonic The Hedgehog. The casual gamer will find him/herself in the arcade more often than playing a real game. The console heats up (still) quickly which means (once again) make sure you get at least a Version 2, and even so you may want a cooling unit (NOT NYKON). The console sounds like a jet engine. And I don't exaggerate. There is not doubt about when it is on or off. Everything is expensive (Thank you Microsoft). Games are $55 or more, controllers are $40, memory is $35 a pop, even arcade games are no less than $6 and most run $12 or $18. Microsoft even went so far as to maximize profits by ceasing production of X-Box games to focus on the 360.

The Verdict - This console is my second choice for Casuals. The 360 is certainly more grown up and you'll be able to grow up faster on the 360 than on a Wii, but unless you know someone who you trust to recommend games to you, you'll end up getting difficult games and miss out on the fun. Don't worry, you'll get your chance to be pwned! But if you jump out to Gears of War online Versus Match too soon, you'll just get slaughterer and frustrated and crawl up with BeJeweled in the Arcade. After all is said and done, the 360 gets a 4 out of 5 for the casual gamer. Make a friend at your local game store - someone who won't try to sell you a $60 game because it's `pretty' - and go out and get your game on.

Playstation - since it was introduced, it was Sega's only competition, N64 was old and Gamecube didn't bring back the following they had hoped. After Sega CD, Sega Saturn and finally Sega Dreamcast (probably the most under valued console of gaming history) Sega threw in the towel and sided with Microsoft to aid with the X-Box. Playstation has been loyal to fans and works backwards compatibility all the way back to the PSone.

But we will ignore the PSone and skip straight to the PS2. The PS2 has focused, it seems, in RPG (Role-Playing-Games). Try saying "Final Fantasy sucks" in a crowded room* without invoking both applause and anger. *I don't actually recommend this, and I assume no responsibility for those that do try and get beat up.* These RPG's span from the quirky and fun to the Dark and Brooding. So there is no sense in talking about finding something you'll enjoy (as long as you like RPG's). There are plenty of platformers as well. Although the PS2 has probably the best selection for the casual gamer as well as more of the mainstream titles, it's controller is the most uncomfortable and possibly the least functional. There are four "triggers" that are not pressure sensitive. This makes racing very difficult. I went so far as to change the settings to make the throttle the second analog stick. The PS2 is a horse. You can play for hours without fatiguing the console. Of course, most of the games are meant to be played for hours at a time. There are wireless capabilities, but it requires buying separate wireless controllers (the wired controllers are only about 6' long) which will have you connect a receiver into the front of your console. Memory is fairly cheap, especially if you find a sale (which happens frequently) and you don't mind buying third party (Not Sony). Sony is a name drop and you should expect to pay the price for it. Playstation has also included online play, but it is through ISP's (casuals should have their friends set them up to begin with), not through a community.

You'll notice I'm speaking about the PS2 like I have the new-generations of the other companies even though there is a PS3. That's because the PS3 is NOT for casual gamers. PS3 ended up in a "anything you can do I can do better" kick and offered up specs that far surpassed any console that has preceeded. But they paid the price. Or rather, you'll pay the price. The console has a base price of $600. Although it is the only console to offer 1080p High Definition picture, it is very difficult to find good games because, 1) There aren't that many games - it is very difficult to program for the PS3 - and 2) The games that do exist never live up to the hype. Sony has simply made it too difficult to publish a "good" game (read a game free of MAJOR glitches) on their new console. Leave the PS3 for the Playstation devouts. It is NOT for the casual gamer. So I return to the PS2.

The Bad - The PS2 controllers are slightly uncomfortable. You may want to get third party controllers and accept the fact that you'll have to sit no further than six feet from the console. The triggers (although there are four of them) don't have enough play to be effectively pressure sensitive. The online play is through ISP, which can make it difficult for a casual to get involved (I recommend inviting a friend over to help you out). Because it is last-generation, it produces picture in regular definition. There are upgrade wires (component and S-video) to improve picture quality, but it's still not high-definition.

The Verdict - The PS2 gets a 4 out of 5 for casual gamers (the PS3 gets a 2 out of 5). There is nothing that can be said that I haven't already. The PS2 is a great console, but lacks a few creature comforts that in this day and age, a console needs. No surprise as it is last gen. This console is going to be the cheapest, seeing as it is older. But with several updated models (Slim, Silver) and the capability to play DVD's without a remote, it will fit your entertainment area nicely. Although this console received the same score as the 360, I feel the PS2 will rank 3rd simply because the price simply doesn't make up for it's age.

author: K. Ervin
title: Great family fun
content: We are a family of 4 with a 20 year old and a 16 year old.  This is one activity we all thoroughly enjoy doing together.  The sports games are by far our favorite.  The entire time we are up and playing we are continuously laughing at each other.  Definitely worth the money.

author: JPTurner
title: Using is believing.
content: The Nintendo Wii is a better mouse trap. It is fun for all ages to use. Its new controller has a built in pointer and gyroscope. You point and swing the remote and your actions are played out in real time on the screen. Simply amazing.  Our entire extended family played Wii Sports for over 3 hours on Christmas day - everyone from a Grandfather down to a 5 year old. There were smiles all around. Kudos to Nintendo for inventing such a great system, and for bringing it home with a game included for only $250. My kids all love it, yours will too !

author: Hendo
title: Not for Everyone
content: The Wii was interesting and got a lot of buzz when it first released, but it wasn't for hardcore gamers. It had it's time in the spotlight, but it seems like the gaming industry is moving back to the more typical route and focusing on quality games, rather than trying something new. Hopefully the Wii U will be able to blend the best of both worlds.

author: J. Bell
title: Playing this game is so much fun, you've got to have one
content: I am 50 years old and I have to tell you that this game is the best toy I have ever had.  I have so much fun with it by myself or with my husband.  I love hitting home runs, taking batting practice and playing tennis.  Not a big fan of boxing, but the training is fun and funny.  I get such a kick out of the little Wii figures because they don't really have arms and legs.  I play with the Wii game nearly every night while I am waiting for my husband to get home.  I am actually toning up and getting better at the games.  I hope to get a Wii Fit Plus when they are back in stock.

author: C. Lawal
title: Great
content: Love the wii

author: Nancy Drake
title: Wii Hardware
content: I bought this for my daughter as a gift. It came well packaged and in a timely manner. Of course it was a hit. She loves the Wii and anything associated with it so she can play with her friends. Would highly recommend this product!

author: Eternalodyssey
title: A truly AMAZING system!!! I am hooked!!!
content:
My wife and I won a drawing for the opportunity to purchase the console at our local BX and although she was a little bit skeptical about this system at first, she jumped on the opportunity to purchase this hot item on everyone's Christmas list. Besides, it was all I could talk about since Nintendo first code-named it the "Revolution" (which would have been a better name since the game play is so revolutionary compared to other systems). The system is extremely easy to setup and connect to the internet. The real simplicity however comes to the controls.

After a brief tutorial, the controller feels very natural and the innovative design truly allows you to feel like you are more in "control" of what your on-screen character is doing. My wife picked up on it right away as did I and now I don't know who is more addicted, her or I!!!

Upon first contact with the system you will notice how small and surprisingly heavy the system is. But after all, they packed a truly remarkable system into a small form factor that takes up very little space and looks very curious compared to other pricier and bulky systems.

The price was great for the system, the games seem very decently priced and of course I am psyched because I got the one thing that I wanted for Christmas already. Now I can drive by and smile at all the little fanboys twiddling their thumbs and waiting impatiently in line for a ridiculously  overpriced PS3 which has VERY LITTLE AVAILABILITY and in my non-expert opinion will not likely achieve the ability to compete against the big N's remarkable offering to the current console wars.

Oh yeah, a bit of advice, grab any extra controllers you might find in the stores because we had to search extensively to find an extra controller that wasn't being sold for 3 times the amount you'd expect to pay at a retailer.

One word to sum up the WII: Awesome!!!

author: James J.
title: great game system
content: great game system that is lots of fun. So get it so you can play lots of games it has good features and its still a lot cheaper than the other systems.

author: Kindle Customer
title: Wii love it!
content: I love it. We played it as soon as the boys got home. It is worth every penny. It was easy to set up and we had no problems with setting up the sensor bar. Batteries did come with the remote, but I would buy new ones. The Wii Sports game is very cool. The remote felt a little weird, but we worked it out. I loved the fact that you can do so many different moves with your body to accomodiate the characters on the screen. I do not agree with this being a one star item , but hey I'm just a big kid anyway what do I know. If you have kids well, trust me when I say that they will love it.[...]

author: Steven Sabin
title: A game system for the WHOLE family
content:
I'm a 40-something dad whose gaming experience can be measured in minutes -- not hours -- so you are getting a review here by a real neophyte.

The Wii has definitely found a niche, and I think that niche will prove to be not just "tween," "teen," and "20-something" crowd, but the entire family.  I knew something was going on when my 11-year old had his 69-year-old grandmother doing "virtual" bowling with him and laughing hysterically.

Where do I start?  First, I like the diminutive footprint of this unit and the silence.  We replaced a Sony Playstation 2 with the Wii.  My biggest grip with the PS2 was that it sounded like a freight train...the fan was very, very noisy.

The Wii hasn't tried to outmuscle the competition.  They've done something smarter: they've tried to be different.  The PS3 is big, powerful (and probably noisy), expensive, and not selling all that well at $[...]+ a pop.  In contrast, my son is perfectly satisfied with the $[...] Wii (he had to pay for it from his own savings), and I like the fact that the Wii system requires more physical interaction than just moving your thumbs.

I also like the integrated wireless capabilities of the Wii.  It took me about 3 minutes to get it connected to my home wireless network, which is an absolute world record compared to the frustration of getting other devices connected (such as my office laptop).  Nintendo did a great job of making this simple, and writing a decent manual with step-by-step instructions.  I put the MAC address into my router's list of trusted devices and within minutes - voila - we were connected.  The device downloaded a firmware update and then installed a nifty utility called "the internet channel" that lets us surf the 'net from the living room on our TV screen using the Wii.  [...].  Very cool.

We've only had the system for a couple of days and haven't explored all the features yet.  My son has had fun building little "Mii" characters (sort of like screen avatars) for himself, his pals, me, grandma, aunts and uncles, etc.  We've also watched weather forecasts and news now that it is connected to the internet, and of course, he's played games (the Sports disk that comes bundled with the Wii...and a Mario Party 8 disk).

The number of titles currently available for the Wii seem to be rather limited, but since the Wii is backward compatible with Gamecube disks, there is a library of 545 compatible games from that platform to choose from as the Wii builds up its own library.

The game controller itself is very innovative and is definitely what makes this system appealing to the over-18 crowd -- all the way up to the AARP crowd.

One neat little feature for parents is the daily log that shows how much time has been spent doing activities.  So now when those inevitable disagreements come up about how much time "Junior" has spent in front of the TV screen, you'll actually have an impartial log to turn to.  The first day, my son spent 6 hours and 47 minutes -- but that will be the exception, not the rule.  Grandma let him go overboard with his new toy.

If you are a hard-core gamer that has to have photo-realistic graphics, then this probably isn't the system for you.  But if you are looking for something the entire family can enjoy, and doesn't try to be a "me too" system like the PS3 and Xbox 360, I think you'll find this system to be very innovative, very interactive, and very fun.

author: Cristopher Carlos Martinez
title: Excellent fun!
content:
I'm a 33 year old man. Married with two kids. I'm also the owner of a Xbox360 (which I love) but definitely the Nintendo Wii has the most play time in my home. Thanks to the AMAZING Nintendo first-party games and to its easy accessibility. the Nintendo Wii is by far my favorite console this generation. It has hardcore games for seasoned, veteran gamers like me and more laid-back, addictively fun for my family. This is a MUST buy.
Thanks Nintendo. Thanks to you my family now play videogames together. I will always be your fan.

author: A. Berrier
title: Wii wins over family
content: Our entire family has been unable to put down our Wii since we opened it Christmas day, as a next generation system it might not win with its graphics (which I find fine) but what it really packs is a very fun, very accessible system for almost anyone. Our entire extended family (aged 7-70) has greatly enjoyed taking swings in Wii Sports. Bowling seems to be a favorite, with tennis a close second. Our other "more serious" titles (Zelda, Madden, Tony Hawk) have also seen play and so far the Wii delivers on almost all fronts. The innovative motion sensor technology has great possibilities for both hardcore gamers, and what I feel is even more important, it attracts "non-gamers" to the system. Having three generations all having a blast on this machine really is what gives it a 5/5.

author: All-access Customer
title: The best console in the gaming industry!!
content:
The Wii is a completely unique gaming experience. You use a motion sensitive controller to play the games, and it is a lot of fun too!

There is quite a variety of games for the Wii, all very unique and well-created by Nintendo.

I recommend the Wii for all ages, from kids to middle-aged adults. The Wii is also quite inexpensive compared to the PS3 and XBOX 360, and it gets you up off the couch moving around, yet you still have loads of fun! This product is an excellent buy if you love fun and games. I hope this review was helpful.

author: Michelle Hart
title: Having way too much fun!!!
content:
We are absolutely loving this system!  If I could find any drawbacks it would be that the system should come with two sets of remotes (2 nun-chuck and 2 regular).  Other than that....it's just amazing!  And for those of you wanting a workout....holy cow....just playing the sports games that come with it will give you a good workout.

We give this system 5 stars!

author: Michael Kerner
title: Wii Love It
content:
When Nintendo felt lost in the shuffle for teh past few years, they definitely needed to find a new way to get back in the console wars. Although they have had a very strong lineup with the Gamecube including Super Smash Brothers Melee, The Legend Of Zelda: The Wind Waker, and Super Mario Sunshine, many people seemed to really be more interested in the Playstation 2 and Xbox. Nevertheless, the company needed to find a new way for gamers to play all sorts of great games. That definitely hits well with the Nintendo Wii. Since the hype grew back last year with the new methods we can play video games, can this new system can redefine video games at home forever? The answer is really YES!!!

The Nintendo Wii game system is a new system that really changes the way we play video games. The gameplay on this system is all featured on a wireless remote which you can use your body to move your characters around in new ways. The system comes with a wired remote, a nunchuck analog controller attachment, and has a internal memory where you can store all your video game data. The system does include Wii Sports, which is a fantastic mini-game compilation that warms you up to the new ways you can play baseball from swinging the controller like a bat and a racket to play tennis, to a simple pair of boxing gloves in Boxing that you can use to knockout opponents. The remote also works great for games like Excite Truck, that you can use as a steering wheel to drive your car, or a fishing rod to catch reekfish in The Legend Of Zelda: Twilight Princess.

The compatability with the system also works great for Gamecube owners as well. You can also play your classic Gamecube games on this system like Mario Kart: Double Dash, and Metroid Prime 2: Echoes. All you need to do is simply plug your gamecube controllers into the specialty port, and you can play all those great games Gamecube lovers know and love. The only disadvantage with this is that you can't turn the system off with the Wii remote whenever you play a gamecube game. Instead, you have to turn it off from the main console itself, whcih isn't a big problem. You also can download a whole deal of great classic games from Nintendo's past into the virtual console, and play wonderful games like Super Mario 64 from the Nintendo 64 system, and The Legend Of Zelda from the NES era. You can also download great games from other classic consoles, including the Sega Genesis and Turbographx 16. You can play classic games like Sonic The Hedgehog and Bonk's Revenge that you download from the Wii's online shop, and just play away.

While other systems like the Playstation 3 and Xbox 360 are more about the hype and cost more bang for your bucks, the Nintendo Wii really does deliver in a fantastic system that does deliver in changing not just the way we play video games, but keeps the fun alive for everyone young and old alike. Although I had a tough time trying to find the system, it is really worth the purchase. I love this system, and if you're a die hard Nintendo fan or someone who doesn't yet have a video game system, you'll love the Wii too.

Price: A-

Setup: B+

Gamecube Compatability: A

Graphics: A

Sound: A

Control: A

Fun & Enjoyment: A 1/2+

Overall: A 1/2-

author: JoCo
title: FUN!!
content: The wii is the best game system ever. Even though we are the last people on earth to own one. The Amazon purchase was a pleasant experience. The system came quickly and in great condition.

author: W. COLLEY
title: Wii has made a fan of Mii
content:
I admit I thought the controller idea was very cheesey at first, but wow is it a blast. This thing is great at parties and oh the stories I can tell you about friends playing the home-run derby drunk... lets just say thank GOD for the wrist-strap. The only flaw to the active remote... and its a mild one, is that for folks who play video-games to relax or wind down from a stressful day the entire effort it takes to play some games can be a bummer... but in that case I say just download a classic NES, SNES, N64, SEGA, or TG16 game.

Conclusion: It's not a perfect system, but I can honestly say it DOES live up to alot of the hype, and well worth the purchase price for a novice or hardcore gamer.

Positives: Crowd pleaser at party, player feels more "into" the game, Opera net browser works well... not perfect but well and is free (till June), downloadable games for fee, free download of a wii survey channel, Gamecube games controller and mem card compatibility, built-in wireless works well, small footprint and convinence of wireless controller out of the box, Decent free game included (no one does thing anymore), free Wii weather channel is a neat idea that still needs work (data is a bit outdated).

Negatives: NO DVD movie support (rumored to be included on future versions), wirless keyboard a MUST option for net surfing (but not available as of yet), Downloadable video game library is extremely limited, wired ethernet connection addition accessory, Wii points system can burn you (extra points are often times wasted becuase of varies in price and limiting the purchase amounts), Game library still need much more growth, limited availability of consoles

author: Rob
title: Made a fan outta me!!
content:
Let me just say that I am not a fanboy of any system, I own them all and they each have their perks. I won't go into technical details on this system for the simple fact that by now you've heard them all. However, I will say this, just in case your like me and skeptical at how well the motion sensor works and how "fun" it is to flail around your living room hitting tenis balls on the screen...ITS FUN!!! Thats right I said it. I'm normally an XBOX or Playstation fan and when I saw this I wasn't even planning on getting it. It seemed like something only small children would like. I'm the type of guy who likes to sit back and drink a beer with the guys while we talk crap and play madden. So the idea of swinging an imaginary bat seemed juevenile and just plain dorky to me. I went ahead and got it with my wife in kids in mind, I figured it'd keep them busy while I was on my PS3 or my 360. Well it turns out that this thing is fun, incredibly accurate and family oriented. I can't remember the last time we could all sit in the same room and play each other and have a good time. Its easy enough that my wife, who doesnt play games, can do it, and challenging enough that I could enjoy it. We played the Wii Sports all night and had a blast. I guess the point of this review is to let the "tough guys" like myself, know that this system is worth every penny, and to folks with families this thing can be a cheap date on Sat. if your looking for some family fun. I didn't abandon my 360 or PS3, but this is something we can all do together. My boys will be coming by this weekend and I'm gonna hand it to them in baseball LOL.

I guess this is more of a testimonial than a review LOL, ah well you get the point

author: Computer Tyme
title: It died after about a year
content: It worked ok for about a year but now locks up constantly. Of course this happened right after it went out of warranty.

author: Sparkey
title: Four Stars
content: need a new one this one is fine for used

author: EGAD1 "morris"
title: The best
content:
The nintendo wii is the most unique console ever made. It has the best price on all the consoles even though the graphic capabilities are not as good as the other two consoles because the wii operates on 480p graphics while the PS3 and 360 operate on or around 1080p. But don't be fulled by graphic capabilities if the games are not fun there is no point in having all those graphics.
This is where the Wii takes the cake it makes even some boring games loads of fun like baseball. I will devote sections of this review to each major part of the Wii.

The first part is the system itself. Like i said before it isn't the most powerful system but it still sports very good graphics.
Three of the best graphics games are Legend of Zelda, Mario, and Metroid. One of the coolest features is the self loading disc slot.
This cuts down on scratching, alot! It can also self load gamecube games. This system is fully backward compatible with all gamecube games
there is no software to download or anything like that. You just load it in and you are ready to play. On the back of the system there are
five ports three near the bottom two near the top. The three on the bottom are for the sensor bar, the cord that goes to the plug and the cord that goes into the DVD player. The two near the top are USB ports for things like keyboards when your surfing the web or using Wiiconnect24. This system is also very quiet you don't even hear it running. When first powering up the system you will go through the same process on the DS. They will ask you for your birthday what time it is ask you to set parental settings etc. After that each time you turn it on you will go through a be sure to read the health and safety manual before playing video games warning. Also there is a 512MB flash memory inside the system you can also copy memory to a SD card slot on the front of the system provided you have a SD card. On top there are slots for four gamecube controllers and two gamecube memory cards. These slots have coverings that can flip down and up. Another feature is you have the choice to lay the console on its side or stand it up with the included stand.

Part two is about the channels. When you first start the system you will have six channels the weather channel, the news channel, the Wii shop channel, the Mii channel, the picture channel and most importantly the game channel. In the lower right hand corner of the
channel menu you can acces Wiiconnect24. In the lower left hand corner you can access the settings and memory.
To access a channel you just pooint at it with your Wiimote select it then push start.
The game channel is where you start any gamecube or Wii game except wii fit wich will make its own channel.
The Mii channel is where you make and edit Mii's. Mii's are used for games like Wii sports and Wii play and Wii fit.
Weather channel, shop channel, and news channel all require internet connection by either a wireless router, the nintendo wi-fi hub that plugs into your computers USB port, or the Wii LAN cable.
Now the shop channel is for buying other channels (i.e. vote channel) or old games from the NES, SNES, sega genisis Neo Geo, Nintendo 64, and Turbografxs 16. Wiiconnect24 is where you can send and recieve messages from other Wii owners that are on your friend list. Your friend code will be generated as soon as connect to the internet using Wiiconnect24.

Part three its about what you get in the package. What comes with the Wii besides the Wii is a stand, the sensor bar, the plug that goes to your wall, and the plug that goes into your DVD player. It also comes with
the quick setup manual, the owners manual, and the channel manual. A Wiimote, nunchuk, and the game Wii sports are also included. Wii sports is a game that has golf, bowling, tennis, baseball, and boxing. Really all it is is to get you used to how you are going to be using the Wiimote and what you can do with the Wiimote.

Part four is about the games. In my opinian nintendo has some of the best games on a console it has a wide range of titles and ratings.
It also has very good sequals to their classic titles like super mario sunshine and metroid prime 3. Although they have not released sequals to all their classic games they are sure to some time in the future life of the system. This system has games for every person in your family from hardcore to never even played a video game.

Part five is about internet service. This system unlike their prevous consoles has fully functional internet play. For the most part its free although their are some extras that you must pay for. To find a fully functional internet game all you have to do is look for a
blue circle in the upper left hand corner that has Wi-Fi in white letters. Their are also some games that use Wiiconnect24, but these games are not fully functioning internet games. Now i won't lie to you their internet games aren't the best but for bieng free their are very good.

In the end if your looking for a powerfull system that has lots of bells and whistles this isn't it, but if your looking for a fun system with
a few bells and whistles than the Wii is for you.

author: Jazzyp
title: I'm really digging my animated self!
content: Wow...great fun for kids of all ages.  Just make sure you have adequate moving-around space for the 'kids' that play hard.

author: Darvin H.
title: Four Stars
content: No complaints the wii works and it was delivered on time.

author: Carolina Casas M
title: Very good
content: all very well, excellent equipment protection. wii functioning well and in very good condition. very very good sin mas que

author: Jeremy Wiles
title: Wii is my next gen console choice!!!
content: I love this system it's about the most fun ive had playing video games since the days of Nintendo 64!!  The controllers are awesome I love the freedom of wireless and the built in speaker makes the games that much more realistic!!  The virtual console is great but the only drawback is that if you dont have a broadband connection then you can't access the library of games of yesteryear.  [...]  Overall this is an amazing console and I would highly reccommend picking it up if you already havent!

author: Adrian Meza
title: Clarify please
content: I was expecting 2 nunchucks because the description said "1 nunchuck" twice. When I asked for clarification, BigDaddyDon1981 only copied and pasted the description. Other than that, the stuff that was included in the package was in good condition.

author: beachgirl
title: awesome
content: I do not know how anyone could not love using this system. There are many games to choose from, so everyone should be able to find a game he likes. It does suck that only one control is included though. Anyone who is not single needs a second control, and that will cost another forty dollars. I bought one that game with nine games, for fifty dollars, and the games are fun. They are not the best, but for ten dollars more, worth the money.

author: someguy
title: Awesome!
content: I finally got one of these and it was worth the wait.  It comes with Wii Sports, which is fantastic because you can instantly see just what the Wii brings to the table as far as an alternative to the XBox 360 and the PS3.  Don't get me wrong, I'm not a Nintendo fanboy, I had a PS2 and an Xbox but no Gamecube, and I think all three of the next-gen systems are great, so I'm not hyping the Wii at the others' expense, but people who compare it directly to those are missing the point.  As far as graphics and processor power and all that, the Wii is behind those.  But what Wii offers you is something that those can't.  It's like having one of those fancy video game arcades with all the crazy virtual games that cost a buck a minute right in your living room.  Heck, Wii Sports is practically like having a bowling alley in your living room.  And that's just one of the five sports included!  There are control issues here and there, especially with the boxing game, but most of the problem is realizing what movements the machine is looking for and which ones it interprets as what actions in the game.  All in all, I can't believe how much fun it is.  I can't wait to try Zelda and to see what other great games come out in the next year.  Highly recommended to anyone who likes fun.

author: T. Paquette
title: Family Fun!
content: The Wii is an absolute blast that brings family fun back center stage. My youngest (six years old) is a bowling manic! The sports games are incredibly fun. We can't wait for Wii Play to release in February.

author: George H. Paulussen
title: Very impressed
content:
This is my first game console and i am very happy the way it works . It is easy to install and easy to use and most important it is a lot of fun. Especially the included game of wii sport.

If you can get your hands on one i would say buy it.

author: J. Romano
title: It got our lazy butts off the couch!
content:
First gaming system that I really got into, and I have to say really got my lazy butt off the couch!
We also got the Wii Fit, which I would also recommend as it really does not seem like you're exercising.
A word of caution--do it easy on the Fit the first few times.  We got really competitive on the down hill slalom and went back and fort beating each others score.  After two hours of this, my abs were SORE the next morning.  Same with the hula-hoop!

Lots of family friendly games available and plenty of fun for all ages.

author: V. Abney
title: WII
content: NICE GAME CONSOLE BUT SOME GAMES ARE CRAP I MEAN ITS FUN PLAYING LIKE SMACKDOWN VS RAW AND BOWLING OR TENNIS OR SHOOTING GAME OR EVEN PLAYING THE OLD MARIO 3 THAT U HAVE TO BUY ONLINE ON THE GAME BUT I LIKE PLAYING GTA4 AND COD4 AND LIVE 08 THEM GAME R SO STUPID ON THIS GAME IF U GET THIS GAME I HOPE U GETTIN IT JUST FOR THE OLD MARIO GAMES R OTHER OLD CLASSIC GAMES AND HOPE U GOT A XBOX OR PLAYSTATION3 ALREADY CAUSE IF THIS YOUR FIRST CHOS. U WILL BE MAD

author: Merideth A. Black
title: Wii, the smart  game console
content:
Not only is this game fun, but its smart too. The wiimote turns off when you turn the console off. It's very user friendly and can almost sense what you're trying to accomplish to help you complete the task.

It's a lot of help for parents who played games before the memory card era. Oh, yes and parents I almost guarantee you'll love Wii sports more than your children, so every once in a while pretend like you got this

system for them -to throw them off.

author: Hhutyera
title: Met our needs
content: Fully satisfied w purchase. Didn't have all it's part, but we had fried our previous one & were able to take what was needed from our old one.

author: Carolyn Sanabria
title: Good condition
content: In really good condition for the price that I paid.

author: Megan Pawlak
title: Wii Sports a good measure of the console's abilities
content:
I was amazed at the sensitivity and area that the tiny IR bar could read. It covers an area of about 5ftx5ft or MORE once you have it set up correctly. It senses even the smallest movements.

One point ot be concidered is the players ability to imagine themselves in an environment. While intuition might tell you to point at the screen to aim, that's not the case. You actually have to aim where you normally would if you were in that situation. Thus, something like hitting a ball that's coming at you becomes tricky if you're aiming below you because that's the level of the tv. The Wii wants you to act naturally at your own body levels, not aiming at the screen like an end-all-be-all answer. It takes some getting used to.

I wish I had my Legend of Zelda: Twilight Princess in order to see if these comments were useful there.

Bottom line: an excellent console that goes above and beyond, though it takes some self training to get used to the handling of the Wii remote. WELL worth the $250. More features should be added as the console gets older (more internet channels and the ability to connect to other players).

author: CAPS
title: Wii Console
content: This is really a good game for the family.  We have a lot of fun.  I got the item earlier, which was really good.  That why I like to buy from Amazon, because so fa so good I haven't gotten no problem yet.  I really recomend this game to any body.  I was looking for this game all the stores over St. Petersburg, Bradenton, Clearwater Florida and no ones have it, but when I look in Amazon.com I saw it and I bought it right away. I'm a happy customer.

author: Julie
title: Fun and games for everyone!
content:
I love the Wii because it is so easy to use. Once Nintendo switched from just A B and the cross controller, I found myself unable to coordinate my fingers and keep up with the technology. Since we have purchased the Wii, I have been able to play games again because I understand the controller. For the most part, you just point it at the TV and wave it around. You can make it as active or as passive as you want to.

They also have a wide range of games available for the Wii so all ages and skill levels can play on it. You can use the game cube games on it too.

Another cool thing is that you can use the Wi-Fi and link up with people around the world to play! Much funner than just playing with yourself and it helps you to develope your gaming skills. You can also download classic nintendo games. :)

I would recommend this to anyone! Well worth the money.

author: Phillip Bosier
title: Four Stars
content: Delivered on time works great.

author: M. Kushma
title: love my game system
content: I love my WII. It is good fun. Now my game system collection is complete

author: KristaS
title: now i understand what all the fuss is about!!!
content: Just got a Wii today - we are not gamers at all - but this is so awesome. I cannot believe how fun it is, even just bowling is a blast! The main reason I bought it is because my not quite 4 year old son is having surgery tomorrow and I wanted him to have something new to do to keep his mind off of the possible pain/discomfort he may be in so this is his early birthday/sorry you have to go thru surgery present! - and he and his brother have been playing mario kart all night and it's been a blast, it's lots of fun for all of us, even my husband who is even less into gaming systems than I am - he and I are looking forward to the kids going to bed so we can challenge each other to a game instead of mindlessly sitting in front of the tv. I'll admit the price tag hurt a little when I bought the Wii, Mario Kart, an extra remote and an extra wheel all at once, but I can tell it'll be well worth it. I can't wait to get the Wii Fit and Active and so much more. This is so great for families! I am looking forward to taking it to family gatherings - I know it'll be popular!

author: Amazon Customer

author: Patricia Bynum

author: GGG
title: ... long time to get a Nintendo Wii but I like the console and have started collecting for it
content: It took me a long time to get a Nintendo Wii but I like the console and have started collecting for it.

author: S.
title: One of the best systems in years
content: I haven't been impressed by video game systems in recent years...aside from minor innovations, basically each new system represents an improvement in graphics.  The basic concepts really remain the same...every once in awhile, you get something new, but by and large each game seems to be a knockoff of the previous.  Sequels are ubiquitous.  For that reason, I haven't really been a "gamer" since the NES was all the rage.  My brother has been a big gamer, so I always try his latest system or hot game, but can never really get into it...then he brought the Wii out to my house.  I have to say, Wii sports is very addictive.  Although these aren't the most realistic graphics by modern standards, the Wii remote more than makes up for this shortfall.  I find myself getting into the games, positioning myself as I really would for a real tennis or golf game.  I haven't played any of the other games yet, so I'm curious how the Wii remote holds up for all the others.

author: hbJWA
title: Wii, indeed
content:
I was fairly skeptical about all of the enthusiasm regarding the Will -- after all, how different could it really be from other platforms?

All I can say now is, Nintendo -- forgive me for having doubted you.

It really *is* fun for the entire family.  It really *is* easy to setup and use.  It really *is* the most interactive video game experience I have ever seen.

It is the best value in video gaming, and well worth the wait.

author: Christine Wood
title: Just what I wanted
content: I got this to see netflix on my TV. Works great. And I may plat a few games on it also.

author: 40creek
content: No HDMI. WTC???

author: Peter Svochak
title: What a workout!
content:
I got advance notice of the upcoming week's ad from Wal*Mart and parked myself in the Electronics Dept. for 3 hours until 12:01 last Saturday night. When I unboxed my Wii, setup was a breeze, The sensor bar is unobtrusive and blends right in with the top of my TV. The following morning, I was fooling around with the Wii Shop Channel and my Wii automatically found my wireless DSL modem upstairs and connected to the internet! I was amazed. I was able to connect to the internet without running cables or even getting up off the couch!

The Wii does so much more than play games. You can get News and local weather, download classic NES, SNES, N64, Genesis, NeoGeo, and TurboGrafix 16 games. Wii points cost $.01 USD and the average game is 500 Wii points to download.

Know someone else who has a Wii? Exchange Wii Numbers and you can send messages back and forth.

The Wii Sports Pack is amazing! I woke up Monday morning with an aching shoulder, butt and thighs from bowling for close to six hours straight. The disc also includes a Personal Trainer of sorts. You play for five minutes at a combination of Golf, Baseball, Tennis, Bowling, and Boxing. And at the end, it gives you your Fitness Age (20 being the best possible age). My first day, I scored a 45, second day 38, and my third day I actually went UP (because I was sore from playing Wii and working at a tire factory) to 72!!

author: J. McCracken
title: Great!
content:
This is a very awesome system. The system itself is beautiful, small and pefectly designed. The graphics power of the system is slightly better then the old Xbox. But if you have an HDTV, I recommend buying Component cables for the Nintendo Wii. It will make games look way better.

  As for the gameplay, It is quite enjoyable. It's easy to learn how to use the remote for anyone.  It's truly a game system for family and friends.  My Dad was able to quickly learn how to play some golf on Wii Sports. He is horrible when it comes to learning how to play games, or use electronics. He don't even know how to turn on a PC. It's amazing how much they can do with the remote and nunchuck. I can't wait to see what kind of games will come out in 2007.

I recomend this system to anyone who likes playing with their friends or family. If you value gameplay over graphics, then you came to the right place. Nintendo Wii is gonna rock yo' socks.

author: TOAN
title: Five Stars
content: great

author: Doris Bender

content: What a great way to get in some exercise. Be sure to warm up first though so you don't injure yourself. Well worth the price! Delivery was very fast.

author: A. Pilonieta
title: One of the best video game system ever
content:
Wii is one of the best game system ever made, my kids (4, 6 and 9 years) and I, enjoy it very much.

Wii es uno de los sistemas de juego jamas creados, mis hijos de 4, 6 y 9 años y por supuesto yo, lo disfrutamos mucho.

author: Brett Anderson
title: The Wii is Great
content:
I got a Wii last May, and it was between the Wii and the Xbox 360.  I liked the new features the Wii had when comparing it to the other consoles, but I wanted Halo 3 for the 360 which is coming out soon.  However, that's the only reason why I wanted the 360.  I'm a college guy, but despite what people say that the Wii is for kids only, think again.

The Wii has games for everybody alike.  You don't have to purchase the kid games if you don't want to; there are plenty of other options.  And with Legend of Zelda, Smash Brothers coming out in December, Guitar Hero III in October, Resident Evil, Mario Kart Wii next year, Metroid Prime: Corruption (which is out already), and even a Mario and Sonic Olympic game (which looks good), there are games that can satisfy even a college guy.  There's also Madden 08.  It's nice to see that you basically do the action that the character is doing.

The good thing about the Wii is that the online feature is free.  More and more games are going to be coming out for online play, through WiFi connection.  Guitar Hero III, Smash Brothers, Pokemon, Mario Strikers Charged, and others in the future.  Though I liked Xbox Live, the Wii's online will only improve with games in the future, and if you don't have to spend money on that, then the better.

Overall, the system is good for anybody, new or experienced at video games.  It's simple to get used to, and yet brings difficulty to people who want a challenge.  Get into the game!

author: Jennyfer camp
