title: Love It, Love It, Love It
content: I can not say enough!  I bought this for my son for christmas and couldnt wait.  I hooked it up and was hooked immediately.  Finally a game console that we the parents can actually use and enjoy as well!  I played all the wii sports and was actually good at them all!

author: Michael
title: Abesolutely amazing!!!
content: WOW! I wasn't sure about what I was getting when I stood in line for a Nintendo Wii Saturday night, but I was pleasantly surprised when we opened it up at home. I've had Xbox 360 for nearly a year now, and the Wii is so much better! Wii Sports is, literally, the funnest game I've ever played! This is definitely the best game system out there, and would be my recommendation to anyone I meet! Don't hesitate when considering buying a Nintendo Wii!

author: Lynn
title: Not great graphics but lots of fun
content:
The graphics on the WII games are not up to the standard of the other newer video games (XBOX, Playstation, etc.) but for the interactive games and workouts it is quite sufficient.  Each motion is picked up great and it feels like you are getting as good a workout as if playing the real sports.  Additional games purchased for use with the WII are just as realistic.

The best part is you can have fun playing video games while moving your body at the same time.  Parents don't have to feel so bad about their kids playing the video games.  It also provides great entertainment for the spectators.  Watching someone "pretend" to hit a ball or punch someone in the face when there is not the real thing in front of them is very funny!!

author: Ashley Hayden
title: One Star
content: It's doesn't work that's my review

author: Lyude
title: A review
content:
I didn`t buy my Wii off of Amazon but I can still tell you its a amazing system.

First of all, the gameplay is very good. Especially on Wii Sports, which is the first great game ever to come with a game system. This is because the fact that you actually have to get up and move as if your actually playing a sport, which makes it more realistic. Also, you might think that you`ll lose grip of the remote but they recently fixed that by simply adding a wrist strap to it.

Second, the Wii doesnt just play Wii discs, it also plays Gamecube discs (there goes your need for a Gamecube).

The Wii also has a feature called Virtual console, which lets you buy old games from the Wii shopping channel and play them on the Wii.

Finally, the Wii can also get Weather, News, and the web (but for that you have to download the Internet Channel off of the shopping channel, currently it`s free). All you need for that is wireless internet or a special adaptor for the Wii.

Overall, the Wii is a great system, and I highly reccomend it.

author: JC
title: Fun for kids and adults alike - not sure for how long though
content:
I was fortunate enough to snag a Wii when Amazon launched them on 11/19/06. I ordered Zelda alongside it.

I won't re-echo the sentiments of so many other reviewers in as great detail. Yes, this machine is fun; yes, the motion sensor is revolutionary; yes, it's cheaper than the other next gen consoles...

...But is this really next-gen, or an updated Gamecube?

I'm not sure if there's going to be enough interest in producing games which harness the true motion-sensing power of the Wii - only time will tell whether this is the case. It's a question of production costs and market demand.

Once the hype has died down I wonder whether kids over the age of 8 will simply put this console down and forget about it - or whether it truly will be the invite-your-friends-over-to-wii phenomenon that everyone is going crazy for right now.

I hope I'm proved wrong...

author: Victor A. Bustamante
title: Great console for the whole family
content: Great console for the whole family, sensors work great, never had a problem with it, it connects easily with the controllers and also to the internet.

author: DW Jones
title: Used Wii
content: My original Wii finally gave up the ghost so I purchased this used one to replace it. It has worked and performed just like the original and my wife was happy to be able to play her exercise game again.

author: Bridgette Fultz
title: Very fun, hip, and helpful!
content: The wii is the most modern and exciting game console for families. I am a teenager and my friends and I like to play wii together. We bowl on the game that comes with the wii, and also play guitar hero. I have been using Wii Fit for about a year, and just bought Wii Fit Plus today, and both are amazing work out games. My wii, which I've had since the first month it came out, has never failed and always been quick and fun. I have not had any failure with any of the parts or pieces.

author: Amazon Customer
title: Item to be returned
content: The system didn't come with any cables. I am unable to use the item and will be retiring it when I get the chance

author: Karen
title: How to Get a Wii!
content: I just purchased a Wii directly from Amazon for $250.  I managed this by subscribing to wiialerts.com.  I got a text message that alerted me to an email with the message that one was in stock.  The link in the email brought me to amazon and I purchased it right away. You have to act fast because they were sold out again in less than 10 minutes!  I also got signed up with nowinstock.com who also sent me an email that amazon had them in stock.  I received that email about 2 minutes later than the one from wiialerts.  Good Luck.  I will update this review when we actually play it.  I just wanted to help those of you still on your quest.

author: R. J. Benson
title: part of the collective
content: I can't add much to the discussion, except to say that my 87 year old father in law loved bowling; couldn't get over the realism.  He kept backing away from the foul line after he "threw" his ball, just like at the alley and would fall backwards into the sofa. . .

author: JBonaparte
title: Some programs still need work but the fun factor is high
content: I resisted getting a video console system for my children because I didn't want them sitting and just pushing buttons. This system is so different.  They play by moving and also stand up the whole time.  Simple games like bowling and tennis are played by the whole family and friends.  I noticed that syncing movement, speed of movement with each game is not perfect, but with current technology it is good enough for the youngest and the oldest to compete in equal terms.  I'm surprised how much energy we spend playing the boxing game.  Everyone gets some physical excersise so I can feel good about this purchase.

My 5 y/o nephew loves it just as much as we do (I'm 25 and my sis-in-law is 28). This system is so much fun and you really do find yourself getting into the games! I wish that detail was written into the description so I could've ordered it in time for the party.....bummer!!!! Grrrrr!!! THE REMOTES DO NOT CONNECT PROPERLY. CANNOT SELECT A GAME AND PLAY.....HELP!!!!

author: Matt
title: What a game console should be
content:
The Wii is what a game console should be: Good clean fun. The games have been very fun, and using the Wii remotes is pretty second nature once you start playing. It definitely becomes more fun and amusing watching other players take their turns. The batteries last pretty well in the Wii remotes, though I definitely see us getting the rechargable set in the not-so-distant future. We planned on going to the nintendo long before the surge in popularity due to the kid-oriented nature of many of the games. We have younger children and don't need the darker tones of the PS games.

It plays the gamecube games very well. We've bought as many of those as Wii games, probably. You will need gamecube controllers and a gamecub memory card to make that work.

I haven't tried the virtual console games, though it looks simple to setup. You will probably want to get gamecube or the "classic" controller for some of them, as the Wii remote won't work for all of them (just not enough buttons in the right places.)

We have had one issue arise. Our Wii stopped pulling the discs inat one point, and we suspect perhaps the toddler decided to put a few DVDs in at once, so keep this out of very young children's hands. On the bright side, Nintendo was very good to work with about a replacement. The customer service department seemed very helpful and the whole process was very painless, except for having to do without the Wii while the new one got here.

Overall the Wii has been even more fun than I expected. Everyone that has played it has thoroughly enjoyed it.

author: Connie
title: Great Way to get in shape.
content:
This was a gift from our son and I wasn't sure how it would help us. As soon as it was unwrapped we tried it out. It was made more fun by the participation of two of our adult children participating. I should say at the outset, I am 80 and my husband is 83. I needed to work on balance primarily. Wii helps you to build your profile, weight gain or loss, and whatever goals you want to work on. Today I progressed from beginner to intermediate level in balance. All of this comes in game format but it is a workout. There are categories of Yoga, Strength, Balance Games and Aerobics. You can spend as much or as little time as you want each day, week or do monthly checkups.

Our family, being quite competitive, had a blast bowling together. I can say with great pride, I beat my husband in the first two games. So much for a hook! We also played tennis and tried boxing.

Even though this is in game form I certainly get a work out and can also relax with Yoga.

Wii is terrific and I look forward to the new features.
Connie.

author: Felicia Taylor
title: My son is very happy!
content: Works as stated.  Arrived on time.

author: Brian
title: Dust collector after a month
content: I bought a wii because I'm not a serious gamer and just wanted something fun and simple to play. Maybe I got suckered in by the hunt for the hard to find wii or maybe by its cute little white case. Heres the deal though: Nobody is making any good games for this console. And all the games that use the wii's gyroscope tech. suck. If you have a tv over 32" forget this machine. I have a 1080P 46" lcd and it looks pathetic. The wii only outputs 480p. Right now your best bet is gonna be a xbox 360. It outputs 1080p, streaming high def netflix, super online play with other people and tons and tons of great games. Luckily I was able to sell my wii on craigslist while they were still hard to find and I immediately went and got a 360. The wii is a novelty and nothing more. Please don't get sucked into the hype, you will regret it.

author: T. Pavey
title: Perfect console for me....and probably you.
content:
I have been a Nintendo fan since the original NES launched and have stuck with them through ups and downs (loosing the FF series hurt).  The Wii is the perfect living room console system.  The last few years my PC has been my primary gaming platform. The console has been there for select games from the Nintendo library like Zelda, Metroid, and Mario games.  Most of the play time on my GameCube was for playing MonkeyBall minigames, Mario Party, or some other multiplayer game that anyone can pick up and play.  Nintendo was king in that department with the Cube and they will be even better now.  My friends who don't play any games have fun with MonkeyBall and Mario Party.  They aren't just for kids.  Look how popular DDR, eye toy, and guitar hero are.  Moving around and getting into the game is fun for everyone.

5 Reasons to buy a Wii.

1.The Wii is at a good price point to make it reasonable for a secondary gaming system as well as a primary system for casual gamers.

2.The motion control system and combined with the IR targeting of the remote make this console even more accessible.  You don't have to throw the controller as hard as you can.  A simple flick or sublte movement is enough.  Although, I confess to some aggressive swinging now and then.  Many people say Madden 07 for the Wii is the best version yet because of the control (just needs online play. Maybe in 08).  The Wii could revolutionize every genre out there if the software devs are creative enough.

3.Nintendo will keep their great multiplayer lineup and probably expand on it.  The new Rayman game is one of the new titles.  Returning we have Monkeyball, Smash Brothers, and many more in the pipeline.

4.They continue to have the best exclusive lineup in the industry.  Zelda, Metroid, and all the Mario games are amazing series that will continue to get better with the new console.

5.The virtual console is great. They just released the original Ice Hockey.  Now, that is a classic game that is still fun.

So, if you are like me and find your console to be used for casual gaming with friends who may not play many games, or if you just like the exclusives that Nintendo has, this is the perfect console.  Perhaps you are bored with the existing state of console gaming where the focus has been so much on graphics that only 1 or 2 actually good and original games come out per year.  In all honesty, unless you absolutely despise video gaming, there is no reason to not have a Wii.  It truly is the perfect console that has something for everyone.

author: Dr.E
title: Worst Experience as a consumer to date
content:
I purchased this for my son for Christmas 2016 purchased it in advance. Return Window closed, before I ever opened it to see if it even worked. This is unfair consumer praactices !!!!! Secondly I did not realize it came with nothing except unit, thus, I had to purchase all items separately. This why its 6th January 2017 and I finally know I was sold something worthless. Today all the adapters came in, my son was excited to finally play the Wii he got for Christmas. But this Wii cannot read any discs or games. You would like to think as a consumer they are knowingly selling items that they check and that function, not the opposite scenario were they don't check and don't know or they do check and don't care. My point is don't ever buy from this company and maybe don't ever buy used electronics. Learn from my mistake.
Sincerely, Dr. E PhD MD

author: jgUNCCrugby
title: Love my Wii
content:
In my household we currently have 7 different game consoles and this is by far my favorite.  This is a great way to burn off stress and have fun late in the evening.  It allows you to be a little competitive without sitting in the chair getting sore.  I love the interactive aspect and have found the games to be very entertaining.

I would recomend this for someone who wants a console but wouldn't consider themselves a super-gamer.  Anyone can pick this up and figure it out.

author: Gina Lollabridgida
title: Wii - best thing since sliced bread
content:
I love the Wii gaming system.  This was actually purchased used a second Wii system for our basement.  We have a very small family room in the house we recently purchased and were unable to set up any of the fitness and dancing games, so we got this for the basement gym area.

Wii is highly interactive and the best thing is that most games get you up and moving, which is great for both adults and kids.  When I DDR or any of the fitness games, I always lose weight.

Great family fun!

author: ha-evolution
title: Fun, fun, and more fun
content: I got this as a gift for my nieces and they loved it.  So did the rest of the family - in fact the parents are playing it more than the kids!  Originally I thought the only decent game for this was the included Wii Sports but that's not true.  There are several other games out there that are also fun to play.  I would recommend this for everyone.

author: jessecurry
title: Great System, Great Price, Great virtual console
content:
When I first purchased the Wii I was worried that the limited graphics capabilities would be a problem, but once I got my hands on the Wii-mote those fears completely disappeared.

Another awesome feature is the virtual console. I was a long-time emulator user and loved playing all of the old games on my PC, but it may not be legal to download the ROMS, and I couldn't play on my big plasma. The first download was Super Mario Bros., followed by The Legend of Zelda. Since then I've downloaded almost every title that's been released. Although the new games are the best part of the system the virtual console has allowed me to enjoy some more casual games.

If all that didn't make me happy enough, I can watch youtube videos on my TV now too.

author: Rick Jackson
title: Wii
content: thank you very much. this item was in very good condition. system plays great. i was supprised how great the item's condition was. also shipped very fast. got it 2 days before before expectence.

author: Headroom
title: Depends on what you're looking for...
content:
The biggest complaint I hear about the Wii is its lack of "Mature" content. The people who are complaining are totally missing the point. In a nutshell: if you are looking for a system that is "Bleed through your eyeballs" hardcore, than the Wii is not for you. If you are looking for a system that is simple, fun, and entertaining, than you've come to the right place.

PROS:

-Tons of extra downloadable content including classics from consoles past.

-Some really great games. I suggest: The Legend of Zelda: Twilight Princess and Super Smash Bros. Brawl

-Detailed interface design. Lots of little touches that show that care and love went into the system.

-Compatible with all of your gamecube games/accessories.

-Fun for everyone, from your creepy Uncle Charlie to your emo nephew.

CONS:

-Library of games is comprised mostly of worthless mini-game collections and other mediocre software.

-As mentioned before, there isn't a whole lot for the hardcore gamer. The only example I can think of offhand is MadWorld but it contains enough blood, guts and language to make up for a lifetime of joy, puppies, and rainbows

-Motion control can become menial and tedious in lower-quality games.

-Graphics are lacking compared to other next-gen offerings.

Although it is a departure from the norm, the Wii manages to be is fun and worthwhile. I give it two thumbs up.

author: Dew
title: Wii - Online notes and comparisons from a Wii and 360 owner
content:
First - here are a few important notes about the Wii's online capability:

#1 - Getting Connected - In order to get your Wii online you will need either a wireless network, a wired network with an online PC and a Nintendo WiFi dongle, or a Nintendo branded USB ethernet adapter.

  - A - Wireless network - no problems - you are all set.

  - B - Wired network - There is no ethernet port - only USB.  DO NOT think you can just run out and buy an off the shelf USB-Ethernet adapter b/c I tried and it doesn't work - which should have been obvious, but anyway they won't work b/c they don't have built in Nintendo drivers (remember this isn't a PC).  Nintendo will be releasing a Nintendo branded USB-Ethernet adapter in the next couple of months or so.  If you are like me and simply can't wait to get your mits on some old NES downloads then you can by the Nintendo WiFi dongle.  Originally created for use with the Nintendo DS, the dongle connects to a wired PC and "piggybacks" off of its internet connection which it shares wirelessly with surrounding Nintendo products - DSs and Wiis.  Easy to install once you download the latest drivers from Nintendo's website.

#2 - Ok - I'm connected - Let's download.

  Well the pitch is that for about $5-$10 you can download classic NES, Genesis, SNES, and N64 titles of the past.  Sounds awesome (albeit a little expensive), but the available titles are still pretty light with 'The Legend of Zelda', 'Super Mario 64', 'Sonic the Hedgehog', 'ToeJam & Earl', and 'Gunstar Heroes' being the most notable.

#3 - Online gameplay - Xbox Live it isn't.

  Apparently the capability of playing other people online exists in the Wii somehow, someday, but .... not today.  Nintendo's free online gaming network WiiConnect24 is supposed to connect the world of Wiis out there with multiplayer online gaming and traveling Miis (user profiles in lego form).  However, there currently are not any games available that use this network, not even Super Swing Golf (a.k.a Albatross 18 - a free PC game that exists entirely in the multiplayer online world) and no foreign Miis have yet to visit my Wii.  If you want to play others online it appears that Xbox Live is still far ahead of the competition on this front.

I won't labor over the core gameplay too much as anyone reading this probably gets the idea by now - less focus on graphics and more focus on innovative gameplay.

Wii-Mote - Innovative gameplay mechanic or short lived gimic?

I think the jury is still out on this one.  There are some areas where the motion control is awesome and makes gameplay exponentially more fun that the old button pushing in other consoles.  Wii Tennis, Super Swing Golf, Trauma Center, Rayman, and Excite Truck show how the motion control for sports games, driving games, and party games works beautifully and succeeds at thrilling non-gamers and gamers alike with fun, lively and engaging gameplay.  However, there are other areas where the motion control is rather awkward and is probably not the best mechanic.  Fighting games like Dragonball-Z and shooters like Call of Duty 3 show where having an analog stick and some buttons or a keyboard and mouse still feels more natural than swinging the Wii-Mote around.

Graphic-wise the Wii rates higher than current gen system, but far below true next gen systems like 360.  If the 360's graphics are a 10 and Xbox's are a 4, then the Wii would be about a 6.

Overall, the Wii serves as a great innovative party platform for gamers and non-gamers, young and old.  It is nigh impossible to not have a terrific time with the Wii.  It literally puts a smile on your face everytime you play it.  With that said, serious gamers who are only getting one "next-gen" console will likely be better served with an Xbox 360, as the Wii is somewhat of a novelty that won't provide an all encompassing game experience.

author: Anne Shirley
title: Nearly 30 year old Woman with no Video Game Experience
content:
I am nearly 30, haven't loved video games since pokemon and mario cart on N64, and I LOVE THIS SYSTEM!!! I love that you can invite friends over and laugh for hours, I love that the makers haven't made a completely new system in years and that there are tons of great games, I love that the system and games don't break the bank, and I love that there are a lot of games with more of a mini-game mindset.

I have never bought a new gaming system for myself and thought I might regret it as a frivolous waste of money. It wasn't. I'll be using this more than any other indulgent thing I've ever bought myself, except maybe my vibrator.

author: LS
title: Finally video games I can play
content: Never been able to master the strange movements of the other game controlers.  This is so much better.  The games that come with the system are great.  It only gets better when you add on.

author: David Michalkiewicz
title: Advertised as collectable. DEFINITELY not collectable...

author: Kindle Customer

content: I received a Wii and it was in very good condition, just like it said on the product. Everything came with it and the product was in very good working condition.

author: tmphs

content: Good buy. Works really good. My kids love it! And the games that came with it are amazing. This was one of my best purchases!

author: Jason Hines
title: Four Stars
content: I needed a wii so bad and this was in great shape

author: J. Harley
title: The true next generation of video games ...
content: PS3 and Wii are both viewed as next generation, but although the PS3 has better graphics and more processing power, there is no doubt that the Wii is truly the revolutionary of the two. I had extremely high expectations for the Wii after reading about it and it has exceeded my expectations in every way. I want to make it clear I am no Nintendo fanboy or even an avid gamer - the last system of any kind I purchused was the SNES and my daughter did get a PS2 a few years ago which I have probably played twice, but I've never even played a Gamecube. I can tell you though, in fun factor, this system is absolutely unbeleivable. Within an hour of hooking it up, my five year old and fifteen year old daughter were boxing on Wii sports, and what blew me away is I watched my five year old beat my fifteen year old for two hours straight. The fact that we could all pick up the system, figure out the controllers, and be having a blast in no time was amazing to me. No, the motion detection is not absolutely perfect, but you quickly learn and get around the nuances - they are no barrier to fun. The old school games available through the Virtual Console and the Gamecube compatibility are also awesome. Now I can go back and play some of the games I missed without investing in multiple system. For thise of you who have drifted away from home video games, I have some advice for you - its time to come back.

author: Birdieman
title: Wii is a winner
content:
I have a Wii for myself and have enjoyed playing the sports package and using Wii Fit. My wife and I donated a Wii to our locate in-patient rehab center. Studies have shown that rehabilitation is much more fun while using the Wii. Patients with all types of needs Physical, Occupational, and Speech therapies benefit from using the Wii. I know of several senior centers and retirement communities that have set up leagues using the bowling part of the sports package. Some places have waiting lists of people who want to take part in a Wii bowling league.

This is a 5-star system with many uses. It's more then just a toy.

author: tifany710
title: Absolutely Love IT!
content: I had played the Wii prior to getting it and had absolutely loved it. I have a PS2 as well and was looking to get one of the newer gaming consoles. I went with the Wii because of the fun of playing and it's more interactive. The Wii Sports game is great even though they are all short games it still provides loads of fun when you first try out your Wii.

author: Henry C
title: Wii: For kids and non hardcore gamers
content:
I purchased the console as a gift. However, I do now some information about the Wii. It gets 5/5 because everyone has a certain preference when it comes to gaming and consoles. It is not a "bad" console but it does appears to cater to a specific demographics.

Pro:
- Very interactive; players move around and use body movement during game play
- More kid friendly games
- Small design
- Price, very cheap and makes for a great gift to non hardcore gamer/kids

Cons:
- Limited well known games, for example: Final Fantasy, Metal Gear, and First Person Shooters

Wii - well. Yeah. Wii is awesome.

Not sure why I waited til now to review it.

But I loved it when I got it - used the heck out of Mario Cart - well worth it for that alone not to mention Dance Dance Revolution. Holy crap is that awesome.

author: James L.

author: LJ in WP

content: I bought this as a gift, and he loved it!  I personally got hooked on the Wii bowling game that comes with it. I played until my wrists and shoulders gave out.

author: MMcaskey

content: Easy to use and install.  The grandkids have spent hours on it with no issues.  A good investment for their visiting friends.

author: Susan Donckels
title: A Fun Diversion for the Entire Family
content: The Wii is a great electronic device that helps the family play together. Unlike other consoles (we love those too), the Wii encourages players to stand up and move. We have a house rule, while playing the Wii, everyone has to stand up. The handheld remotes work well from any position, seated, laying down, etc., but the fun is in the motion. There's a variety of software games available. We especially love the sports because it reinforces healthy competition with each other. I really don't think we'll ever get tired of it.

author: I. Leser
title: WII review
content:
I purchased it for my kids (18, 16 and 12 years old)
They all enjoy a lot with teh product.
I played with this and it is fun
i hope they will find it interesting even in few months

author: LIbby L.
title: Great Hardware and a lot of potential
content: Okay just to clarify some people give the wii a bad rap just because of its games but that's not really the wii's fault.  Basically game developers are to lazy to make a good game that effectively utilizes the motion control.  So the stick to the generic controllers of the PS3 and Xbox 360 and PS3.  Pretty much this is a bad time for video games because i think the Wii is the superior hardware. based on reviews The 360 and PS3 have a lot of Hardware issues and it's not good to spend all that money if its going to crash.  So basically the PS3 and 360 have all the best games because the developers don't feel like thinking of ways to use the motion controllers but they have a lot of hardware issues and the wii has pretty much no hardware issues and is almost perfect accept not a lot of really good games for it.  I do appreciate the few games that actually utilize the motion controls in an engaging way such as No More Heroes, Okami, Legend of Zelda, and Super Mario Galaxy but those are only 4 games.  so really a wii is a good buy because it doesn't have hardware issues so you can actually play the games even though there are really only four worth playing.  But with the 360 and ps3 you get all those games and then it crashes and 4 games is better than none at all.

author: slim
title: Fun for parties
content:
We have had our Wii for over a year. We bought some extra games to play, but so far, the ones that came with it (sports) are still our favorites. We don't find ourselves playing with it unless we have a party, and need to entertain the teens or younger adults with something.  Younger kids like it too, but the controls can be a little confusing for them when under age 5.  My 5-yr-old had no problem figuring out how to do the bowling, or boxing, but tennis still baffles us all somewhat.  Sometimes we swing, and it doesn't register as a swing at all, or it's "late" with the response.
  We don't own any other game systems. We chose this one to help us get up off our "sitters" now and then.  No problems with the system. We are just getting to know all the "Wii points" and other stuff that can expand the system more.  Overall, I'm glad we bought it.

author: Rene'
title: Works great
content: Works great.  Glad I got this at a good price.

author: J. Sober
title: Need a break from the hardcore?
content:
Got a Wii for Christmas yesterday! Gotta work today, so I'm counting the minutes until I can get home and play.

I have to say that this is definitely one of the most user-friendly systems I've ever owned. My parents, who still prefer to play on my old NES system, were able to pick up the controller and just play, without me having to explain much of anything. That alone is a testament to the designers at Nintendo, who, I firmly believe, are sheer geniuses.

So far, every title that I've tried has been loads of fun. Now, granted, I've only played a few titles and only for relatively short sessions. Plus, speaking for myself, there's the nostalgia aspect of finally getting to play some new Mario and Link stuff, since I haven't had a Nintendo system since the N64 (which was also awesome.)

All this is coming from a pretty die-hard Xbox 360 gamer. And, I'm NOT comparing the two systems; they're completely different in their approach and style, and, as we all know, variety is the spice of life. What I WILL say, though, is that the Wii is a breath of fresh air. After just finishing Mass Effect a few weeks ago, and before that, BioShock and Halo 3, the Wii is a wonderful change of pace.

Yes, I love hardcore gaming. I love playing seriously gorgeous, realistic-looking, challenging, well-written, epic games. But man, playing this is just a nice way to unwind after that 12-hour-long Halo 3 multiplayer session.

I think this system is a good pick for anyone who likes to have fun. Last time I checked, that was pretty much everybody on the planet. No, for those of us who are hardcore gamers, this will NOT replace your Xbox 360 or Playstation 3. But it sure makes a nice addition to your console collection.

Oh, by the way, DON'T give those money-hungry ebayers your hard-earned money! The only way we're ever going to get past this stupidity of consoles (or any popular electronics, for that matter) selling for two, three or four times more than retail is if we STOP SUPPORTING the pieces of trash who think they can make a quick buck off of us! Eventually, those greedy little no-talent knuckle-draggers will stop buying up all the consoles and we'll actually have them available in the retail stores, for suggested retail prices! The current suggested retail price for the Wii console is $249.99, NOT $441.99 (that's the cheapest for a new console on Amazon!) Oh, and if any of you price-gouging neanderthal sellers out there are reading this, please, do us all a favor and go walk in front of a bus. Now.

Now to find something else to do for that last hour of work...

author: S. Borden
title: BEST YOUTH  REJUVENATOR OVER FIFTIES
content:
The Wii console arrived via Fed Ex in just two days in new, perfect conditon.  Came with Sports package (I ordered the Wii Fit separately).  It came with all cables to hook into my new 42 inch plasma tv, and it is a bright, crisp picture.  I have been a real couch potato for too long, and this is so much fun, I have been playing it every day for hours, especially the team tennis.  You can play one person, as I do, against the games pre-existing characters, or purchase additional remotes and play as a family.  I ordered a nice spungy mat, so as not to wear out the carpet, and to protect my feet.

Also, between tennis sets, or golfing, etc., I watch the weather around the globe, and up-to-the-minute news updates, as it is Wi-Fi enabled, and connected to my router.

In one week's time my arms are noticeably regaining a more youthful shape.  My legs and tummy, too.  It has got me up and moving and playing/feeling like a kid again.  Even my mood has been lifted.  The best part is you can move at your own pace avoiding injuries, while having a boatload of fun...  I purchased another set today (at retail price) from Circuit City for a family with a kid.  They are going to love it too!!!!  If all that was available was just the Sports Package, this purchase was so well worth it.

author: Joao M. Goncalves
title: Wii
content: The Wii is a magnificent videogame console that gives you the power to really feel the game, i don't need to say anymore it's better to see it for yourselves. But if you are looking for power and graphics instead of fun and gameplay the Wii is not for you.

author: Mark Fagenal
title: Wii is Extrordinary
content:
I come from a family of longtanding Nintendo fans, and I have to say that every family should have a Wii. The system is very impressive, even after I've had it for a year. I can not believe any negative reviews for this system. But if you're the kind of person who thinks graphics are everything, don't bother to buy this product. You'll just be disapointed. The Wii does not have the best graphics, not as much as 360 and PS3, but it is the best game console I ever bought. For the first three days I had the Wii, I did not leave my living room. No food, drinks, or bathroom. Call me obsessed, but it's true. Another thing, the Wii does not have many single player only games. It is more of a family/party console.

 So, if you want a good family system, or if you are wondering what console to set up for a party, the Wii is the best choice.

author: Talitha Snyder
title: Better than the Wii U. (Note: Not tried Wii U)
content: I like this system more better than the Wii u! I haven't tried the Wii U. I have tried the Wii! I LOVED THE WII!!!!

author: Kyle
title: Fun!
content: Fun!

author: Tayler Stultz
title: Not what I expected
content: This needs to be advertised as a console only purchase. I was under the impression it had the cords and wiimotes. Luckily the cords and sensor bar are extremely inexpensive. Its just irritating not getting what you want.

author: MrsQueue
title: We are happy to keep playing our favorite Wii games
content: Our old unit had melting feet and wouldn't recognize game discs. We are happy to keep playing our favorite Wii games.

author: A. Rhode
title: Something for everyone - really!
content:
The Wii plays and feels great! I have been nothing but thrilled with my system and it's been great to play with different types of people.

For gamers, this system offers excellent games that allow you to play in an innovative way. What's better than actually aiming to shoot something?  Duck hunt anyone? This would be enough of a reason to get it, especially considering the price compared with the Playstation 3 and X-box 360. Zelda: Twilight Princess, Metroid Prime 3: Corruption, Super Paper Mario and Super Mario Galaxy (and more) rival the best games on any system. In addition to these new games you can get Super Nintendo classics for $5 a piece and Nintendo 64 classics for $10 on Virtual Console. Super Mario World, Super Mario 3, Donkey King Country, Mario 64, Zelda: Ocarina of Time, etc. Are you kidding me? These are some of the best games ever made! And you no longer have to break out your old system and spend 20 minutes blowing the dust out and tweaking the cartridges to get them to turn on. When you look at the other systems, their games always have a bunch of hype and then, with the exception of a handful, the games are disappointing. You read those reviews and they all have the same continuing theme: the graphics are great but the game isn't very innovative or it's so big that it gets redundant. The Wii keeps bringing out high quality games with variety. Also, more and more developers are concentrating on the Wii because of its popularity and the creative opportunities, so the games will keep on coming.

This system has really been marketed for non-gamers and for good reason. My Dad actually played tennis and had a good time. He's never gone near a video game in his life. My non-gamer friends also love coming over and playing. I must admit, although I've been an avid nintendo fan since the days of the original nintendo, these casual get togethers are by far my favorite type of gaming. The Wii offers a ton of games for getting groups together: Mario Party 8, Wii Sports, Mario and Sonic Olympic Games, Smarty Pants.

It should be noted for those who haven't owned a video game system before (who are good candidates for the Wii) that it only comes with one complete controller (remote and nunchuck) and the rest have to be purchased separately. At $40 per remote and $20 per nunchuck, it adds up. With any system, you have to buy extra controllers, but a complete Wii controller is slightly more expensive than controllers for other systems since it has the complete motion sensitivity. Unlike other systems, there is enough in the box to start playing right away for one person at a time. If you are planning on taking advantage of the virtual console games (and you should) they may require a $20 classic controller as well.

Another thing worth mentioning is that the motion-sensor bar simply consists of a couple of infra-red points (read: heat). It basically would work the same of you put two candles in the same location (which has been tested by people successfully). Therefore any other concentrated points of heat are going to interfere with the motion control including candles, and in the case of my apartment, the heat being on (the radiator is only a few feet from where I sit to play). This is something that has only recently became frustrating as it's gotten colder. I imagine that for many, this wouldn't be an issue, but something like a space heater will likely be a problem.

Overall, it's the best system (and best value) out there for anyone except perhaps for the gamers who just wants the same old games with better graphics.

author: Kcorn
title: Different than any other system and the first one our entire family loved!
content:
We came late to this system, mainly because we didn't realize how popular it was or how it differed from others out there. Having gone through the Xbox 360, Playstation 2, etc...it just seemed silly to get another system.

  So you can imagine my surprise when I tried this out and realized it was truly revolutionary, with movements very close to the actual ones used for such games as bowling, tennis and more. The controllers come with wrist straps for this very reason - some players have damaged televisions by swinging too hard and letting go of the controller. So please, take my advice and USE the wrist straps.

  We haven't tried a lot of the games yet but we found bowling to be extremely fun and the skill levels of the games varied widely,making it possible for a wide range of ages to play. It does take some motor skills to manage some of the games and I found darts to be a bit taxing, although I have hopes I'll improve with practice. Monkeyball was a major hit.

  As of this writing, this system is sold out everywhere. Our local video store, a major chain, carries accessories and games, but hasn't had a single system available for sale. We found that extra controllers were very useful so do consider getting some as well as looking at these items:Nintendo Wii Bundle #2 w/ Wii Sports & 3 Games

Wii Nunchuk Controller

Wii Classic Controller

author: P. Metz
title: Living up to the Hype
content:
By the time I was able to locate and purchase a Wii, I had read various reviews of the new console. Needless to say, the consumer reaction had my expectations set pretty high. I quickly found that the Remote and Wii combo fully lives up to everythig that I have read.

I bought the Wii at a retail location with Zelda: Twilight Princess. I opened the box and 4 easy steps later, was up and running. Even on my old 27 inch CRT with the factory supplied RCA cables, the Wii menu was crisp and impressive. My Wii remote instantly and accurately displayed a pointer that seemed a little sensitive at first, but quickly became easy to control with only slightly smaller, and slower movements. I created a Mii: a fun little extra with lots of customization available. In seven minutes or so I had created Miis for me and my girlfriend that were actually pretty decent caricatures of ourselves. Torturing myself, I left Zelda in the package and popped in the game that comes with the console, Wii Sports.

The Wii Sports games are very basic. Tennis requires no button pressing at all, and you don't move your Mii character to the ball, the computer does that for you. Despite the limitations, you can control the hardness and directionality of your shot by simply altering your stroke hardness and timing with the Remote. Baseball is also rather simple. It is more like a homerun derby mixed with one-on-one baseball you might play in the backyard with ghost runners and ghost fielders (based on your hit, the batter is declared out or is given a single, double, triple, or homerun, depending on how long it took for the ball to be fielded by the AI controlled fielders). Human players only control pitching and hitting, but the Wii Remote operates flawlessly. I was even able to place my hit like real baseball, hitting it down either line or up the middle. After a few innings I hit my first couple homeruns and moved on to the next game. Bowling is as simple as real-life bowling. You can line up your Mii and put as much or as little hook on the ball as you want by simply twisting the Remote in the corresponding direction. I bowled the best ten frames of my life on my very first round. Golf is a little more difficult. If you swing too hard, you will shank the ball pretty badly, and not in a predictable manner. It doesn't help matters that if a ball lands in the rough, your max shot power is reduced by half and there is no chance of reaching the green in two shots on a par 4. The Mii on-screen does not always match your back stroke accurately. Luckily, the on-screen backstroke doesn't seem to affect how well you hit the ball when you swing forward. Putting and chipping are all touch. If you have shot at least four or five rounds of golf in your life, you can just look at how far away the hole is on the TV and swing accordingly. You can read the greens just by looking at them and adjust your aim to correspond to the slope. The ball responds pretty true-to-life and it is very easy to find yourself overshooting the green or putting way past the hole. This is not a fault with the Wii, however, it is a reflection of the difficulty of the real game of golf. The final game on the Wii Sports disc is boxing. Not quite Fight Night, but still rather fun; Wii sports boxing will warm you up. You can float like a butterfly, though your feet don't control anything on the screen. Your gloves on screen mimic where your hands, equipped with the remote and nunchuck, are in real-life. You can bring your hands to your face and block and then dodge left and right. If you are trying to do a punch other than a jab, it requires a pretty specific motion of either the remote or the nunchuck (just uppercutting the air will not necessarily perform an uppercut on-screen; you have to exagerrate the motion quite a bit to see results), and don't expect to be able to execute lightning-fast combos, at least not until fight night or a new rocky game is released. Overall, the sports games are more teasers than anything else. They show the true potential of the wii remote and nunchuck, especially for sports game applications. I can't wait to see some of the old sports favorites adapted to the new control scheme. The potential is there and Wii Sports hilights this potential while offering replayable games that are still fun and intuitive. My girlfriend, who will only play zelda games, was up jumping around, boxing and nearly falling over returning tennis serves within ten minutes of setting up the console.

Zelda is beautiful so far, but I haven't really acquired enough items to make any firm determinations. I did, however immediately go out and buy Red Steel, which I have to say is great as well. It took a few levels to truly get the aim down and adjust to the sensitivity, even though I am still occasionally forgetting that the remote controls looking and letting the pointer wander off of the screen. The graphics are great and the control is fantastic after a little practice.

Considering the high price tag and extremely limited availability of the other next-generation consoles, I definitely prefer the Wii. Graphics will continue to get better and better until reaching a level of near reality, but what then? Nintendo has taken the first big step in radically changing the way that users interact with the digital world and I glady forfeit some minute details and crispness in the graphics for the brand new control scheme. So long controllers with 15 buttons and counterintuitive, "press this button to do this," memorization-required control schemes and hello pick-it-up and play, get-off-the-couch controls of the future.

author: Sam I Am
title: Wii - Big Hit Here - Best Holiday Gift We've Ever Received
content:
The Wii we received as a gift was an instant hit.  The child it was bought for had never played a video game before, but instantly and intuitively mastered the basics right away, especially with the optional (not included with a basic Wii purchase) sports accessories package.

The Wii graphics are first-rate and the wide selection of available games was also very positive.  Also, the games are such a high quality that they appeal to both kids and adults, so you won't be looking at your watch, wondering how long you have to endure playing one more game with your kid - you'll like the Wii as much as they do.

author: Spence-Daddy
title: Fun
content: I only have played Wii Sports on this console but even that keeps me occupied for hours on end. Love it.

author: cethompson
title: Irritated costumer
content: Received Wii in a very reasonable amount of time, in tact, I was very pleased with that until I opened up the box to find no attachment cables. Emailed seller, he sent then with no problem, I was fine with that. Wii appeared to be in very good condition, turned on fine, went to Wii fit plaza, but as soon as I tried to go any further it said an error occurred. Obviously this is a malfunction of the console because my disk never had problems in any other Wii. Needless to say, buying this Wii was a waste of $50!!

author: Mom246nunder
title: Fun for children! Graphics beyond lacking
content: If you have a PS3 and a plasma over 32" and appreciate HD you will be sickened by the Wii. The graphics are tragically horrid. The lack of response in the controllers compared to other gaming system is also not an appreciated attribute. That said, if you are considering this for your 5 year old or you really like to be active this is the system for you! The games that involve activity just don't exist outside the Wii in the same manner so for that fact alone it's worth the purchase if you want to move around. If you seek aesthetics and rapid response stick with XBox 360 or Playstation 3.

author: K. Kellie
title: Wii Disc Failure
content:
Bought the unit Christmas last year. Family has played it maybe 20-30 hours and now disc failure.
Ta Da! In to the shop for repairs. The cost is not outrageous just disappointed that for $500.00 bucks in unit and games
and accessories this is the disc life on this one.
I know it's an inexpensive console but we're not talking Xbox 360 either. Just a simple format player.
I'm just saying...

author: Amazon Customer
title: great condition, an excellent deal
content: Works perfectly, great condition, an excellent deal!

author: C.Elmore
title: Fun! Fun! Fun!
content: After waiting and searching forever, I finally found the Wii at my local Walmart last week and I grabbed it up. Needless to say, I'm very glad I did! The Wii is much more fun to play than our Xbox 360. The graphics aren't as good--doesn't matter though, I could care less! Even our 3 1/2 yr old son enjoys playing some of the games. Way to go Nintendo!! Fun for the whole family! Would definately buy this again!

author: DDS
title: Five Stars
content: Was a classic when I bought it

author: Melissa Mccauley
title: Keeps my daughter and husband busy for hours!!!
content: Love this product. Love that it is a video game that you have to get off the couch to play. My daughter will play it for hours.

author: Patricia A. Clark
title: Five Stars
content: Arrived as promised,

author: G. Martin
title: Wii...Love it!
content: The Wii really does get you off the couch, if that is what you want.  It was easy to set up and we have been having a blast with it.

author: Andrew Neath
title: Five Stars
content: Love Nintendo Wii.  Wii Sports can not be matched.  Played it all day with my family and friends.

author: oli
title: Not what I ordered!!!
content: Did not recieve the product I ordered, only the console was in the box. I made sure to check description first before writing this. The product shows a full console in box with cables, wii remote, sensor bar, and a game. All I received was a wii console in a brown box. Not happy as this was a gift for my family, and now I have to go and find a full system.

author: christine
title: The Wii works great!!
content: The delivery was so fast!!  The Wii works great!!

author: TDC
title: Super fun Nintendo Wii
content: I bought the Nintendo Wii for my 14 year old daughter for Christmas, thinking it wouldn't be that much different from other gaming systems we have purchased in the past.  Wrong, my daughter, my husband and I all have had so much fun playing the sports games on the Wii.  It is amazing how much one feels a part of the game, we even come away feeling sore, it is so realistic.  One of the most entertaining items we have come across in a long long time!!!

author: Bishoy Shehata
title: One Star
content: They promise me to send the rest of Wii equipment it's almost year now and nothing happens

author: n/a
title: Five Stars
content: Thank you so much!

author: Dawn Baird
title: Satisfied Customer
content: Wii's have always been my favorite gaming console. Very easy to use and it keeps u moving instead of sitting still like most of the other gaming consoles. Love it!!!

author: Olivia Frasier
title: Wii Rocks
content: I love the wii! netflix works awsome on it and I love to see my kids get up and play the games. It's simple to use and get used to and it is very compact! thanks nintendo for another awsome game!

author: BK
title: Wii is cool - lots of fun for the kids
content: Wii is cool - lots of fun for the kids.  Real video game enthusiasts that love the "newest" cutting-edge stuff may find it obsolete now, but it was cool while it lasted.  Nintendo has been around a long time and makes some great products.

author: Amazon Customer
title: Netflix use only
content: Wii seems to not be popular anymore. I don't really use mine to play games, I only have one game and I can't find any anymore anyway! But I still use it for Netflix. Purchased six years ago and it still works.

author: Mary Anna
title: Great fun, exercise
content: This is great entertainment  when you are stuck inside. Also provides some decent exercise. The only negative is the same music over and over.  Had to quit playing for a while, because the music drove me crazy.

author: Brian Caton
title: Five Stars
content: It was in great shape with all the things needed to hook it up as promised. Thanks again

author: MR
title: Price
content: Broken 2 year soo no good

author: Princess Pat
title: Wii!!  What Fun!
content: I've not been a big gamer through the years.  To put it into perspective, we had Pong, then an Intellevision game unit.  No X Box or PlayStation.  I love our Wii!  The sports disc that comes with it has some fun activities.  We spent about a week exploring the system before adding the Wii Fit Plus (reviewed separately). Wii Fit Plus with Balance Board With the option of so many games, this will keep us up and moving.

author: Pietro
title: Nintendo Wii: One of the best consoles ever!!!
content:
So, I recently bought a Nintendo Wii because I was looking for a console to have fun with, and it definitely did it!!
I totally recommend this console for children, teenagers and adults as well. You can bring good memories back by downloading old school games from the Virtual Console Channel, you can also play online and enjoy the good titles that have come out for it. The motion sensation is good enough and its price is totally good. I really like its design.... I've been a Nintendo fan since long ago and I can totally say that Nintendo's done again!!!

author: Tiffany R. Mckinley
title: Definitely worth it
content:
I am a big fan of the wii, I love the controls and the selection of games.  I considered a PS3 becuase I love my PS2, but I realized that I love the games I played on the PS2.  This is why I chose the wii, with games like Mario Galaxy and Wii Fit how can you go wrong?  I definitley recommend this even if you do not have a family, I am taking it over to a friends house this weekend to play Rayman Raving Rabbids and we are sure to have a ball.
Definitely not for hard core gamers, stick with the XBOX 360 or the PS3, those game titles are designed for you, the wii's game titles are definitely geared towards casual/platform gamers. A fun time is to be had by all when playing the Wii, give it a shot, like I said its worth the price.

author: John Wesley Hardin
title: a Promise is a Promise
content: I bought the Wii for my Brothers Thirteen Birthday  he was so happy thank you so much Amazon for sending  me the product ontime thats what made this gift so special and this product was not available anywere didnot no how popular the Wii was till i went to ten stores  you were the only company that had one and just in  good time got the last one you had nobody had it till  the end of may and i needed on april 22 i had one week to make it in time for his birthday thanks for great costumer service you are the best you save me because i made a promise that i would get him the Wii for his birthday thank you for helping me keep my promise. your costumer for life John Wesley Hardin.

author: C. Peterson
title: Great System
content:
When Nintendo announced that they were making a new Gaming Console, I freaked! I've always been a Nintendo FanBoy if I must say. When Nintendo released the WII, I felt that it would defintely remind me of the "Nintendo 64" and "Nintendo GameCube" however that was not the case.

As you can tell by my rating, I enjoyed the system, I just think Nintendo attempted to take the cheap way out and thought thay people wouldn't notice it. Fans allowed Nintendo to pass the GC off without a dvd player, but the Wii is missing several critical components, regardless of people having 5 to 6 DVD players around the house, which consist of Pc's, dvd players, Blu Ray, and etc, it's always better to give fans the most for the money.

Also the Controller gimmick got really tired, really quick. I sold my WII to gamestop and that was the end, I'll join back up with Nintendo next generation.

author: Mike
title: Awesome
content: It's a wii! How can anyone give this a bad review? Awesome product, awesome service but I bought this for my girlfriend at the time who is no longer my girlfriend. Great gift but buy it for yourself:)

author: Elaine Tsangaris
title: Great Fun for all ages!
content: Wii We got this for ourselves and have found this product easy to use as well as a lot of fun!  Bowling is our favorite because we find it competitive, but less strenuous than going to the bowling alley.  We like the variety of the games and the numerous choices that can be added.  It is great to be able to recreate ourselves in the form of a mii.  That is so cool!  We aren't seniors yet, but we are close and the wii gives us an opportunity to be active indoors, especially in the Chicago winter!

author: Lauren
title: Wii console broken/does not read game discs
content: After numerous attempts/troubleshooting, the Wii console will not read any wii games inserted. Seller notified, but will not allow return. Dissatisfied customer.

author: tae kwon-do black
title: Let's play.
content: It's been years since I bought my wii and I love it. I've only had to send it in once to nintendo, because it wouldn't turn on, but it's great. My main suggestion is to plug it into a power surged, which comes in real handy after blackout's when you can't get the wii back on.

author: Michael Pease
title: It makes weird noises and grinding sounds when running and ...
content: It makes weird noises and grinding sounds when running and has lines when playing games. Shipping was fast. It works and it will be OK... Just expected a little more

author: Amazon Customer
title: Great seller and perfect product
content: Product arrived in better condition than described. It works perfectly and I'm so happy. Thank you so much.

author: swohiom
title: Wii
content: Fun and easy to set up and play.  Good family fun, good fun with friends.  Plethora of games to choose from too!

author: Daniel Einstoss Korman
title: good enought
content: Working well, no strap in the remote control, missing the suport of the hardware

author: K
title: Two Stars
content: Stopped working after a few months.

author: Relentless
title: Why Wii beats them all!
content:
I was very fortunate to be able to get a Wii console @ my local electronics store. The decision to purchase a Wii over any of the two main competitors came down to these simple criteria:

* Price: Wii's sticker price is almost half of the low end PlayStation 3 and about $100 less than an xbox 360.

* Innovation: In that tiny box, Nintendo managed to pack impressive hardware (but only what was strictly needed to give an amazing game-playing experience). With a mind-blowing accurate motion sensor, ATI graphics card, an "off-the-shelf" IBM processor and even a wireless network adapter this little fellow has exactly what it needs and nothing it doesn't (no BlueRay Disc, for instance).

* Fun, fun, fun: Look at it whatever way you choose. We, in the universal sense, buy and play video games to have fun--period. Nintendo with this Wii and all it offers brought back the fun factor to the forefront. It does not matter if your console has a military-grade processor or 60Gb of data storage or a graphics card that can render a gazillion polygons per second...it matters not a little, tiny bit if it's not fun! Nintendo managed, with a reasonable price, to get everyone excited about the video game EXPERIENCE.

Both MS and Sony missed the boat and missed it badly. Way too much emphasis put on performance not enough on what matters most, having lots of fun. I see it like two car makers trying to make the biggest, meanest, most powerful SUV and then these little guys who many gave as being out of the map come up with this affordable, sexy, enticing and stimulating ride. All you have to do is play with one Wii for a few minutes (even the included games that, to some, might seem silly) and you'll fall in love with this machine in no time. I'm SO glad Nintendo was able to capture all what people really wanted in this gadget.

If you do not have one, please, please, please wait for it. Nintendo has said it will accelerate production to meet world-wide demand. After playing with this console for a little while I can almost guarantee that you and you family/friends will have a blast with it.

author: Kranthi P
title: Loved it
content: Kids love this product and have been using it to get the much required physical activity during cold weathers with games like just dance and baseball and cycling

author: Tera Leigh
title: Great tool for exercise, even if you aren't interested in gaming!
content:
I have played with the Wii at friend's house, but I decided to buy one after reading a review in a magazine for the purpose of exercise. I am 45 years old and not even slightly interested in gaming, but the options available for the Wii for exercise are terrific.

I purchased the Wii unit with Wii Sports, and have since purchased another exercise "game" and a dance "game" for Wii. I love to hike, walk, get out on the water on a kayak, swim, etc. but the weather, and my schedule, do not always cooperate. The Wii programs allow me to get in a good workout that also engages my mind. When it comes to exercise, I tend to like to do things outside because I have zero patience for repetition. I can't stand DVD's after I've watched it twice, and going to the gym bores me to tears. The nice thing about the Wii programs is that you can choose what you want to do and mix up your workout each time. Some days I concentrate on my legs, others upper body, etc. It is fully customizable.

Because much of the audio is repetitious, after I've learned the "game", I usually turn off the audio and put on my own music.

Many of my friends thing of game systems as the old "sit on the couch and point a joystick at the TV" version. The Wii is nothing like that - it is fully interactive and responds to your movement. You can purchase add on tools like the balance board, dance pad, etc. that add to the difficulty and challenge of the program.

I am not likely to ever purchase a traditional war or sports game for my Wii, unless I did it for friend's kids to play with when visiting. I consider the Wii a great investment for a reasonable price as an engaging, and fun, alternative to my traditional work out. I don't think it will ever replace hiking, swimming, etc. for me, but for the days when my schedule or the weather keep me from getting out, the Wii gives me the ability to get a fast, fun work out at home.

author: Adam-Won Kenobi
title: I love it!
content: As a Nintendo fan I was really looking forward to the "Revolution", but was really skeptical of the new controller concept and minimal enhancements to the graphics over the Gamecube.  Initially I was looking to buy the PS3, but after I saw the price tag and heard all of the great things about the Wii, I knew I had to get one.  My birthday was yesterday and was hoping to get a Wii, but was not holding my breath especially since my wife expressed no interest in getting it.  But I got it a day early and my family and I love it, even my wife.  As for those gamers who scream "graphics", I feel they are only part of the equation and a small part at that.  Game-play for me is number one and Nintendo really hit the nail on the head!  I love it and wouldn't trade it for anything.

author: Jesse
title: Wii
content: We've been delighted with the Wii! It shipped promptly was easy to set up and we've been loving the family playing the games. Thanks so much :)

author: B. Piper
title: Family fun for all ages
content: The marketing for Wii is 100% correct.  Our recently purchased console has been played by people 2 to 72 and all have had a blast.  Wii Sports and Play are great for the casual gamer than only has 10 minutes to spare.  The graphics may not be state of the art like some of the new next-gen consoles, by Twilight Princess looks pretty good even on an old CRT.  The ability to view photos and surf the web are nice features too.  The only con is that you get sore muscles instead of just a little blister on your thumb.

author: Amazon Customer
title: I never thought I would own a Nintendo
content:
I never thought I would own a Nintendo but now I have two - the DS and the Wii.  The Wii is true to it's development name "revolution".  I am looking forward to more games, the included Wii sports are a fantastic hint at what is to come for the Wii.  There is so much clever polish in the whole system, such as using other Mii characters in the games, and having a player's favorite color show up regularly in game elements.

My Kids took to the system right away and I have even got my wife playing Tennis.

The features beyond the games are show a lot of promise too.  The "channels" available so far - news and weather and the Web browser in beta are a nice feature, I hope there are more to come.

My only disapointment is that Wii does not Play DVDs and they did not build in an Ethernet port but instead sell it as a $25.00 US accessory.

Amazing product.

author: Cliente de Amazon
title: EXCELLENT
content: Excellent

author: DKIM
title: Hi Jerry, It no longer works and we haven't ...
content:
Hi Jerry,

It no longer works and we haven't done anything to it in particular. It won't read discs no matter how many times we clean it. Disappointing  Thanks, Deb

author: David
title: Favorite Wii console for DDR fans
content:
It's not easy to find the old version of Wii console which is still in good condition nowadays. It's especially designed with 4 gamecube ports on the left side. If you want to play the DDR games with a dance mat, the Wii console must have the gamecube ports. Many people bought the dance mat but they didn't know that the new version of Wii console does not support the gamecube ports anymore.
However, the disadvantage of the old version is it does not support Wii motion plus. Therefore, some new games which require motion plus feature cannot be played on it.

author: S. Matte
title: This is great!
content: We finally bought the Wii and now I am not sure why I was fighting it.  It gets you off the couch and you can have some fun family time moving around and not glued to a TV show.

author: Cody Cunningham
title: Sent me a pretty disgusting Wii
content: They shipped me a wii in a gigantic zip loc bag that was quite obviously owned by a smoker, the thing is a weird yellow hue.  Other than that, it modded and loaded Melee 20xx perfectly and I was able to clean up the case pretty good.  If I wasn't desperate for some melee I definitely would have returned it.

author: Tricia
title: Great product
content: I was really pleased at first I couldn't get it to work so I had to go on line and find out more info. But was able to finally figure it out. And now I love it. It works great. Would recommend this product to anyone. Seller was very fast with shipping.

author: Chad R. Stewart
title: Great console, wii + gamecube + virtual console
content: Great console, with the ability to play gamecube and wii games, as well as download virtual console games the game library is enormous. Always something different to play

author: Isa
title: Great System
content: The ability to play all gamecube games and newer wii game makes this console excellent to have in one's collection. Personal favorites to play on this system are any Mario Party games!

author: FurFur
title: Super Great item!!!
content:
We have thoroughly enjoyed our Wii.  Having it for almost 3 years now our family has played many games on it; from Mario, to Wii Fit!  It has been worth the initial cost plus some.

The only downside is the small little add-ons that you have to purchase for certain games.

author: K. Shaw
title: Disguised exercise!
content: The games on the Wii are so much fun that you don't realize your muscles are working hard (until the next day!)  I have had so many friends comment great reviews on the Wii.  Would definately recommend!!!  Definately try the Wii fit plus game.

author: J. Pohlman
title: Best thing since sliced bread.
content: I love my Wii.  I use it for working out and playing games.  My 6 year old daughter loves to play games with it.  Everyone who plays it wants one of their own.  What a great way to stay active and play video games.  It is so much easier to get up and work out when I feel like I am actually getting up to play video games.

author: Robyn L. Tatham
title: More fun than I ever expected!
content: My husband and I love the Wii!  We have spent many hours playing and improving our skills.  You won't be disappointed!  An added benefit has been being able to downstream movies from Netflix.  We had no idea we would be able to do this!

author: Marilyn in Chicago
title: fun for all ages
content:
we needed some activity that could include young people and seniors well over 80!  this was it... active, perfect level of activity for all ages after big holiday dinners.
AND easy to set us and use!  pefect.  Also this came in great shape, as well as quickly from the amazon warehouse--refurbished, dented box, whatever.  it was perfect to use.

author: Francine Roberts
title: Defective product
content: This product was defective so I had to return it.  I was very disappointed because I had bought Zumba Fitness to be used with the Wii.

author: Sun-T
title: Wii is Family Fun For All
content: We ordered the Wii as a Christmas gift to the family and have loved it. We bowl together, golf together and making the players resemble our family members is so clever!

author: A. Gay
title: The Best and EASIEST to operate gaming system ever.
content: The Nintendo Wii is the best gaming system ever made. It is everything a system should be: A) Fun to play. B) Easy to use. Firstly, I have played almost every single game released for the Wii so far. Whether it is the 50+ hours on Zelda, or 4 player gaming with my younger brothers on Mario Party I have done it all. The system easily and perfectly accomodates everything I could ever ask for from a  gaming system and is totally fun at the same time. Secondly, I have run my Wii through almost every function it has. I've connected to the internet and downloaded games and used the Weather Channel, I've plugged in my Memory Card and used the Photo Channel, I've even wasted time creating countless Mii's and you know something? Everything works quickly and easily. There is none of this freezing and breaking involved in the Xbox 360, and none of the complicated software associated with the PS3! This is the perfect video game system and everyone should buy one.

author: M. Robinson
title: Fun way to exercise
content: Wii Fit plus on the Wii system is a fun way for an oldster like me to exercise and keep active.  I've lost 30 lbs. Wii-ing daily and watching my diet. So I bought this for my son and his wife for Christmas.

author: Jessika
title: good
content: Was in great condition and works well. I love it.

author: Shelly
title: Wii is great for the family
content: I made a last minute decision to give my children a Wii for Christmas. I got lucky by using Wii alerts to notify me when one became available and I snapped it up right away. Now I say I got this for the children, but my husband and I have had just as much fun playing the games. What is really unique is that you get up OFF the couch, talk to eachother and interact. I see now what all the buzz is about.

author: Daniel Kays
title: Playing the Wii at 56 years old
content:
Great way to keep active during the long cold days of winter.  My wife and I play 4 or 5 nights a week.
Any advice on what other games to buy?

author: Dolores Jojola
title: works fine.
content: Bought it for Netflix only, works fine.

author: Kindle Customer
title: Doesn't eet the hype -- But doesn't disappoint either
content:
The Wii is nintendo's most recent addision to the console market, and as such it carries a lot of expectations on its shoulders.  Nintendo has been making games for over thirty years now, and they have a legacy second to none.  As such, any product they produce must be of the highest quality, if only to live up to the hype.

The wii is a mixed bag, and only partially lives up to the positive press.

Construction wise the machine is fantastic.  I've dropped mine, knocked it over, kicked it, gotten it wet and it still works like the day I got it.  The controllers are of a similar build quality; I have abused them in a similar manner, even having a friend mistakenly throw one against the wall, and they are fine.

Beyond the construction, the Wii can be great.  Can being the optimal word.  The system definitely appeals, but to a different market then games of the last generation marketed to.  By this I mean that if you are a "hardcore" gamer, who revels in endless hours on the latest and greatest first person shooter (FPS), this isn't really for you.  Why do I say this?  Simple.  The games on the Wii aren't of this nature.

Most/all of the games are targeted at a much more casual group of gamers.  For Nintendo this is probably a great move, as this "casual" market is larger then the "hardcore" market, but for many of us diehard fans might consider this a bit of a let down, and if you are reading this you probably take your games seriously enough that you will want something more.  In the next few sections I'll break the Wii down a bit, so you understand exactly what you are getting if you buy it.

When you buy a Wii you get the wii itself, a Wiimote (wireless controller) and a copy of Wii Sports.  Technically there are two things that make the Wii different then the other consoles of the same generation.  First, and most importantly, it uses a non-traditional control mechanism called "Wii Motion."  This is a combination of infared sensors and accelerometers which allow you to "interact" with your games naturally.  An example is the Baseball game in Wii sports, which allows you to swing your bat by swinging the Wiimote in a swing-like motion, and causes your avatar on screen to swing his bat in the same manner.  This "Wii Motion" functionality is not used in every game, but it plays prominent in many; Wii specific games will doubtlessly involve some use of these mechanics, be it pointing at the screen as if you had a mouse, or shaking the Wiimote to spin Mario in a circle.  When not using such functionality the Wii controller can be used like a normal, albeit uncomfortable, controller by holding it sideways and using the traditional control pad grafted to one end.  Other games involve a secondary attachment to the Wiimote called the "nunchuck" which connects to the Wiimote by way of a small cord.  This also has some "Wiimotion" capabilities, but mostly is there for the extra buttons and a small thumb joystick.  I'd say that almost all the games I've played on the Wii, beyond the Wii Sports/Fit have involved this Nunchuck to a large extent, and if you are going to be playing a lot of games on your

Wii you will have to buy one (does not come with the Wii).

My commentary on the Wii Motion and control scheme is this.  It isn't great.  It's a gimick.  The controllers just don't allow fine enough control for most games, and they aren't really easy to use either.  Games involving Wii Motion features are mostly spent trying to figure out exactly what motion the Wii wants and then doing your best to repeat it.  This can be fun, but it isn't intuitive, and for most games it is just a pain in a neck.  Doubtlessly this is the reason many games on the Wii, including the latest Mario installation (Mario Galaxy), have almost no Wii Motion elements, and simply use the normal controller features of the Wiimote and nunchuck.  These "normal" features are fine.  The Wiimote-nunchuck combination is suprisingly comfortable in your hands, and control is excellent.  However, by the time you have bought both items you have basically paid $60 for one controller.  So, if you wanted the full 4 controllers you have paid: $200 for the full set.  This is compared to the $150 for 3 PS3 (or Xbox 360) controllers.  The Wii's controllers also lack a "charge while you play" feature.  This causes you to buy chargable batteries, or to buy lots of replacements, and the controllers do eat batteries.  Overall, I'd give the Wii's controls a mediocre rating at best.  I'd have much rather had a traditional wireless controller with good battery life, and a "charge while you play" feature.

Now, to give a holistic overview, we must address the Wii's software.  The Wii itself has great software.  The interface is intuitive and unobtrusive.  Updates happen very seemlessly and painlessly through the wifi, and configuration and setup is a breeze.  No one should ever complain about the Wii's interface, especially compared to the obnoxious layered menu system of the xbox 360, or the large tree of options presented by the ps3.  However, the system's interface isn't what usually interests users, so much as the games themselves.

The Wii's games...  Before I continue I want to make a small point about the Wii.  It is a hardware concern that I didn't mention above, but it really effects the games produced.  This concern is the fact that Wii is not much of a performance increase over the gamecube.  The result are graphics that are not as visually stunning and those found on the PS3 or Xbox 360.  Also of note is that the Wii does not provide true HD video, but merely some upscaled 480p.  These combined attributes are definitely a major factor in the sad truth about Wii games, which is that they are not cutting edge installments with the best graphics and the hottest gameplay.  Every game I've played for Wii has been one of a few

categories.  1) Gimicky use of the Wii Motion.  2) A Nintendo produced rehashing of one of their key franchises (Mario, Zelda).  3) A port from another console.

I'll expand on this categories with examples:
1) examples: Wii Sports, Wii Fit, Wii Sports Resort
  These consist of a bunch of mini games centered around use of the Wii Motion Capabilities.  Fun, but mostly just a gimicky display of a neat technology.  These are the most fun to play with others.  So I'd consider them a "party" game.
2) examples: Mario Galaxy, Mario Kart Wii, Zelda Twilight Princess
