content:
This is a great game system. I play the included wii sports with family and friends. Its a great way to spend family time when I'm 18 and don't really want to. Wii gives the family a chance to stay in and play some games and have some family fun.

Great System

author: T. Stoddard
title: Love My Wii
content: I love my Wii.  I wasn't sure if I wanted a Wii, now that I have one I don't know how I lived without it.  I play with my Wii all of the time.  Especially when my wife is not home.  When I am at work I think about my Wii.  When I am at home I can't keep my hands off of my Wii.  If my kids touch it I say hey get your hands off my Wii.  That is not appropriate, you are too young to touch my Wii.  Anyway I wasn't sure if the control would be hard to get used to, however once I got started it was as natural feeling as if it was a body part that I have always had but did not realize the potential to play with.

author: santiago carreño
title: Four Stars
content: GOOD

author: Casper_Knightshade
title: WEEEEEEE! I mean 'Wii', but importantly it's F-U-N!
content:
I waited. I waited several months after the Nintendo Wii came out to buy it, and after one year of using it I am ready to write my review on this product. There is more than one reason to buy the Nintendo Wii: the most important reason is the fun factor.

You may have heard that this is only a gimmick system, like the ill-conceived Virtual Boy and (I dare say it) PlayStation 3, because of Wii-remote controllers used to move the action in the game by actually moving the controllers. Such an idea, critics have said, is to cover up the flaws of the system and the product line, the lack of graphics compared to an X-Box360 and the number of games compared to the PlayStation line. What I have found since my days of video gaming began with PONG and actually having to pay to play 'Donkey Kong' that pretty, tight, and sexy graphics mean absolutely nothing in terms of replay value: the pretty colors and characters are there to cover up the flaws.

I admit the Nintendo Wii, with its base game 'Wii Sports', is not graphics pretty, but Nintendo once again focuses on that 'F-U-N' factor of game play with system ownership: a concept lost on its rivals. With the Wii Remote Controller you have incredible interactivity: use it as a pointer to select your options on the Wii Menu to using it achieve goals in the games you play. The motion sensing of the remote can be adjusted to create either a loose or tight response with little lag. Be it selecting a button, or having to perform a swinging motion to swing the 'Wii Sports' batter in baseball or in tennis or in golf, or jab it forward in boxing, or underhand throwing in my favorite bowling, the Wii Remote just about perfects the remote video controller concept. Sure, again, the graphics of the in-game is not great, but after a year I'm still playing them. Again, it's all about FUN! And once again, Nintendo also emphasizes the group 'all there in the living room' factor as opposed to the recent trend of playing someone else somewhere else.

Although the Wii does allow you to play with or against others around the world via a high speed internet connection it's not the only thing it can do. The Wii Network allows you access News, Weather, and a Nintendo Game Shop where you can download the classic Nintendo Games all the way back to the NES. Although you can't use the Wii Remote on these games the hard link controllers are cheap to get. Plus for Nintendo Game Cube owners don't toss your GCN stuff away: the Wii plays Game Cube games, uses the memory cards and the controllers.

Since the year and the half the system has been out, innovation is finding its way to the system, as well as the games. The Nintendo Wii is not a gimmick: it's an honest game system that is cheap, doesn't demand that you buy it for it's DVD or BluRay capability, and once again F-U-N!!!!! to have.

author: Me
title: Love my Wii!
content:
When I first decided to get a system, I looked into the other gaming systems and the Wii seemed to fit me better.  I'm not a big 'gamer' so I didn't think I would really take advantage of the other systems.  The Wii sounded great because of all the family games that can be played.  After having the Wii for several months, I can happily say, it was the perfect choice.

I was able to get the Wii when Amazon had an open box unit available.  For folks trying to get one, I was looking every day for several weeks.  I didn't spend huge amounts of time on it, but whenever I remembered, I would check out different online stores and I finally lucked out on Amazon!

If you don't know yet what gaming system to get, what really helped me was to take a look at the games available for each system and see which I thought I would actually play.  Also, I went to the electronics section at my local Target and tested out the systems there.  I've seen people playing the systems at Walmart, too.  I'm sure all the stores that sell these gaming systems have them out so people can try them.  Anyway, all the systems seem very well made but the Wii was easier for me to play and seemed like a fun family system.

And what makes the Wii even sweeter, is the great Christmas gift I got!  Rockband with a wireless guitar.  Sooooooo much fun!

author: Ari S

Why on earth would anyone buy anything else in terms of a system? The point is, Wii gets you off the couch and requires you to socialize! This system is for multiple people! And it's fun!

You are not wasting away exercising your fingers here. You are actually up and jumping around, it's incredibly fun to play wii tennis with a friend. This is a very social system, and is really what video games have been missing. Between playing a long, solitary game that requires me to expend no energy, and playing the wii which is unbelievable work of accomplishent on nintendo's part.

I think the graphics are fantastic from what I've seen, and most importantly, everyone -- even people who don't like video games -- loves to play it.

author: P. Hartman
title: Wii is the Greatest
content: I bought the Wii to get in shape and do something physical. Living in colder weather where it snows and is very cold outside makes it difficult to get in daily walking. I have found the Wii gives me plenty of exercise and it is fun! I would recommend a Wii to everyone. In fact, I encouraged my sister to purchase a Wii and now we meet once a week to do our yoga together. Wii is a system that is easy to put together and easy to use. No, it does not have all the special graphics that today's computer games have, but it is perfect for any age that just wants to move. When I can't go outside I can run, walk, bowl, play games, and keep busy all day in my house.

author: Phil
title: Wow... I am... STUNNED
content:
I figured there's so many people writing BS reviews I'd throw a real review up.  I picked mine up at Wal-Mart, and I'm JUST reviewing the system + Wii Sports (haven't played the other games).

What can I say.... this is.. GREAT.

"But you only gave it 4 Stars!", you may be saying (or maybe not).

Well, yeah, I did.  There are some issues, particularly with the Wiimote... it seems a little... touchy.  And this MAY be user error, or may require another firmware update.  Honestly, if I could, I'd give it **** 1/2 or **** 3/4.  But without playing any other games, I can't give just the console itself a solid ***** rating... yet. :-)

One thing I can say regarding the Wiimote and Sensor bar: Experiment.  Find what works.  I may still have some more playing to do before I can get it just right.

Another minor letdown is the UI.  I consider myself fairly intuitive with user interfaces, and there were a few spots that had me scratching my head.  Nothing major, but I'd like to see this cleaned up in a later release of the firmware.

The console itself is physically stunning... I'm serious.  This machine is a beautiful, elegant example of engineering.  The Wiimote and Nunchuck are virtually weightless.  I barely felt they were there.  The console itself is beautiful.  Much better looking than the PS3.

As I said, the only game I've played so far is Wii Sports... it's the perfect pack in for the Wii.  The only word to describe this game is "FUN!"  I've played through all the games, and the Tennis and boxing games are my favorites.  Bowling's kinda lame, and golf is okay.  Baseball is fun too.  Overall, a great package.  I know they say you can sit on the couch and make small movements, but... no... GET UP AND MOVE! :-)

Overall, I'm happy with my purchase, and I highly recommend picking one up.  I've also got Zelda, Rayman, Trauma Center, and Super Monkey Ball to go through, and I will review those as well.

author: Grandpa

Shipping container was unmarked as far as having any damage and items are in perfect condition, very suitable for a Chrismas gift. Highly desired by both young and old.

author: Yellow Bird

author: Sweeney Fry

content: The Wii is my favorite system. I've had one for 7 years and only had to replace it once. I love playing it with my family.

author: bookitty
title: It's not just the console you're buying...
content:
I got my Wii for Christmas, and it's awesome!

However, when you start trying to get stuff for it, you think you have it all and then you find out you need more stuff.

For instance, you can play Gamecube games on a Wii console, but no one ever says you need a Gamecube memory card to play them as well.

Or, Wii fit, which is a steal at $19.99, but requires a $96.00 balance board to play.

Or, you don't have a wireless router, or wireless service, and the Wii only has Wi-Fi capability unless you know that there is an adapter that can make it able to be physically wired to the internet. Which you will never find out about that unless you think of it. Then when you do think of it, there is a question of the type of Ethernet cable you need and how long the cable needs to be. (Which the cable type is category 5.)

Basically, I love my Wii system, I wouldn't trade it for the world, but if you're going to buy one, realize that it's not just a console and couple games you're buying. You have to buy a lot more than you think. There's additional wii-motes, nunchucks, boards, plugs, adapters, and lots more that you may not think you need, but are vital to the running of the gaming programs on the Wii.

So to people new to the Wii gaming system, be sure to do your research and find out whether or not you are willing to make the various and costly investments.

author: W. Zacharias
title: Amazing System
content:
I haven't owned a game system since the original NES years ago.  My reason for not getting any new systems is that the controls have gotten too confusing and difficult to use.  Now with the Wii they have made the controls simple again.  I must say that I was surprised how well the controls worked as I didn't think they would respond so well.  This console has turned out to be a lot of fun for me and my family.

Here are the games that we have been playing:

Wii sports - really shows you what the new controller scheme can do and give you a workout in the process.

Zelda: Twilight Princess - I have always avoided games like this because the controls have been a pain to master (which was shown my my frequent deaths during the course of the game which made me give up).  However, the Wii controller finally makes this possible for any average joe to play.  It is the longest that I have ever played any sort of adventure game this this in my life and that is saying something.  The story is interesting and can take up hours of your life without you even realizing it.

Rayman Raving Rabbids:  If you want a fun game that is a challenge but will make you laugh as its silliness than this is the game for you.  It makes full use to the new controller and will make you laugh each time one of the bunnies comes running at you screaming.  Oh, and having bunny backup dancers is a good time too.

This system is by far the best system that has been released in years.  It is by far the most fun I have had playing video games since the late 80s.  Wii is worth your time and money.

author: captain_comrade
title: Wii? What happened to the Nintendo Revolution?!
content:
Out of all the consoles released during this last generation, Nintendo’s Wii was the hardest for me to warm up to. Nintendo’s apparent lack of interest for the core gaming crowd in favor of casual gamers was already in full force by the time I finally received this console as a gift around 2009. By that time, I had already gotten over the cheap gimmicks Nintendo was pumping into the market and ready to move onto what I thought was bigger and better things. It didn’t help that the Wii library seemed like it was filled with nothing but cheap shovel ware, or tired first party titles like Mario and Zelda that never go down in price. I decided that most of the games weren’t worth my time and saved up my money for a PS3 instead. Now that it's the Wii U’s time to shine, I had a renewed interest to go back and play some games that I missed out on. After going back and playing the Wii for the last three months, I have to say, that it was really wrong of me to dismiss the console like I did. In this amount of time, I was having more fun on the Wii that I was having on my PS3 during the first year that I owned it. The Wii really is a great game console because there are games that everyone can enjoy, regardless if you are a self-proclaimed hardcore or casual gamer.

One of the best things about the Wii is its bargain price. With the PS3 and 360 costing somewhere around $300 dollars, the Wii’s price is definitely an advantage amongst its competition. Unfortunately the price starts to speak for itself, because the Wii looks and feels cheaply made. The console itself feels very thin and the white outside of the console feels like cheap plastic. It doesn’t look or feel very sturdy at all, especially without it’s little gray stand. There are little flaps on top of the console for gamecube controllers and memory card to go in, but the damn things are so delicate and cheap that they are easy to unhinge and fall off. Also the white color of the console can get very dirty and scuffed up very easily, especially around little kids. Just holding the console feels like it’s really flimsy. However, despite it’s initial appearance, the Wii is actually made really well. I have dropped it on a few occasions by accident and even though it’s outward appearance is nothing special, the inside of the console is very reliable. I’ve rarely had problems with the Wii in terms of freezing, crashing, or being stuck in menus. Even when the rare occasion that this does happen, it’s very easy to reset the Wii and run everything again like normal. Given the amount of dust that was on the machine and how much I’ve neglected it, the console runs really well from all the abuse I’ve put it through. To put it in comparison, I’ve had to go through two Gamecubes in the same amount of time I've had my Wii. Nintendo was a lot smarter about designing this console and I've never had any disk reading errors unlike the gamecube.

Nintendo’s consoles have never been known to boast any special features. When you buy a Nintendo console, you get it for games and nothing else. This straightforward policy is obviously there to avoid making the console more expensive for consumers. It makes sense, because I can’t see how sticking on a DVD player would be that big of a selling point, especially when Blu Ray was already the standard on the market. Nintendo did manage to add a little more this time around, by having separate channels open for access on the Wii’s main menu. These channels are pretty much pointless I really can’t see the point of using them maybe once or twice to see what they do and then never using them again. The only one that can be fun is the Mii channel in which you can create a kind of avatar based on your appearance. It can be a cute little distraction to make models of your family but it's nothing special.The most useful option is the Nintendo store, which operates like almost any other PSN or Xbox store, where you can download games and some add ons for money. Also by some grace of God, Nintendo was smart enough make the Wii Netflix compatible, which is a great decision as far as I’m concerned.

It’s easy to see that the Wii isn’t going to wow anybody in terms of graphical power and performance. Even when it was out,  its design and options were very dated and made to appeal to people who don’t really play video games. There aren't a lot of social options, online play is almost non existent, and there isn't much room for customization or things to do when not playing games. Nintendo’s stubbornness to venture into online territory really held back the Wii and there are a number of games available that would have benefited from actual online play. Most of the games with online options are so limited, that they really aren't worth playing more than a few times.

Putting aside online issues, the Wii has what matter most. It's expansive library of games. I really mean it when I say there are some awesome titles on the system that no one has heard of and very fun to play. It’s a shame that so many hardcore gamers disregarded the Wii so quickly, because there are a lot more games on here than they give it credit for. Games like No More Heroes, Metroid Prime 3, Red Steel 2, Madworld, Silent Hill: Shattered Memories, Donkey Kong Country Returns, Excitebots, Trauma Center, Kirby’s Epic Yarn, Super Mario Galaxy, and Xenoblade are more recognizable and are easily some of the best games I’ve played last gen. I got more value and more fun playing some of these games than I did shelling out top dollars for PS3 exclusives.  Where the Wii really shines though, is other lesser known gems like Boom Blox, Cursed Mountain, Sin and Punishment 2, Tatsunoko vs. Capcom, Bully, Ghost Squad, De Blob, House of the Dead Overkill, Sonic Colors, Lost in Shadow, Klonoa, Muramasa, Metal Slug Anthology. The list goes on and I still left out quite a few games. All these games are easily worth your time and money and should be played by anyone who has even the slightest interest in video games. What makes these games special, is that many of these games are actually very unique. I've yet to play anything like De Blob or Lost in Shadow on the PS3 or have played any RPG that has gotten close to being as good as Xenoblade. Tatsunoko vs Capcom is leagues better than MvC3, No More Heroes is refreshingly cool, Sin and Punishment 2 has hardcore shooting action, and Donkey Kong Country Returns is one of the best 2D platforms I've played since the Super Nintendo era.

Wii’s motions controls work just as well as you would expect, if not better in some cases.  I’ve never ever had problems with it not reading movement or misinterpreting my gestures for almost all the games I’ve played so far. There are some later games released that utilize a Wii Motion Plus add on to allow for even more precise movement. With that said, the problem with these controls lies with how the game developers make you use them. As time has shown, many developers have had a middling affair with motion controls, but nothing serious has come out of it. There a lot games out there that definitely benefit from the control scheme and then there are others where it feels completely shoe horned in, making a would be enjoyable game more difficult than necessary.  These games are usually far and few between, and all the games I’ve played have only benefited by being on the Wii remote and nunchuck.

The Wii is definitely worth owning either as a complimentary system to a PS3 of 360. I wouldn't really recommend it as your only console, because even though I had a middling experience with most HD era games, there are some games that shouldn't be missed if you only own a Wii. That said there are a lot of games worthy of your attention, regardless if you are a hardcore Sony fanboy or Microsoft fan. If you somehow don't have a Wii yet, I can safely say that you won’t regret your purchase. The overall dated policies and hardware designs may be a turn off in the beginning, but you’ll ultimately stay for the Wii’s variety unique games and gameplay that you won't find anywhere else.

author: Manish Thakore
title: Video games - one handed !
content:
The Wii is amazing for most people and simply wonderful for everybody else. I used to play video games ages ago. Now with Wii most of the games provided by default (Wii Sports) can be played with only one hand and a little flick of the wrist.. there are plenty more such games.
I brought the Wii to my office once and after just one session the team decided to get a team Wii for use in office (after hours of course :)

cheers :)

author: SQ

My son and I both love the game so much we are using it every day. The only downside to Wii is that the better games cost quite a bit more than I would like...

author: a nony mouse
title: Revolution
content:
I stood in line at our not-so-local (next town over) Wal-Mart for ten hours for my Wii.

Ten hours very, very well spent.

The Wii is awesomely fun, innovative, and affordable. The graphics aren't as good as the competition's, but the entertainment value makes up for it.

The Wii is fun for everyone, even my mom (who is a total non-gamer) plays Wii Sports with me. There's something about the Wii that everybody can enjoy.

I highly recommend the Wii for gamers who care about the quality and fun of the games, not just the graphics.

The Super Nintendo Entertainment System was the greatest console ever made, and I think that the Wii is going to be the next Super Nintendo.

(Please note that I am not a "fangirl", as I just ordered a 360 yesterday.)

author: Whitney
title: Few years later
content: This is a late review but my product still works perfectly

author: ChuckF - RochNY
title: I love this system.
content:
I'm an avid video gamer and have been playing video games since Pong was released.  I'm always looking for a new fun twist on video games and the Wii fits the bill.
It comes packaged with Wii Sports and just playing through each of those has provided hundreds of hours of fun for me and the family.  The motion sensitivity adds a new element of fun and interactivity which almost compels you to get off your butt and move around while playing. ;)  There are also a host of other games available now that take advantage of the motion sensitivity.  They span multiple game categories from typical platforming games to sports and even party games so I'm sure there's something for everyone to enjoy.
It was also easy to set-up and upgrade through my 128-bit WEP enabled wireless network.  There are cool free software downloads available on the Wii Shop too.  The weather channel-like program is pretty cool and has helped provide quick and accurate weather planning for the day.  The Everybody Votes channel is fun and somewhat enlightening on the opinions of Wii owners in the US and around the world.  This channel also provides a challenge element where you can guess which result will get more votes and tracks how many you've predicted correctly along with a crude breakdown of you personality, based on the answers you've given.  There is a free web browser channel as well.  It's not great but still useful for checking sites while the computer is tied-up by someone else.
I could go on and on which you have no doubt found boring already but I'll just sum it up by saying that even if you don't like video games, I think you'll have fun with the Wii.  It gets you up and moving and has something for everyone in the family to enjoy.

author: Costa Rodis
title: Tons of Fun
content:
It's enough to say that the kids can't get enough of it and that adults are quickly pulled in, too. Although the controllers can be a bit wonky form time to time, requiring resynchronization with the base unit, that hasn't stopped the show at any time.

Is it more fun than other consoles? Yeah, without a doubt. And that's almost entirely due to the controllers. When you replicate real-world movements to activities on the screen, you really get immersed in any game. And that's hard to beat.

The virtual boy had a good couple of games that still play through emulation. Nothing on this console is worth revisiting. It also feeds into the idea that tells moms that violent games turn people into a murder as well as a fat jobless hog. Even when I modded my Wii it was boring. Worst console nintendo ever made except the Wii U so far which is just a last gen shovelware console that plays crappy wii games. 3DS is great though. Nintendo sucks now with the exception of the 3DS.

author: KathyQ

Great fun interactive games that arent your typical shoot em up that your so used to. I would say its a great system to compliment either a PS3 or a 360 and you could definitly justify owning both.

author: Kelly Westbrook
title: Great for family night

We all like playing the sports games and we are enjoying the workout as well.  I think the Wii is one of the best things invented.  We have come a long way since Pong and Spaced Invaders.  Very glad that Nintendo decided to knock the price down.

author: Davvalco

author: Amazon Customer

author: Amazon Customer

content: This was advertised as "Like New," but arrived with lots of scratches on the outside of the console. So far it's functioning well.

author: Melvona Thompson
title: Great Product
content: This product was purchased for my 15 year old daughter. She plays it everyday and loves it! It has helped us bond.

author: K. Robinson

content: Bought it for my nephew in Europe and was surprised to discover that the adapter cannot handle 220V so I then bought "Wii Universial AC Adapter for US / UK / Europe / Australia", and that worked fine.

author: Tom Terrific
title: Wii Sports Package
content: The Wii purchased from Amazon came with the Wii console, Wii remote with clear rubber case, Wii Nunchuk, Sports gaming software, instruction booklet and the composite and other cables to get you connected.  Batteries are also included. This is the real deal and one fun way to get started with your Wii.  Fun for everyone right out of the box, nothing else to purchase and no additional cables necessary, unless you have a DVD or VCR (video cassette recorder for those who forgot) connected to the composite plugs in your TV set.  But still a simple unplug, plug in deal.  Definitely a 5-star item!

author: Robert L. Driver
title: Works like a charm
content: Exactly as posted.  Works like a charm!

author: M. V. Fumero
title: The Best System
content:
I say that cuz its the most innovative and to some extent, the most fun.
You cant play multiplayer with the same way as the Wii. Making it a party favorite.
The Wii takes gaming to the next level with the infamous Wiimotes. Its amazingly fun and everyone will want to play.
I say that this is my favorite system and the best system overall. Xbox360 has the slightly better graphics, PS3 has the overall better games, Wii has the fun and different factor of playing with a whole bunch of friends.
Wii wins.

author: Anonymous
title: Great gaming system for all
content:
Our family has had a PS2 for many years.  This Christmas the kids wanted a WII.  It's a great alternative to the PS/2.  Sure the graphics are lousy and the platform is not made for realistic graphic intensive games, but the interaction is fun for everyone.

Pros: LOTS of fun for everyone

Cons: Only contains one remote

author: Amazon Forever
title: Five Stars
content: Love it Great Price

author: N. Estep
title: Pretty Good, Could Use Larger Game Library
content:
I finally got a Wii for Christmas this year and overall have been very pleased. Everything worked like it was supposed to and the WiiSports game is very cool. I like that the Wii comes with WiiSports. It's a short set of sports games that give you a very good feel of the capabilities of the system, particularly the remote. It also gives you something to do out of the box without having to buy anything else. Granted, you'll want to get other games.

I have never been a "gamer" and I am also a college student. I have no problems with the graphics, but then again, my TV probably isn't good enough to make XBox 360 or PS3 graphics look any better. It is true the Wii has a larger target audience than the XBox 360 or the PS3, which is probably why it has sold so many. You will see people griping about the graphics. They would rather have a button and joystick controller in there hand and be able to see a fly from 300 yards. In my opinion they don't like the Wii for valid reasons, but they are reasons that other people don't need to have shoved down their throats.

I am disappointed that it doesn't play DVDs. I don't need it to, I have a home theater system, but it just seems like it should play DVDs. I also wouldn't expect it to play Blu-Ray discs becasue frankly Blu-Ray is a waste of money to 90% of people.

The other thing I am disappointed in is the game library. As others have pointed out, there are a ton of games like "Petz" and "The Naked Brothers Band". There are some good ones like "Mario Party" and "Mario Kart" (supposedly, can't find a copy anywhere). There are Guitar Hero games for it too, but I want to see some more games for older people, one's that aren't first person shooter games.

This system is perfect for anybody under about 13. There need to be more games to make it perfect for anybody older than that, but still worth having.

author: A. G. Gant
title: Great exercise and fun
content:
I'm 63 years old and I exercise on a treadmill which I hate.  I bought the WII after searching for one for weeks.  They are hard to come by and sell out quickly.

Since buying the WII I have found out that much of my body was not getting the exercise it needed.  I have never played tennis and did not understand the game terms(points).  Now I play almost everyday and understand the terms.  I can tell the difference in my body.  I love my WII.  Great for your health.  There is also a game for eye coordination and memory.

author: M. Stephens
title: Works great! Great seller
content: The Wii was delivered quickly and my daughter loves it!  Works great!  Great seller!  Definitely gives him 2 thumbs up!! 👍🏻👍🏻

author: C. Bigelow
title: "Great Fun"
content: "Amazing", what alot of fun. Christmas day we had the entire family playing together. This is the best family entertainment system ever. I would reccommend it to anyone. My 3 & 4yr. old daughters just loved the bowling game and actually did very well(easy enough for them to understand how to use the controller).

author: Janmarie B. Weston
title: Weeeeeeeeeeeeeeeeeeeeeeee with Wii
content: I just love my Wii.  My son had purchased a Wii when he was still living at home and he got me Wii Fit and Dancing with the Stars.  When he moved out and took the Wii with him I had to get one of my own.  I enjoy the Fit games and challenge myself to improve every day.  It's great!

author: James Jameson
title: Great family fun!
content: Great fun for the family. And a very reliable console. Have never had any problems with the Wii

author: Stuck in NNJ
title: PS2 graphics with inside the game feel & control!
content: are the graphics PS3 or XBOX 360, no! This is PS2 graphics with interactive remotes to get you to feel like you are inside the game. For me this is much more fun and i can take the lesser graphics for more fun. As long as Nintendo opens the gates for developers, not to mention get some more units delivered in the US this is a GREAT FAMILY SYSTEM, even for the occasional gamer such as me. Spiderman 3 is going to ROCK this system!

author: Cometairy
title: Wii is wonderful!
content:
We bought a Wii the day after Thanksgiving and had a wonderful time with all our friends, gamers and non gamers alike.

setup:

super easy and very well explained, make sure you set up in a room that allows your full arm width as you will use up a lot of space. There is also a sensor that you will have to place in front of you for the controller to work, the distance of the sensor cord (for those with projection screens) is about half a rooms length. The only thing that took a long time during setup was the updates when we hooked it up to the internet (about 10min), and you have to make an account with Nintendo.

controller:

Awesome and very intuitive, even our non-gamer friends were able to get a hang of it within a minute.

the Mii: allows you to build an avatar (sp?) which you can allow to "travel" and interact with other people's Wii systems. These are a blast to make, all of our friends... even those who refuse to pick up a traditional controller, had a wonderful time building there characters and sending them out in the world. Not to mention any time we get lonely there they are ;)

parents: there is "log" that allows you to see what games have been played and for how long, as well as parental controls so you can control what your child plays when you are not around. I highly suggest you try to play as well, it really is a lot of fun, and easier to learn then a traditional consoles.

The sports game that is included:

great starter game to get you used to the controllers, not to mention alot of fun. It also allows you to track how many calories you have burned while playing tennis, bowling, baseball, golf and boxing. (And I don't even like sport games)

Overall:

it is very, very fun to play and great for parties with people of any age (we're in our late 20's and 30's). The controls are a wonderful innovation and very natural. I would suggest this for anyone, even non gamers. Several of our friends were considering PS3 and skipping the Wii, but after playing once they are determined to get one.

author: Jackson
title: Wii fun
content: We love the Wii.  Purchasing it from Amazon was easiest, no lines, no hassel and it arrived within a week.  I have a 7 year old he loves it, my elderly mother loves it, and my husband and I love it.  What a great workout.

author: Elizabeth
title: Five Stars
content: Great

author: J. Dragich
title: Wii will ... Wii will rock you!
content:
I just picked up a Wii yesterday along with Marvel Ultimate Alliance, and I love both! I have not owned a game console since the days of original Nintendo and Atari. I felt very left out by the game clearly designed for either young children or obsessive young males willing to spend 8 hours on a couch twitching their thumbs. I loved Wii Sports so much I have a sore arm today from countless games of bowling, tennis and golf. Yep, even golf is entirely entertaining for hours on Wii. Can Xbox or PS say that?

To everyone who gripes that the graphics can't compare to Xbox or PS, Jar Jar Binks used better graphics than Yoda in the original Star Wars trilogy but Jar Jar was still the worst movie character in history! If graphics were the most important part of a game, no one would have played Pac Man.

The Wii's graphics are fine. Really, once you play you stop paying attention to graphics. You'll be entirely focused on hitting the pitch coming at you! I've already rushed out and bought Legend of Zelda, too. I love the game play.

The Wii is the most innovative platform ever!

author: Brice S.
title: The Wii was a complete success.
content:
You know you scored big when Sony quickly tries to copy your success. I've had the Wii for a couple years now and I have been nothing more than impressed. Nintendo continues to be the biggest innovator of the gaming world. Sure they may not be your huge gamer platforms, but they are the most consistent gaming company in my opinion. Yes Playstation and Xbox are both very good platforms, but they don't go out on a limb like Nintendo does. I remember when the Wii came out many people said a double controller console would fail, but as usual Nintendo delivered (as they did on ever console they've made). Come late 2012 I will be investing in their newest creation, the Wii U. They have not failed me yet, so I'm sticking with these guys.

The games on Wii are very fun. They are not overly complicated, but still very entertaining. If your a gamer that needs tons of graphics and lots of high tech games, go with the Xbox and Plystation. Though the Wii is my favorite and the most entertaining to me, I fully under stand that it lacks in the newest tech race.

All this being said, I fully recommend the Nintendo Wii. I have every Nintendo console I've ever owned since I was 5, so scooping up a Wii now (even though late) will still serve as a great investment.

author: Dennis J. Logsdon

author: Pink Breadsticks
title: Just Plain Simple Fun For The Whole Family!
content:
Whew! All the drawn out technically challenged reviews are not necessary.
Just know that this system, made by Nintendo holds up to it's name. Your family from age 3 to 99 will certainly be entertained for many hours, days, & even nights to come. If you loved your GameCube, you'll love this more. It plays all your gamecube games, and you can even use your old GC controllers as it has 4 ports for them.

The best thing of all is how we can just pop in our SD card from our digital camera and let the fun begin with slideshows and many unique editing features! Come on join the fun! Paint a mustache on Grama and add some sunglasses to your favorite pet! Add some great background music to your shows!

Even totally surf the interenet with your Wii!

It's awesome!

author: JZRHSC
title: Nice system...graphics are better than I expected.
content: This has been a great system for the kids.  They have had a blast over the years with their games.  Graphics are better than expected and a surprisingly excellent range of games available.  With the Wii U now out, we'll probably upgrade--I hope it does not disapoint.

author: Vivian
title: I have owned this for over a year; absolutely no regrets.
content:
First of all, I took off a star because the Wii has some cons, but only a couple of them annoying; still, they warranted the loss of a star. Now to my reviews...

BASIC REVIEW:
This console is so fun, entertaining, and versatile I would be willing to pay twice as much money for it. The backward-compatibility with GameCube games & controllers plus the ability to download classic SNES, N64, etc. games makes this the only Nintendo console you need. Additionally, the News, Weather, Everybody Votes Channel, Internet Channel, Photo Channel, and many others will serve your needs beautifully. It's very easy to use this device ten hours a day, seven days a week and not get bored of it.

DETAILED REVIEW:
In addition to what I said in my basic review, the Wii has the following:

Pros:
-Small, stylish form factor and the ability to rest horizontally or vertically make the Wii a great accent to any room.
-Motion sensor completely revolutionizes gameplay. It feels very natural to point at what you want or to turn the controller when steering a virtual vehicle. That's right. Mario Kart Wii with Wii Wheel takes advantage of this new technology to bring gamers what they've been instinctively been trying to do for years: steer by twisting the controller.
-The simple Wii remote is so easy and intuitive to use you quickly forget about it and get immersed in the game.
-Remember not being able to pause your games? Not any more. By pressing the Home button on the "Wii-mote," as I like to call it, you can instantly freeze the game. On that menu one can check the battery levels in all four controllers, go directly to the home menu, get help (when using a channel), or rearrange the order of Wii-motes (1st player becomes 3rd player, for example.)
-The wireless Internet connection allows for easy software updates, game/channel downloads, and Internet viewing.
-Parental Controls can restrict children from viewing inappropriate material on the Internet, changing Wii settings, or spending money on the Wii Store.
-Portability: the Wii is the lightest full-featured console on the market and the smallest, which makes it a breeze to carry it in a case. I recommend the Wii G-pak Console Organizer Case - Black; I've been using it for months. It performed admirably during my two transcontinental flights and the Wii & accessories all came out without a scratch.

Cons:
-Motion sensor doesn't work if the Wii remote isn't aligned in front of the TV or with an unblocked line of vision to the Sensor Bar. For four people to play at once you need to sit side-by-side.
-Using a wireless router with a password more complex than a WPA password won't work with the Wii. Also, you have to type the password on the screen - not good if other people are there.
-The Parental Controls are dumb, in my opinion. By dumb I do not mean useless, I mean stupid. Instead of categorically blocking content, they can only block the entire channel. For instance, to block pornography on the Internet Channel you must restrict the whole thing, same with the Wii Shop Channel and Wii Settings. Your four-digit password is required to access them at all.
-The Wii needs an adaptor to connect using Ethernet.
-The Internet loader is pretty slow - you'll want to stick to a computer.
-When downloading items from the Wii Shop Channel, an annoying Mario runs across the screen collecting coins and occasionally hitting one of the three overhead blocks. The noise is supremely irritating; I recommend muting the TV.
-The Wii uses a moderate graphics processor - no high definition gaming like in the XBox 360 or PlayStation 3.
-It's easy to accidentally move a character on the screen when simply reaching for something in the real world - the Wii-mote's motion sensors see to that.

Overall, the cons are pretty easy to tolerate - I barely notice them. I only listed the cons so you'd have a thorough understanding of what you're going to get. The reason I brought my Wii on two transcontinental flights was because I had so much fun without it, I couldn't bare going a whole month without playing my Wii.

You might say the Wii is expensive. Two hundred fifty dollars could buy you about 50 meals. However, when compared with the XBox 360 and PlayStation 3, the Wii is much more fun (I own all three consoles and have used them extensively; the Wii reigns supreme) and cheaper. If you're thinking about getting a new game console, get a Wii. Besides, why do you think it's still sold out after a year and a half of being out? It's a wonderful device. Trust me, you'll be glad you spent the money for it.

author: Carlos

content: with new games like punch-out the wii proves that it's still got it. But the lack of good games is a downer.The good games like mario kart and brawl make the system worth having if you don't mind giving up the graphics that is

content: My grandson recommended this game. I am having so much with the bowling that I havent gotten to the golf or tennis.  Great for the family or individual.

author: Robert
title: Good
content: Great

author: Doreen G. Crowe
title: Fun for Family Night
content: I am not a fan of video games but the Wii is at a different level.  It's fun for the whole family but there are games that you can play by yourself as well.  I don't like the fighting games, however.  I like only the games that gets you active in sports.

author: Josue A. Rico
title: Had it since the day it came out!
content: The long line at Gamestop pays off because the Wii was worth every penny!  First in motion control, the ability to buy older NES, SNES, N64, etc games (even though for 5, 8 and 10 dollars per game its kinda expensive), but best of all, all the Nintendo franchise games (Mario Galaxy, Galaxy 2, Metroid Prime 3, Zelda Twilight Princess, Wario smooth moves, Fire Emblem, Paper Mario, Donkey Kong Country Returns, and the list goes on! This is a must buy!

author: S Martin
title: Wii vs The Rest Review
content:
Let me start out by saying I have owned all three current gen systems.  With the recent price drops I think now is a good time to do a simple comparison so I'll do my best.  I'm actually on my second wii, i bought one in 2006 at the launch and after 3 years it stopped reading discs. I think my issue was pretty isolated, but honestly I can't complain I got plenty of entertainment value out of it for the price in my honest opinion.  The only other hardware issue I have had is the lights on the remotes, they seem to burn out very quickly for me, but it doesn't ruin the function of the remote.

So how does the wii stack up against the ps3 and the xbox?  Quite honestly it really only beats the others in two departments and with the recent price drop it's more like one, but it's a biggie!  The wii is FUN, it's fun for a group of people, it's fun for people who don't play video games on a regular basis and for ones that do.  My wife and I play the wii together quite a bit, we always play it when friends visit and it's a lot of fun.  It doesn't have the graphics of the ps3 or the xbox 360, it isn't the media hub that the other two are, for the most part what the games lack in graphics they make up for easily in fun.

The controllers are innovative, the game play is innovative and prior to the price drop of the xbox and ps3 I would have said if you only buy one system the wii is definitely worth considering.  With the price drops of all of the systems the choice is not so easy now.  My recommendation, i guess would be this:  If you plan on playing a lot with friends and family when the visit and not so much by yourself or online then the wii is a solid choice.  If you plan on playing online games and playing a lot of solo games then I've got to recommend the PS3 or even the Xbox (you can see my ps3 vs xbox review for my conclusion on the winner there).

Hopefully this review will be helpful to someone doing their xmas shopping this year.

author: Michael Hall

author: N. Christie

content: I bought this for my husband for Christmas. He loved it, that was no surprise. What was a surprise was that I love it too!I never expected that I would enjoy it so much!!! It is an amazing console, extemely entertaining. I highly recommend this product.

title: If you dont have one jump on it !!!
content: I love it me and my 2yr old son have a blast playing , great awesome family fun a must have if your a nintendo system fan ...

author: Margaret
title: I'm one of the ones who nabbed one from Amazon!
content:
I'm one of those lucky ones who managed to nab one of these Wiis from Amazon during the minute it was available.  It arrived yesterday, and I have to say that I'm very impressed just like everyone else seems to be.

I just wanted to point out 2 little things about the system that aren't a big deal, but are a little annoying.

1. There's a sensor bar that senses the movements of your remote/nunchuck.  You have to attach it to the top of your tv or in front of the tv.  Makes the system hard to move from room to room, which my kids like to do.

2. The remote/nunchuck makes noises during gameplay.  And there's no way to turn the sound down.  At least as far as I know.  A problem when your kid wants to play till 3am and everyone else wants to go to bed!

Like I said, those are just small little things. The system is just great, and I'm sure we'll be getting more games and controllers soon.

author: Valerie Kendrick
title: Five Stars
content: Great gift for kids!

author: Reflection Haiku
title: It's Game, It's Sports, It's Fun for the Family
content: I used to be proud that we don't have Wii so we can spend more time reading; now I am proud that our family has Wii so we can do our exercises in PJs quickly and move back to reading. We have two young children that love all kinds of sports. Unfortunately they have a very inactive mom who knows nothing about sports except Yoga. Wii comes to our rescue and we are on our way to become top athletes in five sports areas that come with the initial Wii console. They are very easy to install and you can play instantly once the cables are plugged in and several bottoms pushed. My daughter (ages 5) loves especially the Mii where you create little you for the Wii games. She creates all our relatives and friends so we get huge audience to cheer and watch us play sports. She changes our hairstyles daily and adjusts Dad's weight according to his diet results. Very fun to watch! The kids love bowling, golfing and tennis. My son tries the boxing and to my relief, it is not graphic at all and in the end both opponents dance happily together. Whether going to bowling or winning the Bronze medals were illusions or not, the pain we felt the next day after the workout was certainly real. It's game, it's sports, and it's the fun time for the whole family.

author: B. Family
title: SERIOUSLY- WHO GET'S THEIR TURN FIRST!!!
content:
Decided to get the Wii after a bit of research on the internet. My main reason for purchase was all of the positive feedback on the Wii Fit Plus. This is a additional item that you purchase in addition to the Wii gaming Console.
I was inspired for how fun it is and can be to do virtual workouts- while also losing weight and inches. While results are not drastic- It does get you up and excited to complete each day to see and track your progress. That seemed to me like a something I would enjoy. I have yet to make the purchase for the Wii fit plus- but the Wii is very fun. It's fun to watch the family aiming at things as though they exist in front of them. The control has a nice gel pad for added protection from the unexpected (Accidental tossing of the remotes). LOL!!! It has a bit of sound and vibrations that come from it as you use or play the item. While my family is not completely the gamer type- The Wii has options. The item arrived within days from Amazon- and I appreciate the fact that I do not have to pay tax on items I order from them. I live in Florida and my sales tax is 6-7% depending on the county you live in. I always save when making Amazon purchases all around. Who doesn't love savings?

author: kickey herron
title: Five Stars
content: i love it

author: Amazon Customer
title: I am happy that we finally decided to purchase it
content: I am happy that we finally decided to purchase it! My kids have so much fun! They are not just sitting all day long playing with games, they have to move a lot with these games!

author: jeremiah
title: Five Stars
content: Great product

author: Lrogoz
title: Fun for the whole family
content: This came for Christmas from Santa for our 8 year old. It has not disappointed. The whole famiy has been playing it, even the 2 year old can bowl with help. I don't feel so bad about my 8 year old playing video games so much now because he is active while playing, not just sitting on the couch.

author: R. Drouin
title: Gets some major things right, but leaves out some other major features
content:
The Wii is a console of perplexing decisions. Revolutionary control scheme? It has that, but the hardware in the wiimote lacks accuracy for finer movements, leaving most games to rely on broad, simple strokes and the pointer features.

How about the built in wi-fi? This is a fantastic feature, and it's great to see it on such a low priced unit. But it lacks a built in network jack, instead requiring the user to buy a Nintendo USB dongle to connect the thing to your network "the old fashion way".

Nintendo also released a while back it's Wii ware channel. This is sort of Nintendo's response to Xbox Live arcade or Xbox live community games. It's a great feature that lets smaller developers get there games out to a much larger audience. The problem is that the Wii only has 256 megs of built in memory to store those games on, and no hard drive support is promised. Things get tight quickly.

On the audio visual side this console is a joke. For a full 50 bucks less you can buy a machine that does HD graphics and supports proper surround sound. Dolby Digital 5.1 has been around for a long, long time now, and to not even include an optical port on the Nintendo wii is vexing to say the least. If you care at all about how your games look or sound, avoid this platform. The graphics hardware it's self is essentially a game cube repackaged. If you get a chance, run the original Halo that came out as a launch game for the Xbox against any Wii game. Halo typically looks better, and it came out 6 years ago.

Next there is the online experience. As mentioned before, Nintendo was kind enough to provide wifi support on the console and with that connection they give you access to free online gaming. But rather than having a unified friends list like Xbox live or PSN, your required to trade 16-digit friend codes in order to friend someone, and those friends don't necessarily persist from game to game. This means swapping friend codes for every single game you play on the wii. Not my idea of fun. In addition to the online gaming, Nintendo also offers a news reader, weather channel, web surfing and some other fun extras. These features ultimately are fairly useless as most people who have a Wii connected via wifi also have a PC connected that can run it's screen at a higher resolution and thus make for a much more pleasant web surfing experience.

So what is good about this thing? Where the Wii proves to be at it's best is in exactly the same spots where Nintendo consoles have always been at there best - local multilayer gaming. 4-player split screen Mario kart will always be fun, and Wii sports shows that introducing motion controls allows simple sports movements to be replicated in a party atmosphere with some degree of accuracy (although, admittedly, not all that much accuracy either). If your the type of person who wants to have 4 people in front of the TV to game, then this console is a good buy. Just remember: 3 extra wii motes and nunchucks will run you approximately an extra 180 dollars (although you can save a bit buy buying online). At that price, you could have a blu-ray playing PS3.

Lastly, there is the software. This console has shown it's self to be just like every other Nintendo console ever made - First party Nintendo games sell great but everyone else not so much. The result has been smaller, lower funded development teams developing piles of shovel ware for the system. This console lacks any major AAA 3erd party games. Generally the only AAA games on this platform are Nintendo made, and even those are generally retreads of older Nintendo game such as Smash Bros and Mario Kart. We've played these games before, and they want us to spend 60 bucks to play them again.

To any a/v nut or anyone who loves AAA games out there, this console is an utter waste of your time and money. I couldn't recommend it less. But to anyone who just wants a simple, go have fun with your friends on the couch experience, it would be hard for me to recommend a better platform. It will be a smash hit at thanksgiving and Christmas get together, but when your board on a Wednesday night and alone, this consoles poor online and lack of AAA games will leave you board.

author: MERLE
title: Five Stars
content: works very good thxs

author: Irunnoft
title: Wii - believe the hype!
content:
I've got one each of the "next gen" gaming consoles and there's nothing out there like the Wii!  I was skeptical that it would really be all THAT fun, but I was wrong.  Currently, I spend about equal amounts of time playing the Wii as I do my Xbox 360.  Sadly, my PS3 has been mostly used for Blu Ray movies.

The Wii is an entirely different gaming experience that the 360.  In fact, it's unlike anything I've ever experienced thus far.  For the most part, I play games like Gears of War, Crackdown, FEAR, etc. on my Xbox 360.  These are games that take full advantage of the processing power of the Xbox - this is the 1080i stuff that just looks amazing on my XBR2.  However, when I want to play something that's just plain fun. . . the Wii is fast and easy to use!

I know there are games like Madden '07 that are available on both systems, but the graphics aren't going to approach the same quality as that of the Xbox.  So, that begs the question, why buy the Wii version?  For the new type of game playing. . . motion detection in the Wii remote!  The WAY you play the games can actually be more important than the raw processing power of the unit itself!  Yeah!  Sounds crazy, but it's true!

Nintendo certainly hit one out of the park with the Wii!  There are some in-depth shooters for this system (Red Steel, COD3, Far Cry, etc.) and some more on the way (Metroid Prime 3 Corruption) as well as games that don't require as much involvement or commitment (Elebits, Smooth Moves, Ray Man, etc.).  Either way, the Wii is a LOT of fun and the controllers aren't an issue for extended gaming periods.

I think a lot of people expected to be able to walk into stores and just pick up a Wii a few weeks after launch.  The irony is that I've seen PS3s just collecting dust on shelves in Best Buy and Wal-Mart, while I've yet to see a Wii on the store shelves!  Obviously Wii would like to play!

author: Christopher Blizzard
title: Awesome for casual non-gamer
content: Of course everyone will say that the graphics don't compare to 360 or PS3, duh! But this system is for having fun with other people in the same room, not sitting in a dark basement for hours yelling into a headset mic.

author: Shdwfthsun
title: It's cool I guess
content:
The Wii is basically a Gamecube in a smaller white package with motion control. Some new features besides motion control have been added though, and now you can: view photos off SD cards, create weird little people that kind of look like you called Miis, and (given you have a wi-fi connection or adapter) download Nintendo's entire back catalog of games, vote on stuff, view the weather, read the news, and surf the internet with it (including youtube, myspace, and flash game sites).

On the games side, the Wii is pretty boring if you don't have any friends or family to play with, mainly because there are just two good single-player games that have come out: Zelda and Super Paper Mario. Soon that will change though as Metroid Prime 3: Corruption, Super Mario Galaxy, Resident Evil: Umbrella Chronicles, Super Smash Bros. Brawl, and Soul Calibur Legends arrive on store shelves. Overall it's a good system but one that only excels above the others in price and controller innovation.

Excellent console for this generation.

author: Janet M.
title: Home-brew Hacked system - wasted hours of my 'time' finally learning this. System was sold as hacked
content: I don't usually write reviews unless really happy or really disappointed in a purchase/product, but I feel this one necessary to write to share my disappointment and frustrations. My son was having difficulties getting this system to do updates so he could sync the system to the internet from the moment he took it out of the box. It was not allowing him to do so and consistently sending "code error". We "chatted" with Nintendo for a good 45 minutes (they were very nice) and they had us do Speed tests on our internet and asked us to try many things to troubleshoot. The best they could come up with the FIRST time we called Nintendo was to call our internet service provider and check from them to see if our speed was ok and if that was the problem. We did and they said there was no problem from their end. A couple days later WHEN I FOUND YET MORE "FREE" TIME my son and I called Nintendo and this time it was about 25 minute call. This person had us do a few things and BINGO... The system was "Home brew hacked". Not knowing anything about this, and knowing my son wanted to play a few games and this hacking prevented him to do so, the man I spoke with said the system was compromised.  In all, I believe we WASTED over two hours of time to find out we were sold a system that was NOT stripped or refurbished to factory settings. Now, I have to take the time to pack it up, print label, bring to UPS. Do yourself a favor and ask if it TRULY is being sold as reset to the factory settings. I kicked myself for not going to GameStop to look for a pre-owned system, because they had plenty and I paid $79.99 and can go locally to get any help if needed. They assured me the system was re-set and that they'd never sell any system compromised such as this one was. I'm just so frustrated they would sell this. Would have been nice to use all the WASTED time playing a game on the wii with my son, not troubleshooting from the minute it came out of the box.

author: wendell alberry jr

content: we had a ps2 it went up so we got a wii and the grand kids love it there are a lot of games for the wii

author: joan
title: Five Stars
content: The Wii game console worked great I am pleased with it

author: JoLeene Boguslawski
title: Wonderful fun
content: I bought this on a whim and am absolutely glad that I did.  I enjoy the challenge of beating my previous score in bowling, but have not been able to master the links or boxing.  My muscles were sore for over a week, but it was worth the fun and laughter it brought to the household.

author: slopyjoe71
title: Best thing since sliced bread
content:
I knew that the Nintendo Wii was going to be great, but I was still shocked at how great it actually is. I got the Wii for Christmas and haven't stopped playing. The Wii is the best video game system I've ever played and I've played them all. I was with my in-laws for Christmas when I got the Wii. I opened it and figured I'd take it upstairs and set it up because they wouldn't be interested. Boy was I wrong. They all told me to hook it up downstairs, so I did. We spent the next few hours taking turns playing Wii sports against each other. Even people who had never played video games in there life played the Wii, including parents that are almost 70. The Wii did exactly what it was made to do. It brought the whole family together and got people to play video games that had never played before. Nintendo would be proud.

The gameplay is amazing and extremely fun. It presents a whole new way of playing video games. The motion sensing is almost flawless once you get use to it. It even gives you a little exercise. My right arm is sore from all the wii sports I was playing. The graphics are great, much better than the gamecube and these are only first generation games. Things will only get better once more software developers create more and better ways to use the wii-mote.

Overall, I would say the Nintendo Wii is a MUST BUY for everyone. It provides hours of entertainment and has something for everyone. Gameplay is awesome 5 stars, and the graphics are great 5 stars. (of course not as good as Xbox360 or PS3, but graphics can only get so good then you have to create better gameplay, the graphics are good enough, Zelda looks awesome)

author: Michelle E. Perz
title: Not for RPG players.
content: First, let me say that there are many positives to the Nintendo Wii. The system is intuitively designed and, if you enjoy the motion sensing novelty, can be extremely enjoyable. However, one of my biggest reservations about buying the Wii in the first place was that it lacked a range of RPG titles, leaving me with games like Mario Kart and Super Smash Bros that are fun, to be sure, but provide me with many less hours of entertainment than my PS2 did. Unfortunately, until Sony can fix its backwards compatibility issue and bring its mid-range models down in price, the Wii is the more cost-effective and more affordable option.

author: Jesse Mumm
title: Nintendo Wii
content: I first made this purchase to actually turn around and sell it .... I was able to get the last one out of a shipment.  When I told people they would just rave how fun it was so my husband and I had to try it out....well we did and we are NOT gaming people we love to hike camp do outside things but we LOVE LOVE LOVE the wii it keeps us active while playing a game my four year old also loves it this is GREAT FAMILY FUN for all ages!

author: Leon
title: Five Stars
content: Fun to play with friends and family.

author: Alicia J. Phillips
title: Technodealz is the best
content: After not being able to find a Wii anywhere in town, I ordered from Technobiz - they stuck by their promise 110%!  It was here as promised (if not faster).  I also ordered from them for a friend after being so pleased, and hers was the delivered quickly (faster than promised).  I will definitely order all of my stuff from them!

author: Talon Karrde
title: Great
content:
The Nintendo Wii is a great system. Albeit the Accessories you need or want to purchase on top of buying the system and expensive games are costly, and there is a lack of decent games for the Wii as it is. If you are looking for a system that would be fun to play with friends and family then I highly recommend the Wii. Easy to play games make it fun for all ages, but you will need to purchase expense wiimotes and nunchucks in order to have up to four players in a game. Its an addition $40 for each wiimote and another $20 for each nunchuck. Not to mention if you want to buy a charging station with rechargeable battery packs for your wiimotes (theres another $40 or so) and then there are the games you would buy for it and possibly the cost of Wii points to download games to your system. You might also need a memory card for the Wii if you intend to save a lot of data. All in all, its a good system but you have to know what you want it for. I personally bought it to play new versions of the Nintendo brand games I know and love. Also it does make a good game night with friends, so that is an added benefit.

The point: If you are willing to invest $250 just to buy the system, be prepared to spend another $250 or more on equipment and games, 3 more wiimotes and nunchucks alone with set you back another $180.

The future: I look forward to the day when gaming systems with become generic like televisions, and you only need to worry about which brand to  buy because they all play the same games. Its a bright future, lets hope we get to that point. Then perhaps focus can be drawn to the games themselves and quality of gaming experiences will increase 10 fold.

author: S. Amick
title: Wii Well Worth the Price!
content:
We had been waiting to purchase a Wii for some time and so when the prices dropped and Amazon offered free shipping and a $25 gift card toward the purchase of another Wii product, we had to order!  We absolutely love it!  However, I am still awaiting arrival of that $25 gift card!  Hopefully it will arrive soon.  We plan to purchase the Wii Fit Plus with it.  Cannot wait!  You really do get a work out with this unit just playing the simple games that come with it so we really want the Wii Fit to get in shape and lose weight over the winter months.  Plus, it's just plain fun!  The whole family can use this product it's so simple!  I highly recommend one to everyone!

I just want to add to the review of yesterday that, while we love are Wii and have no complaints about it, I do have a problem with Amazon and the way they do business!  When I purchased the Wii I was of the understanding, by their description, I would receive a $25 gift card as described above.  It sounded as though it was an automatic receipt, no instructions were included how to obtain it.  After waiting over 2 weeks I contacted them to find that apparently I must enter a promo code, which I did not have, and set it as a "purchase" in order to obtain the gift card!  Well Amazon can keep their gift card, I want my Wii Fit now!  That being said, I will simply go to Wal Mart and purchase it since I was going to have to purchase it with a credit card anyway!  Way to go Amazon!

author: Caps fan 1
title: Great Purchase
content: Bought this product (Nintendo WII) for my nephew for Christmas. He is having the time of his life. Great transaction, Amazon was wonderful and not having to stand in lines or run from store to store was the best part. Free shipping was also nice. Look forward to doing more business with Amazon. I just wish I had ordered some other gifts from them instead of trying to save a couple of bucks with lesser known companies ( like SUPERBDVDSETS) and getting burned.

author: Joshua J. Hawkins
title: Just plain fun
content: In the few weeks since I finally got my hands on Wii the thing that has surprised my most has been how much I've just enjoyed playing fun, simple games like Wii sports.  I've played first person shooters for years, and have loved them.  Over the years though I've discovered they are a lot like action movies though, same plot, often enjoyable, but fairly repetitive and predictable.  I bought a Wii in hopes of experiencing different types of games.  And so far I have been pleasantly surprised.  I never thought I'd want to play tennis every day, but it's a great little 20 minute break from work to get me re-energized and get me out of my chair (the joys and perils of the home office).  Ultimately I think this system has great potential and I hope the game designers take advantage of the new possibilities.  It's been exactly what I was looking for in a game system, fun.

author: Beckie

I have owned the nintendo, the sega genesis, playstation, PS2, x box and gameboys(regular, color, DS, etc...) AND the Wii is the only one that i still play. sitting in front of a TV is boring to me, and it makes me not want to play video games. the only other system that remotely compares to the Wii is my DS, but still i give the Wii 5 stars. its really is good clean fun, and a great way to get fit while you play. i can spend 3 hours playing a workout game, and not even realize how long i was playing for. then wake up the next day with my arms sore (so i KNOW im getting good exercise which is great). i would recommend this to anyone of any age from young children to teens to adults :)

author: Christopher Higginbotham

author: Sandi Orth

author: Gregor
title: BEWARE of GAMEFASTTT - Broken Wii
content: My Wii took over two weeks to arrive. Played great for Sports Plus but after buying Zelda SS I noticed lots of mis-placed pixels. I googled the prob and everything said fried GPU (Graphics Card). I informed the seller who promptly offered a refund so long as I paid for it to be shipped back. I don't feel I should have been responsible for shipping considering I ordered a LIKE NEW item, but the seller would not bend. I did pay because losing out on $12.00 is better than being stuck with a broken Wii. My return shipment took two days to arrive compared to the two weeks I waited for arrival. I will not order from this vendor again based on my experience. Thanks Game Fasttt!

author: Doug McKinnon
title: It's a Revolution!
content:
I was on the fence for a long time about the Wii. First, I was a bit hesitant because I kept expecting another "Gameboy Advance - Now with brighter screen!" fiasco. Uh huh. Spend the money on a Wii and they come out with a new one several months later. Or a smaller version - the WiiLite perhaps? So I stayed on that fence for quite a while and waved my hand at any encouragement to go out and buy one.

Then one day I was at a friend's house and he asked if I'd liked to play a game of bowling on his new Wii. I said sure, what the heck. It was free. So he started it up and handed me a Wiimote. That was all it took. After a day's worth of gaming on the Wii I was hooked. I was immediately impressed with the fluid responsiveness of the remote - picking up even the slightest wrist movement could turn your throw into a wicked curve or a straight on dead shot. Another thing that amazed me is that after playing a days worth of bowling and golf I was sore for a week.

The following week my brother came by to visit and I mentioned I had played the Wii and he shocked me by saying he had played it too and loved the bowling game. This was news to me since I knew my brother did not care for video games. Since he was hanging out for the evening I decided to take the plunge and we went to our local Gamestop and I picked up the Wii and an extra controller. We went home and I hooked the console up and we spent the evening bowling. It was the most fun we'd had together since camping as kids.

This is the main reason I love the Wii, because Nintendo has done exactly what they set out to do - they have created a gaming console that gets you up, gets you involved, and gets people together. They should have stuck with their original name, because in this regard the Wii is definitely a revolution.

author: Joan Mack
title: Wii doesn't work
content: The wii doesn't work! I was so excited to get this for my class and they were excited to get to use it but it doesn't work. I am not able to afford a lot for equipment since I a responsible to buy my own equipment for my classroom. I guess the price was too good to believe.

author: BLEEKER
title: SO MUCH FUN ITS UNREAL!!
content: I bought this by luck, I waited on line for 8 hours and that was just a few days ago! Its amazing how much in demand this system is, I can see why now. I've owned EVERY game consol since the original Nintendo game out and I must say, this is THE MOST fun i've ever had with ANY system hands down. Its taylor made for group play. I quickly got bored playing my xbox 360. The graphics are great but at its core it's still the same gameplay and the same games just repackaged in a fancy new box. IThe possibilites for the Wii are just limitless. I cant wait till the games start rolling out nad developers really tap into the Wii potential. So far,its amazing!

author: D. Santiago

content: I've had the system since it came out. I'm a 15 year old boy. Ya i like playing games like Halo. Even though the Wii doesn't have the best graphics out of all 3...its the only 1 that keeps me enterained long enough. Xbox 360 sucks after a while because the only game i hear about is Gears of War *Notice Gears of War is just another Halo* and no one else is online when i play my other games 75% of my friends are playing Gears of War. PS3 sucks because everyone who brought it is either a Kingdom Hearts Fan or Final Fantasy Fan or just want Assis. Creed which by the looks of what i've seen is just another Prince Of Persia with better graphics. Zelda isn't the greatest game since they said over 50 hours or game play and i beat it in less then 15 hours. But my point is that even my parents play it *Note: They are over 40 years old*

author: Gabriel Orellana

author: mel
title: I love this product
content:
I love this product. It has cemented both my status as the awesome aunt and as the good daughter.

I bought this for both of my parents' health, and for my nieces' and nephews' entertainment.

The kids love the sports games on this system so much. Unlike with the other console that we have, they don't sit down and play all day long. This console forces them to get up and be active. They don't even realize that they're exercising and having fun at the same time.

My parents enjoy the low impact games that I bought for this system. It helps with their mobility and entertains them.

author: P. Lauzon
title: I Love My Wii!
content:
I have to hand it to Nintendo, they have created a different way to play video games, and boy is it fun!  I would recommend the Wii to anyone who loves video games....heck, I would recommend the Wii to anyone.  I have never had this much fun playing a video game. You are almost launched into the game. My mother-in-law played the wii bowling and she loved it. I only have the Wii sports game, but so far I'm lovin' it. I find that even the Mii channel and picture channel are fun to play with.

I have nothing bad to say about the Nintendo Wii.

If you can afford it, buy it.  It truly is a new way to be entertained.

author: yehinmy

author: Aquanex Frost

author: C. CHEN
